From sfraves-return-143112-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat Dec 01 08:24:49 2007
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-143112-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 2457 invoked by uid 1103); 1 Dec 2007 08:24:48 -0000

Received: (qmail 2441 invoked from network); 1 Dec 2007 08:24:47 -0000
Message-ID: <2520.71.198.250.91.1196497487.squirrel@secure.saturn5.com>
Date: Sat, 1 Dec 2007 00:24:47 -0800 (PST)
From: "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Reply-To: osby@viberation.com
User-Agent: SquirrelMail/1.4.10a
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] oooh... my Thrusday night Reveiw

OK... so like on the way to the BART station... got into this conversation
with this guy who was all packed to go to Vietnam to hang out w/ the
buddists & i just made sure he knew how to take what bart train etc & I
said he could shadow me if he needed too.. so we got to the BART station..
then i dunno.. like he got lost :(  Hope he made it to SFO :|

So the DubStep party @ Shine was fuckin' SIIICK!!!  I mean.. ok.. all the
DJs who spun did their own like groove w/ the dubstep... Kid Kameleon put
hella 2 Step in his set & I was like totally so diggin' that hardcore
man!!!  But yeah... all the DJs rocked it!!  I was on the floor dancin' my
ass off!  But when it got too hot, & it did 'cause like for as tiny as
Shine is... like it was packed shoulder to shoulder the whole night!!  But
yeah... when Plastician got up & dropped his tunes... oooooh fuck yeah!!! 
For me... he played good then hella bult up his set to like something
Dope!!!  Like the longer her was on.. the harder his bests got & ummm...
it's hard to like really define.. just that it got harder & deeper &
yummy!!  There were alota vocal tunes that sampled alot old skool pop
songs.. none that i could rememeber atm... but ooh YUM!! Plastician did
that alot more towards the end if i remember correctly :)

The crowd was good too!!!  I mean.. like alota the dubstep family
repped... a few Thursday night randoms that followed where the big crowd
outside was... some Sine Regs.. & like alot of berners where there too!! 
It was Fun1!!  There was even this 1 burner i was hangin out w/.. forgot
her name.. but she got me & this other guy like we did these hand like
holding/ touching things where we exchanged energy in our bodies.. that
was kinda intense actually & was very fitting with the music goin' on!!! 
Oh yeah... before i forget, Levi who used to be on this list was there
lastnight!!!  he told me to tell whoever remembered him that he says HI &
well... he kinda hinted to me that he misses SFR & hoefully we'll see him
again!!!

Unfortunately i didn't end up going to Temple anymore for my Jungle fix...
I mean... ooh man.. the vibe @ Shine was sooooo damn fuckin' yummy & the
music was totally what i needed!!!

The adventure home this time around was kinda well... scary!!!  Like after
Shine.. we all kicked it outside then these burners who were like in a
groiup huddle, all beat boxing a dubstep beat & Manny Vibes started
spitting lyrics.. lol.. it was soo cute!! ;)  Then as the crowd kinda
dwindled down.. i walked over to Cat Club to see who was still working @
1984 or like who mighta been clubbing there that night.. but well... no
one was there... but ok.. like mean... from Shine to CC.. like there was
this lady who followed.. iy kinda freaked me out 'cause i'd stop to let
her pass, then she start diggin' in a trash can then follow me again...
then when i was walin' down folsum to got to AllStar Donuts... this man
with a cart well.. it seemed like he was following me.. then another scary
guy like told me he needed $1.75 to make it back down to Stanford & i told
him i only had a bart ticket & a bus ticket to get home & i was sorry... I
mean.. i had like 2 bucks for coffee & donut for that caffine & sugar
boost i needed so i wouldn't fall alseep on bart.. & another $1 for my
bart tix & i could easily like pass through the gate thingie in bart for
the bike people.. but i didn't wanna another $80 fine for doing that &
figured using my $1 ok yeah.. i was guilty.. but anywaze

so i got over to ALLSTAR, then a homeless guy like opened the door for
me... got my coffee & well.. turned out i didn't have anough for a donut &
BART, so i choose bart instead... & while i drank my coffee... like i
dunno.. hella scary people came in allstar & I just like totally minded my
own business@!!

Wheni was walkin' to BART, some security guy started yellng @ me for
taking pictures of street signs, & then when i got to bart... some guy
tried sellin me a $3 bart tix for $10... on top of that... the BART
schedule seems like slightly different now & the bus schedule was totally
diff too.. but YAAAAY... i got home!! OK.. the end!!!


-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

all your reviews are fucking crazy adventures man, love reading them :)

I wonder if I know the guy trying to get to Stanford, did he look like a
student?

and lastly, I know this is going to make me sound like a retard, but what
exactly is Dubstep?  I couldn't find it on Ishkur's guide (while I don't
trust what Ishkur says he does post samples).  I have a mysterious feeling
that I've heard it somewhere before and liked it a lot but just didn't know
what it was labeled.  Is it sort of what Bassnectar and his usual retinue
play?  Please educate me.

SUNDAY SESH II- free outdoor renegade
Sunday, December 2nd- East Bay
10 AM until we get arrested!
BBQ, beats, and b11d's!!! 

Location: Map will be posted on CaliGrownEvents.com message board on
 day of party.

Come join DJ's: 
Mark Phinney vs. Chuck G
Marc(o) vs. J.C. the DJ
Dangrsmind
Dean Kroh
DJ Hil

It's time for another renegade jam session! This month we'll be
 throwing it down at an abandoned UG spot in the East Bay; with the Bay & some
 battleships for our backdrop. Hope you can make it, email
 chuckg_421@yahoo.com if any questions.

peace
CKG

------=_Part_5504_21809247.1196547268386
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

I'd love to hear others' opinions about Dubstep but my feeling about it is
that it's slower, broken drum and bass. Some of it includes the standards
reverbs and ragga mc touches found in "dub" proper, as well as
dancehall. Some of the techier varieties are interesting....

I know Kode 9 was at Mutek this year, which signaled a diversion of the
festival from its typical minimal techno/experimental showcase. Here's a
live performance clip from Sonar:

http://youtube.com/watch?v=3DaQo8XSLI2RY&feature=3Drelated

And a performance vid from NY that I like:

http://youtube.com/watch?v=3DyZe2ZN3Wh34&feature=3Drelated

-Jennifer/Solekandi

> > dwindled down.. i walked over to Cat Club to see who was still working =

> > one was there... but ok.. like mean... from Shine to CC.. like there wa=
s

> > her pass, then she start diggin' in a trash can then follow me again...

> > with a cart well.. it seemed like he was following me.. then another
> scary
> > guy like told me he needed $1.75 to make it back down to Stanford & i

> > him i only had a bart ticket & a bus ticket to get home & i was sorry..=

t
> &

> > dunno.. hella scary people came in allstar & I just like totally minded
> my
> > own business@!!

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Anyone up on "Sweet"?



"Sweet" is a series hosted by Lost Tribe, which was formed by Jim Cyr (a
frequent poster on here) and Matt Stone.  They started going their events
back in 1997 and with over 1,000 parties under my belt, they remain at the
top of my list as having organized some of the most vibiest I've ever
participated in. I find this post sort of ironic since most of their "Sweet"
events were actually held at Cell Space. Having built their own strong,
underground following through the years, Lost Tribe has never used lists and
other types of internet promo to get the word out about their events and
while there was a day when many a SFRave-lister would be familiar with Sweet
experiences, I'm not sure how many still ramain on here that could share
their experiences at past Sweet events.  But, I'm here and I'm sure Jim Cyr
will post up when he sees this.  And while pictures can't convey experience,
I do happen to have a few links to past Sweet events on my website's pix
section. Here's one that was captured at one of the many parties they held
at Cell Space.

http://www.djdragnfly.com/pix/Nov25-2000/SWEETACRACKBETWEENTHEWORLDS/images/
sweet%205.jpg

To sum it up, Sweet parties are hella Sweet.

; )
D

Hey gang... I was just wondering if anyone was up on a group called "Sweet",

Lately, I've been participating on the events commitee at Cellspace, and it
looks like we're going to go with Sweet on New Years Eve...
I was just wondering if anyone knows what their gigs are like, etc.

MOJO <orfsound@yahoo.com> wrote:

> OMG - Sweet is back?!!!

Seems like it.

> Cellspace is a way better space for these parties, in
> my opinion, either way I hope this is true - I am
> truely excited for little tidbit of info.

Well most likely it's true, though you shouldn't this confused
with an "announcement". Myself, I would guess Cell and Sweet
can work out a deal.

Anyway, there's been some turnover in management at Cellspace
recently... the former ED was more into youth programs/community
outreach/classes and so on, which is cool, of course, but events were
getting short-shrift there for awhile, which is much less cool.
There should be some more action coming up at Cellspace in the near
future (and for that matter, if you're looking for an events space,
you might want to keep Cell in mind).

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Anyone up on "Sweet"?

That last Townsend shindig was actually a "Generator" party, still Lost
Tribe, but a shoot-off from "Sweet" featuring a harder-edged sound (which is
tame nowadays), but yeah... I believe the last actual "Sweet" party was at
in January 24th, 2004 Sweet - Virtues of the Spiritual Warrior at Studio Z.
Lost Tribe's last party that I can recall was back in December of 2004,
again at Studio Z... "Bashing the Holidays".

Message-ID: <1899.71.198.250.91.1196682196.squirrel@secure.saturn5.com>
Date: Mon, 3 Dec 2007 03:43:16 -0800 (PST)
From: "Osby Oi Oi Jamz" <osby@viberation.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Reply-To: osby@viberation.com
User-Agent: SquirrelMail/1.4.10a
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] WR: My Yummy Saturday/ Sunday Adventure

ok... so like i woke up early & i was outta the house by 12PM... like the
buses that normally runs on weekdays don't run on weekends, & i called in
to see if i could get a pick up @ my house... they said w/o a 24
reservation yada yada, the wait time would take 2 hours..., i waited for 1
hour & got kinda ansty, so i just walked to the bus stop, which kinda took
a while...

anywaze... so to get to the City... well.. i left my house @ 12, walked,
bussed, BARTed, Muni-ed, walked more.. & with the slow schedule of public
transportaion added to the long walks & long waits in between pub trans
modes/ vehicle thingies, i actuallyt got to where i need to get to the
City b4 almost 6PMish..

So in the early eveing.. went to a family gathering to see my Lovlie
Yummies ( I was sooo late! ) then got dropped off on Gough & Market 'cause
my ride had a show to go there to... so i walked to Fat City from there...
OK.. when i was on 11th walkin' down, i saw this like old lady @ the bus
stop & this guy standing in front of her like hella feet in front... the
lady wouldn't stop yelling & Hello 2day.. she sounded like Satan's Child
she sounded so scary.. then every like 8 words or so, she made a weird
sound.. so i was guessin' she had terrets or something!?  I mean.. i know
it's a bad thing to have & stuff, but it was kinda fun to watch so i
walked like kinda slow just to like i dunno... watch....

So i got to the club a lil early & like the one thing i wanted to do
before all the DIRTY madness started was give Uberzone this oooold flyer
that i had from a rave a looong time ago in Oakland that i'm sure he would
appreciate... so i saw him & gave it to him & then he told me & whoever
was around that the party (Believe in 97) was 1 of the top #2 parties he
ever performed at... & he told us like this mini story about when he was
doin' his set & the vibe & how unforgetable it was.. ironically, the other
top party he performed at was also called Believe & that was in Arizona or
Oregan... so that was fun :)  LoL... both him & Davey asked me where my
Top Hat was... Hello 2day

BUt ok.. the night was fuckin' ILL!!!  Oooooooooooh Yeah!!  So Dope!!  All
the sets were So Dope!!!  I mean.. the the EB Reses like totally threw it
down like no tomorrow ofcourse!!  I mean.. even the lil tag diddy that Bam
& icon did @ the end was hella fun & yummy!! :)  BUt ok... that J
Haezenburger Dude... Fuckin' A man.. his set,.. ok.. 1st off... when i 1st
saw him in the crowd walkin' around & he bumped into me when i was
dancing, i seriously had to double take & grabbed his shoulder & pulled
back to me 'cause i seriously thought he was fuckin' Diesel Boy at 1st...
anywaze... his set was sick.. he opened up w/ this Glitchy Downtempo kinda
groove & kinda built up to yummy breaks in his set... Fuuuck Yeah!!

OK.. Uberzone & Davey Dave... WOW.. I mean... yeah.. just WOW... the live
drums & the live groovy melodies.. bad fuckin' ass... i danced even more
harder than i was  before... it was sooo fun!!!

All in all.. the music was mondo A+ all night long!!  Loved it!!!

The Vibe was really CooL!!  All the usual suspects where there & alota EB
1st timers or haven't been in a long time or even the needed something
differnt and the random SOMA clubby crowds all showed up too!! 
Seriously... b y 12:30, the house was sooo packed & it was literally
standing room only... the floor was packed & like the only place you could
stand was on the stairs or like the small edges of the dance floor (& that
wasn't like huge either)...

Oooh.. upstairs.. so like upstairs was teh Ambient Mafia Lounge & it was
Dope up there too!! They set it up up there to make it all comfy &
colorfully lit but dim & it was Nice!!  They played alota down tempo-ie
stuff, hip hop, old skool jamz.. it was fun too!!!  I was up there
occasionally, but the beats from downstairs just kpet bumpin' my name & I
need to dance dance dance!!!

After the club, i luckily was fortunate enough to crash out @ Bamdon's pad
in E-Ville!!  YAAAY!!  Then in the morning, i woke up to naked people on
the Sofa & drank coffee out of a large Martinee glass...  yeah... & i
haven't laughed that hard in a long time from wakin' up from a 2 hour nap!

Yeah.. it was a Dope adventure!!  YAAAAY!!!

It was Dope seein' y'all lastnight & there was alota y'all i missed
seein'!!! {{{HUGZ SFR}}}}
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Mon)

I don't know if you've been paying attention but I think the tide's  
starting to turn, people are standing up and refusing to support the  
New World Order agenda ... unfortunately we've still got cameras on  
every street corner.  Just remember what the Spanish tour guides say  
at Cuevas del Drach in Mallorca, Spain.  Every other stalagmite cave  
site allows you to take photographs, or makes you buy a permit, at  
this one, none are allowed, but all the Italians do it anyway, so the  
tour guides are going around saying, "la camara, por favor ... no  
fotograf ... no camara ..."

So when you see one of those cameras at a stoplight in the middle of  
nowhere and you're scratching your head wondering why, just say "no  
camara" ...

hey folks,

dunno if this is technically a BSP since it really has nothing to do with
me, but just a quick tip off...

tonight's special guest at "Lil' Brthr" @ 222 Hyde is REALLY, TRULY special!


i can't say who it is, but i can tell you...

* you won't see this guy perform around here again for a long time.
* he's never DJed in SF before
* he's not from the US
* he's performed on the BBC Essential Mix and toured around the world
* he plays a combo of minimal, tech-house and sometimes even a bit of breaks
* there's a hint on the flyer

....and the chit is FREE! (donations accepted i think)

i rarely go out on the weeknights anymore, but this is one set i just can't
let myself miss!

the special guest plays from 12-2am.


here she blows.....

http://i165.photobucket.com/albums/u48/mindwoofer/lil_brthr_flyer_december.jpg

c u out?

----->GB

------=_Part_22203_10118884.1196814951419--

No, not for that DJ Dreamteam thing.  For the SF Bay Guardian's Best 
DJ's Of The Bay poll.  All you have to do is email promos@sfbg.com and 
submit J.C. of An Epiphany Of Sound (KZSU) as the best Terrestrial Radio 
DJ. (Of course, it's also applicable to choose best Internet/Satellite 
Radio DJ, best Dance Club DJ, or best Bar/Lounge DJ if that's your 
choice.)

Deadline is Noon this Friday!

The funny thing here is seeing how completely insane things can get when 
one takes a fanatical stance on something.  Here we see the result of 
this from the "Westboro Baptist Church" (which is not much more than a 
family, in reality.)  To learn more about them, search for them in the 
news, and watch the video to decide for yourself.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Santacon 2007

Recently I got into verbal fisticuffs with an idiot on a bus because he 
was being a rude prick in publick and I let him know,
in no uncertain terms, that his behavior was incredibly socially 
inappropriate.

The bus was crowded and as I was giving him the tongue lashing of his life,
(in my defense, he was the one that started the convo, not me),
someone called out:

"Hey, Buddy! Where's the Christmas Spirit?!?"

To which I snap-answered, w/out thinking:

"I'm *not* a Christian!"

Coulda heard a pin drop after that, it got that damn quiet, all at once.

Definitely a keeper.

:-P

~nwa

know WHY these people believe God hates the world? I wouldn't be shocked if
they claimed that the evils in the world (natural disasters, 9/11, Iraq war,
etc.) are manifestations of God's wrath. Imagine the discussion, "So guys,
why do you think evil exists? CLEARLY God hates us all... Of course, of
course, there's no other possible explanation!" I'm sure they all got A+'s
on their philosophy exams.

Of course! Wars cannot possibly be the product of politics and other
factors; they must be a sign God's divine wrath descending upon the sinners.
So actually, whenever I have a stomach ache it's not because of the spicy
food I ate, but because of God's divine wrath. God is out to fuck up your
day; somewhat like the drunken-asshole that wants to pick a fight with
anyone at a party.

well, no breaks were heard. in fact, no records were heard!

contrary to what i had heard, alex smoke played LIVE, for nearly 2 hours. :)

another stellar performance, despite a couple technical hiccups near the
end.

if you made it down, you know what i mean...

if you didn't, you missed out on a fun night!  thx auralism!


but for the record, i swear alex does mix some breaks/electro/broken-ness
into his dj sets.  for proof, check out his debut essential mix from a
couple years back. the first 20mins or so are all broken-beat bizness.  good
shit too.

------>g

Funny you mention TV....we are gonna be featured on TLC next year.

And why am I not looking for a new job? Well...

1. This time of year sucks for job hunting.
2. I kind of really need ot stay here a full year or more for stability - I 
have historically contracted, and I have found over the last few years that 
employers look upon contractors (even if they have finished all of the their 
contract periods) as "unstable", as loads of contracts are less than a year.
3. I don't have to deal with corporate BS at this job, which I am NOT a fan 
of.

But by next year, after my year is up - you best believe I will be job 
shopping. Unless of course they give me some massive raise.

X-Scanned-By: MIMEDefang 2.56 on 171.66.118.90
X-Greylist: Sender DNS name whitelisted, not delayed by milter-greylist-2.0.2 (kzsu.stanford.edu [127.0.0.1]); Thu, 06 Dec 2007 00:34:29 -0800 (PST)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: c.moore on An Epiphany Of Sound this Thur.

My guest this week grew up in a jazz musician's household and has taken 
that tradition of musical knowledge and wonderfully expounded upon it. 
Originally a purist, he has since evolved to incorporate a wide range of 
these traditional styles into his music while still keeping it as 
organic sounding as possible.

For the show this week, I'm expecting that he'll be providing us with a 
bit of an education, guiding us through the african as well as jazz 
inspirations for some of his music before highlighting his own works.

I know I'm looking forward to it!  And I'm hoping you get to join in on 
the fun!  Please do!  It's really easy; just tune in to 90.1 FM in the 
SF Bay Area, or listen online at http://kzsulive.stanford.edu

Hope to share some time with you soon.

Peace.


-- 
http://www.jcthedj.com/Support.JC.php
http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~dougm/Reinvent.Your.World.php
AIM: jckzsu (or kzsudj during my show.)

If you're going to drive a Hummer and buy carbon offsets, that's like
getting drunk every night and getting into an AA meeting, throwing
money in the basket, and leaving.
-- Ed Begley Jr

"Opinions are my own only, and do not necessarily represent those of
KZSU Radio or Stanford University." (or words to that effect.)

From sfraves-return-143215-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Dec 06 12:36:02 2007
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-143215-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 36913 invoked by uid 1103); 6 Dec 2007 12:36:00 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Received: (qmail 36855 invoked from network); 6 Dec 2007 12:35:59 -0000
Message-ID: <20071206073547.gsslk1rshqo8kwog@webmail.utoronto.ca>
Date: Thu, 06 Dec 2007 07:35:47 -0500
From:	james.hurlbut@utoronto.ca
To:	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <7a86c50c0712051559y9f98806qfcaf2d2598ec1e02@mail.gmail.com>
	<bdbe1bd30712051617x63b12eedj743614982893fa54@mail.gmail.com>
In-Reply-To: <bdbe1bd30712051617x63b12eedj743614982893fa54@mail.gmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=ISO-8859-1;
	DelSp="Yes";
	format="flowed"
Content-Disposition: inline
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8BIT
User-Agent: Internet Messaging Program (IMP) H3 (4.1.4)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] josh wink 88 mix

I remember a few years ago Dan Bell claimed Josh Wink's hits are  
ripoffs of his records. This letter from Bell to his publisher is an  
interesting read:

It's a difficult thing to establish when an artist is influenced or  is
in effect copying another artist. I'm aware that in this age and  that in
my specific genre of music making that the issue of copying  another
artist's work has become an even more black and white issue  mostly due
to the frequency of digital sampling and more specifically  the clearing
of digital samples.

And while digital sampling has made the idea of copying musical ideas
less ambiguous and more easily detected than ever before, I find
myself in the situation where I feel I have become the target of good
old-fashioned copyright infringement.

I am writing this in the sincere hope that you will listen without
prejudice to the evidence I'm providing to you.

Introduction

I believe that the recording artist Josh Wink (aka Winx) has
knowingly copied arrangements, sounds and production techniques from  my
own copyright protected work and has failed to acknowledge the  source of
his success. It is my belief that Wink has developed a
pattern of loosely basing his musical structures and arrangements on  my
own original work. I also believe that his next release "Freak" is  his
most daring copy yet of one of my arrangements. [...]

2
History:

I have met Josh Wink several times. The first time was in November  1990
in Detroit where I was scheduled to perform as Cybersonik with  Richie
Hawtin at a nightclub called "1515 Broadway". The performance  was
canceled hours before it was to start and we only found out when  we
reached the venue. There was no line-up or crowd waiting to get  in, only
two people were waiting when we arrived. One of them was a  disappointed,
then unknown, Josh Wink, who I remember had traveled  from Philadelphia
to see us and was a "big fan" of our music.

I saw Josh Wink again in 1992 in either Rochester N.Y or Philadelphia  PA
while on tour again as Cybersonik. The DBX "Phreak" (the track in
question) was released weeks before on my label Accelerate. He was  sent
a copy of this record from the +8 label directly (the label
pressed and distributed my label Accelerate). He said he "loved" the
track "Phreak" and that he "just wished the track was longer" - it's
approx. 3 and half minutes long (his "Freak" approx. 5 mins).

The next time I had an encounter with Josh Wink was in 1995 just
months after I had released my "Losing Control" record. The record  was a
huge underground success most notably because it featured a  monotone
voice repeating the words "I'm Losing Control" on every bar  faded in and
out of the song. The effect was similar to a melodic  hook in popular
music. The entire song was based on the manipulation  of the vocal. At
the beginning of the arrangement the vocal is
introduced with the high frequencies muted and only the audible
frequencies are the lower frequencies. As the song progresses more of
the high and mid-frequencies are revealed until the whole phrase
of "I'm Losing Control" is audible. The vocal is then manipulated and
echoed and then disappears by subtracting the frequencies in the
reverse way they were added. To my knowledge, this way of slowly
manipulating a frequency filter over a repeated vocal phrase, over  the
course of an entire track was never done before in dance music  prior to
this record

Josh Wink called, he told me he had a similar track called "Don't  Laugh"
that had a "laugh" instead of the vocal "Losing Control" that  was
manipulated and arranged in a similar way. It was strange that  Wink had
phoned me about this because I had never received a call  from him before
or since that day. "Don't Laugh" was released in 1995  and was licensed
to several high profile record companies who were  able to promote the
single into mainstream markets that were not
familiar with "Losing Control". In contrast, Peacefrog records of the
U.K., the original label to release "Losing Control" froze sales at
10,000 copies in order to make the release rare and in-demand to
develop prestige for the label. Even though the release was the
biggest seller on the label to that point, no promotion was done. In  the
end, 500,000 copies of "Don't Laugh" were sold worldwide. Despite  the
similarities and the overwhelming feeling that he was trying to
capitalize on my ideas, I felt that that there was no recourse for me
because his track still had some differences.

3

In 1995 Josh Wink released a successful mix-c.d. on the DMC label
entitled "United DJs of America Vol. 3 " in which he licensed "Losing
Control".

In 2000 Josh Wink released "How's Your Evening So Far" a track that
featured a digital loop of Lil Louis' 1988 hit "French Kiss" . The  track
also featured a voice repeating the title - similar again
to "Losing Control" - only this time the way the vocal was
manipulated in almost the exact same way, as if 7 years later he
finally figured out the specific technical approach on how the
original was done.

Regarding the Lil' Louis aspect of the song the New Music Express
reported on July 4th 2000:

"JOSH WINK has run into a legal wrangle with PETE TONG's label ffrr  over
his version of the LIL LOUIS' acid house anthem `FRENCH KISS'.  The
record is due to be released in the US on Ovum label at the end  of July,
but a worldwide release is not likely until an agreement has  been
reached over how the Wink version will be credited".

Josh Wink reportedly resisted the Lil Louis co-writing credit that he
was eventually forced to put on his release. Many reviewers noted  that
the release sounded like a remix of "French Kiss" rather than a  new
song.

In December 2001, Josh Wink showed up at a club in Philadelphia PA  that
I was djing at and told me that "I have a track called "Freak"  that's
going to be really big" and that it was inspired by early
tracks. The track has been tentatively titled either "Freak"
or "Superfreak" (I also have a track entitled "Superphreak" a 1993
release on Peacefrog) and has been played on Pete Tong's show on
Radio 1 in London.

This track "Freak" sounds like a remix or remake of my track "Phreak"
from 1993. It features a pitched-down robotic voice saying "Freak" on
every bar. The arrangement is sparse like the original Also the main
musical repeating notes are very similar and may even be samples of  my
track cut up.

There already is a big buzz in several countries regarding this
release and I believe it is slated for release on the Ovum records in
the summer months. I feel that this is the last straw and that this
track is too close to my own. Please help to publicize this
situation. His New York lawyers claim there are no similarities. Let  the
people judge for themselves by supplying them with all the
information.

Thank-you for your understanding and attention,
Daniel Bell





Quoting Ben Haus <benhaus@gmail.com>:

Funny you posted this... I always wondered about French Kiss and how it
sounded so damn similar to Wink's release.  Either way, I like and own both
versions.

> U.K., the original label to release "Losing Control" froze sales at
> 10,000 copies in order to make the release rare and in-demand to
> develop prestige for the label. Even though the release was the
> biggest seller on the label to that point, no promotion was done. In  the
> end, 500,000 copies of "Don't Laugh" were sold worldwide. Despite  the
> similarities and the overwhelming feeling that he was trying to
> capitalize on my ideas, I felt that that there was no recourse for me
> because his track still had some differences.
>
> 3
>
> In 1995 Josh Wink released a successful mix-c.d. on the DMC label
> entitled "United DJs of America Vol. 3 " in which he licensed "Losing
> Control".
>
> In 2000 Josh Wink released "How's Your Evening So Far" a track that
> featured a digital loop of Lil Louis' 1988 hit "French Kiss" . The  track
> also featured a voice repeating the title - similar again
> to "Losing Control" - only this time the way the vocal was
> manipulated in almost the exact same way, as if 7 years later he
> finally figured out the specific technical approach on how the
> original was done.
>
> Regarding the Lil' Louis aspect of the song the New Music Express
> reported on July 4th 2000:
>
> "JOSH WINK has run into a legal wrangle with PETE TONG's label ffrr  over
> his version of the LIL LOUIS' acid house anthem `FRENCH KISS'.  The
> record is due to be released in the US on Ovum label at the end  of July,
> but a worldwide release is not likely until an agreement has  been
> reached over how the Wink version will be credited".
>
> Josh Wink reportedly resisted the Lil Louis co-writing credit that he
> was eventually forced to put on his release. Many reviewers noted  that
> the release sounded like a remix of "French Kiss" rather than a  new
> song.
>
> In December 2001, Josh Wink showed up at a club in Philadelphia PA  that
> I was djing at and told me that "I have a track called "Freak"  that's
> going to be really big" and that it was inspired by early
> tracks. The track has been tentatively titled either "Freak"
> or "Superfreak" (I also have a track entitled "Superphreak" a 1993
> release on Peacefrog) and has been played on Pete Tong's show on
> Radio 1 in London.
>
> This track "Freak" sounds like a remix or remake of my track "Phreak"
> from 1993. It features a pitched-down robotic voice saying "Freak" on
> every bar. The arrangement is sparse like the original Also the main
> musical repeating notes are very similar and may even be samples of  my
> track cut up.
>
> There already is a big buzz in several countries regarding this
> release and I believe it is slated for release on the Ovum records in
> the summer months. I feel that this is the last straw and that this
> track is too close to my own. Please help to publicize this
> situation. His New York lawyers claim there are no similarities. Let  the
> people judge for themselves by supplying them with all the
> information.
>
> Thank-you for your understanding and attention,
> Daniel Bell
>
>
>
>
>
> Quoting Ben Haus <benhaus@gmail.com>:
>
> > I'm gonna have to check this out.  Wink's label ovum continues to put
> out
> > quality stuff year after year... I'd really like to see what kinda stuff
> > he's playing now.
> >
> > On Dec 5, 2007 3:59 PM, Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> >> sometimes bayraves delivers!  check this out:
> >>
> >>

There was a time...a long time now back in 1993-1994 when he was just off t=
he chain.
he would spin downstairs at buzz when it was at the east side club. Man...h=
e would come down for 300 bucks and a couch to sleep on lol.
He would play the illiest house. At the time it was considered "progressive=
" but really it didn't sound anything like the progressive we know today. L=
abels like Fresh fruit, early pump (on a beat tip comes to mind)
http://www.discogs.com/release/474608
http://www.discogs.com/release/9246

just flat out funky as shit house.
*sigh* memories.....


but yeah, this acid house mix is fun.
I still play out 151 and where's your child funny enough

Sinestro

I like large posteriors and I cannot prevaricate.
www.rehabrecords.net

a dress code. Here's more info if you're interested:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Candy_raver

Haha, that might be taking it a little too far. I'm not a fan of the candy
style, since it's pretty much a uniform; but I have no problem with the
people. Most candy ravers that have been to more than a handful of parties
are extremely friendly and fun people. Of course you could point out all th=
e
newcomers that dress in the style, and that often have no clue what raves
are about (who tend to cause problems at parties because of this). However,
is that the fault of the candy style? No, it's the people that adopt the
style in order to try to fit in at their first party. The candy doesn't
force itself onto people.

Anyways, I think it'd be great if candy ravers made their own personal
style, instead of conforming to one. We could definitely use a little more
creativity.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Save a Polar Bear...JERK!

------=_NextPart_000_00D9_01C83802.DE250FC0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

http://www.nrdconline.org/campaign/Tell_White_House_to_Protect_Polar_Bear=
s4

You probably know this. Polar bears are in big trouble. Here's how to =
take 30 seconds to help.

 We all know that the poles, the ice caps, glaciers, sea ice, and the =
Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets are now melting, receding, =
disintegrating FAR faster than anyone had ever feared (having now =
reached previous predictions for the year 2050 just this year, 2007).=20

This, of course, all has a huge negative impact on a lot of lifeforms =
and a lot of other areas of concern for this planet. But one specific, =
keystone species has stood out as the one many people feel we really =
need to be worrying about. The polar bear, the world's largest land =
predator, is in serious trouble. Because they hunt seals as their =
primary food source, they depend on sea ice to travel and to hunt from =
and to live on much of the time. Sea ice gaps previously ten miles wide =
are now reaching two hundred miles in many places.=20

Polar bears are starving, they're drowning trying to cross these gaps, =
they're cannibalizing each other, they're abandoning their young, =
they're losing size and mass, they're dying off in huge numbers. This =
iconic northern animal is now under consideration for the endangered =
species list, and could be largely gone in a few decades, scientists are =
saying. Their protection under the Endangered Species Act would be =
crucial to giving them a fighting chance.=20

Below is the email the Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) sent out =
to its members today. If you're interested in helping out, please click =
on the link and add your name to the "holiday card" being sent to =
President Bush, asking him to place the Alaska polar bear under federal =
protection (a small step, admittedly, considering it's not going to =
bring the ice back, but an important one regardless).=20

Taking action with these guys actually makes a huge difference. There =
are millions of members, and they make it extremely easy to just add =
your email address to their petitions and amass a huge number of =
electronic "signatures" which are then sent to policy makers and the =
president and so on. The Council and its members have, in this way, in =
the time I've been a member, actually been the deciding factor in the =
creation of policies which have protected wolves, whales, and fisheries, =
stopped drilling in the arctic, and made huge differences in other =
environmental arenas. I urge you to join. It's free, easy, and they =
don't send you extraneous emails - just when they need you to help with =
something critical like this in which our voices really do make a =
difference.=20

P.S. : Keep in mind that the Bush Administration often saves its worst =
environmental decisions for the busy holiday season -- hoping the =
American people won't notice. That's why we're asking you to sign the =
Holiday SOS Card now. Help put the White House on notice that we're =
watching -- and expecting a decision in favor of polar bear protection.=20


(P.P.S. : If you want to help even more, you can donate at =
secure.worldwildlife.org or www.nrdc.org )=20




------=_NextPart_000_00D9_01C83802.DE250FC0--

21+
FREE like always


We've been doin the Bassdrop events for quite a few months now and
since we're coming up on the Holiday season, we decided that it would
be a good idea to have a residents only show. It's time for family
after all.

Carbon Community
Aaron Jae
Bam
M.O.D.
Athena


--

< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

Subject: [sfraves] regarding Sweet !


so there was a bit of a thread on here a few days ago
asking about Sweet ! -

quite sincerely I was flattered by the responses from
both people who I know - and people who I am not sure
I know . . .

anyway . . .

yes, it's true - we are having our first event in
several seasons - i will always be grateful to the folks
of sfraves who helped us launch Frequency 8 many
years ago - after I split with those partners, I decided
that the only way I was going to continue with ugs was if
I was able to find a space with a decent dancefloor -
specifically,  a wooden dance floor with some bounce to it,
and a community, of sorts, that really was - into DANCING

anyway - i really prefer to keep it to "2 degrees of separation"
so, i would never post an open invite to as public a list
as this - however, there are many people who I feel I "know"
on this list and would feel really good about inviting (yes, pinkho,
including you) - so, if you are interested, (and Osby says
it's OK) - email me privately for the 411 - I just ask that you
do not forward the 411 - actually, forget the Osby part -
that part probably wouldn't work to anyone's advantage lol - Hello2Day

I'm not sure if you were replying to me, but I don't hate candy kids at all
:P In my reply, I said that most candy kids are actually extremely friendly
and fun people. I pointed out that a possible reason why they have a bad
reputation is because a lot of newcomers to the party scene often adopt the
candy style in order to fit in, and that these newcomers often have no idea
what the party scene is about (thus the complaints about drugged up candy
kids in e-puddles). It's not that pronounced here, but if you've been to
parties in LA, then it would be blatantly obvious (it is not rare to see 13
or 14 year olds at parties down there). Of course, this is sfraves, so I
doubt that applies here.

On the point about creativity, it mostly depends on your definition of
creativity. I personally find more creativity in the style of burners,
junglists or househeads because they tend to wear the clothes that they
would typically wear. I see a lot more possibility and combinations in that
sort of approach, than compared to throwing on bracelets, phat pants, and a
brightly colored t-shirt.

However, I'd say out of all of those that the burners are the most creative=
.
I've been to techno, house, breaks, and psytrance parties (although not the
ones in the bay), but burner events (usually psytrance) tend to have a lot
more deco and people dressed in eccentric outfits. I went to the burningman
website and opened the first page of images from 2007 and I found this guy
that looks like a jedi crossed with a russian raver:
http://images.burningman.com/gallery/moontiger.31615.jpg I don't see how a
candy kid can push creatively when they're bound to phat pants, bracelets,
and bright t-shirts; but I would love to be proved otherwise.

In all realness, costumes, face paint, etc, have a long, long tradition in
just about every human culture with their rituals that involve music and
dance.  I think costumes are a great thing to have at parties, BUT, I don't
like the elitism and snobbery that occurs in some of these circles when
people do not dress to what they view as the status quo of their "scene."
This seems to be most prevalent among the burners.

Anyways, I'm serious about the fur trading business, we can go skin pelts
off the back of burners and hawk'm for some sort of profit or exchange!



On Dec 7, 2007 11:51 AM, Marco <electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:

> I don't understand why people feel the need to adopt a costume for
> everyday
> life. That's my problem with any scene "uniform". And let's face it, Cand=
y
> is a fuckin' uniform.
>
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Mark" <vileru@gmail.com>
> To: "pinkko" <ealaughlin@gmail.com>
> Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Friday, December 07, 2007 11:50 AM
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Trippendicular 4
>
>
> I'm not sure if you were replying to me, but I don't hate candy kids at
> all
> :P In my reply, I said that most candy kids are actually extremely
> friendly
> and fun people. I pointed out that a possible reason why they have a bad
> reputation is because a lot of newcomers to the party scene often adopt
> the
> candy style in order to fit in, and that these newcomers often have no
> idea
> what the party scene is about (thus the complaints about drugged up candy
> kids in e-puddles). It's not that pronounced here, but if you've been to
> parties in LA, then it would be blatantly obvious (it is not rare to see
> 13
> or 14 year olds at parties down there). Of course, this is sfraves, so I
> doubt that applies here.
>
> On the point about creativity, it mostly depends on your definition of
> creativity. I personally find more creativity in the style of burners,
> junglists or househeads because they tend to wear the clothes that they
> would typically wear. I see a lot more possibility and combinations in
> that
> sort of approach, than compared to throwing on bracelets, phat pants, and
> a
> brightly colored t-shirt.
>
> However, I'd say out of all of those that the burners are the most
> creative.
> I've been to techno, house, breaks, and psytrance parties (although not
> the
> ones in the bay), but burner events (usually psytrance) tend to have a lo=
t
> more deco and people dressed in eccentric outfits. I went to the
> burningman
> website and opened the first page of images from 2007 and I found this gu=
y
> that looks like a jedi crossed with a russian raver:
> http://images.burningman.com/gallery/moontiger.31615.jpg I don't see how =
a
> candy kid can push creatively when they're bound to phat pants, bracelets=
,
> and bright t-shirts; but I would love to be proved otherwise.

awareness, in part to reimburse costs incurred by the Kill The Spill
organizers: http://sfoilspill.blogspot.com/=20

surf spots and the marine environment http://www.savethewaves.org=20

On Dec 7, 2007 11:50 AM, Mark <vileru@gmail.com> wrote:

> I'm not sure if you were replying to me, but I don't hate candy kids at
> all :P In my reply, I said that most candy kids are actually extremely
> friendly and fun people. I pointed out that a possible reason why they ha=
ve
> a bad reputation is because a lot of newcomers to the party scene often
> adopt the candy style in order to fit in, and that these newcomers often
> have no idea what the party scene is about (thus the complaints about
> drugged up candy kids in e-puddles). It's not that pronounced here, but i=
f
> you've been to parties in LA, then it would be blatantly obvious (it is n=
ot
> rare to see 13 or 14 year olds at parties down there). Of course, this is
> sfraves, so I doubt that applies here.

> would typically wear. I see a lot more possibility and combinations in th=
at
> sort of approach, than compared to throwing on bracelets, phat pants, and=

On Dec 7, 2007 11:50 AM, Mark <vileru@gmail.com> wrote:

> I'm not sure if you were replying to me, but I don't hate candy kids at
> all :P In my reply, I said that most candy kids are actually extremely
> friendly and fun people. I pointed out that a possible reason why they 
> have
> a bad reputation is because a lot of newcomers to the party scene often
> adopt the candy style in order to fit in, and that these newcomers often
> have no idea what the party scene is about (thus the complaints about
> drugged up candy kids in e-puddles). It's not that pronounced here, but if
> you've been to parties in LA, then it would be blatantly obvious (it is 
> not
> rare to see 13 or 14 year olds at parties down there). Of course, this is
> sfraves, so I doubt that applies here.
>

> creativity. I personally find more creativity in the style of burners,
> junglists or househeads because they tend to wear the clothes that they
> would typically wear. I see a lot more possibility and combinations in 
> that
> sort of approach, than compared to throwing on bracelets, phat pants, and 
> a
> brightly colored t-shirt.
>

> creative. I've been to techno, house, breaks, and psytrance parties
> (although not the ones in the bay), but burner events (usually psytrance)
> tend to have a lot more deco and people dressed in eccentric outfits. I 
> went

> On Dec 7, 2007 11:50 AM, Mark <vileru@gmail.com> wrote:

> > I'm not sure if you were replying to me, but I don't hate candy kids at
> > all :P In my reply, I said that most candy kids are actually extremely
> > friendly and fun people. I pointed out that a possible reason why they
> have
> > a bad reputation is because a lot of newcomers to the party scene often
> > adopt the candy style in order to fit in, and that these newcomers ofte=
n
> > have no idea what the party scene is about (thus the complaints about
> > drugged up candy kids in e-puddles). It's not that pronounced here, but
> if

> not
> > rare to see 13 or 14 year olds at parties down there). Of course, this
> is
> > sfraves, so I doubt that applies here.

> that
> > sort of approach, than compared to throwing on bracelets, phat pants,

> On Dec 7, 2007 11:50 AM, Mark <vileru@gmail.com> wrote:

> > I'm not sure if you were replying to me, but I don't hate candy kids at
> > all :P In my reply, I said that most candy kids are actually extremely
> > friendly and fun people. I pointed out that a possible reason why they
> have
> > a bad reputation is because a lot of newcomers to the party scene often
> > adopt the candy style in order to fit in, and that these newcomers often
> > have no idea what the party scene is about (thus the complaints about
> > drugged up candy kids in e-puddles). It's not that pronounced here, but
> if
> > you've been to parties in LA, then it would be blatantly obvious (it is
> not
> > rare to see 13 or 14 year olds at parties down there). Of course, this
> is
> > sfraves, so I doubt that applies here.

> that
> > sort of approach, than compared to throwing on bracelets, phat pants,
> and a
> > brightly colored t-shirt.

> > tend to have a lot more deco and people dressed in eccentric outfits. I

> On Dec 7, 2007 11:50 AM, Mark <vileru@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> > I'm not sure if you were replying to me, but I don't hate candy kids at
> > all :P In my reply, I said that most candy kids are actually extremely
> > friendly and fun people. I pointed out that a possible reason why they
> > have
> > a bad reputation is because a lot of newcomers to the party scene often
> > adopt the candy style in order to fit in, and that these newcomers often
> > have no idea what the party scene is about (thus the complaints about
> > drugged up candy kids in e-puddles). It's not that pronounced here, but 
> > if
> > you've been to parties in LA, then it would be blatantly obvious (it is
> > not
> > rare to see 13 or 14 year olds at parties down there). Of course, this 
> > is
> > sfraves, so I doubt that applies here.
> >
> > On the point about creativity, it mostly depends on your definition of
> > creativity. I personally find more creativity in the style of burners,
> > junglists or househeads because they tend to wear the clothes that they
> > would typically wear. I see a lot more possibility and combinations in
> > that
> > sort of approach, than compared to throwing on bracelets, phat pants, 
> > and
> > a
> > brightly colored t-shirt.
> >
> > However, I'd say out of all of those that the burners are the most
> > creative. I've been to techno, house, breaks, and psytrance parties
> > (although not the ones in the bay), but burner events (usually 
> > psytrance)
> > tend to have a lot more deco and people dressed in eccentric outfits. I
> > went
> > to the burningman website and opened the first page of images from 2007
> > and
> > I found this guy that looks like a jedi crossed with a russian raver:

> > candy kid can push creatively when they're bound to phat pants,

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Trippendicular 4

------=_Part_15346_33220892.1197068509050
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

Yeah, I do not approve of elitism. Not only is it unfriendly, but it goes
against a lot of their (I'm speaking in generalities) personal ideals such
as love or equality. I think people should be able to dress however the hel=
l
they want at a party, and I'm pretty sure that's what happened when raves
first came about. It is about individual expression and freedom (pirate
utopias, temporary autonomous zones, etc.). You shouldn't feel forced to
conform to an image when you party, but inspired to create your own. And I
think we all have a responsibility to encourage behavior like this. Do you
enjoy parties where everyone hangs around in cliques and only certain style=
s
of music are accepted (elitism doesn't only apply to fashion, it applies to
music too)? If not, then I suggest taking action about it. It's easy to
maintain silence and keep this within your thoughts, but then nothing will
change. Inspire people to make things better, rather than allowing them to
revel in their flaws.

P.S. I suspect that burners wear fur a lot because of all the outdoor
parties. It makes sense to wear something warm, when you're dancing in the
cold. And I wouldn't be surprised if psychedelics had some influence on the
abundance of fur either. That shit feels great.

On Dec 7, 2007 12:06 PM, Ben Haus <benhaus@gmail.com> wrote:

> In all realness, costumes, face paint, etc, have a long, long tradition i=
n
> just about every human culture with their rituals that involve music and
> dance.  I think costumes are a great thing to have at parties, BUT, I don=
't
> like the elitism and snobbery that occurs in some of these circles when
> people do not dress to what they view as the status quo of their "scene."
> This seems to be most prevalent among the burners.
>
> Anyways, I'm serious about the fur trading business, we can go skin pelts
> off the back of burners and hawk'm for some sort of profit or exchange!

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Mark" <vileru@gmail.com>
To: "Ben Haus" <benhaus@gmail.com>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Friday, December 07, 2007 3:01 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Trippendicular 4


Yeah, I do not approve of elitism. Not only is it unfriendly, but it goes
against a lot of their (I'm speaking in generalities) personal ideals such
as love or equality. I think people should be able to dress however the hell
they want at a party, and I'm pretty sure that's what happened when raves
first came about. It is about individual expression and freedom (pirate
utopias, temporary autonomous zones, etc.). You shouldn't feel forced to
conform to an image when you party, but inspired to create your own. And I
think we all have a responsibility to encourage behavior like this. Do you
enjoy parties where everyone hangs around in cliques and only certain styles
of music are accepted (elitism doesn't only apply to fashion, it applies to
music too)? If not, then I suggest taking action about it. It's easy to
maintain silence and keep this within your thoughts, but then nothing will
change. Inspire people to make things better, rather than allowing them to
revel in their flaws.

P.S. I suspect that burners wear fur a lot because of all the outdoor
parties. It makes sense to wear something warm, when you're dancing in the
cold. And I wouldn't be surprised if psychedelics had some influence on the
abundance of fur either. That shit feels great.

On Dec 7, 2007 12:06 PM, Ben Haus <benhaus@gmail.com> wrote:

> In all realness, costumes, face paint, etc, have a long, long tradition in
> just about every human culture with their rituals that involve music and
> dance.  I think costumes are a great thing to have at parties, BUT, I 
> don't
> like the elitism and snobbery that occurs in some of these circles when
> people do not dress to what they view as the status quo of their "scene."
> This seems to be most prevalent among the burners.
>
> Anyways, I'm serious about the fur trading business, we can go skin pelts
> off the back of burners and hawk'm for some sort of profit or exchange!
>
>
>
>

> > reputation is because a lot of newcomers to the party scene often adopt
> > the
> > candy style in order to fit in, and that these newcomers often have no
> > idea
> > what the party scene is about (thus the complaints about drugged up
> > candy
> > kids in e-puddles). It's not that pronounced here, but if you've been to
> > parties in LA, then it would be blatantly obvious (it is not rare to see
> > 13
> > or 14 year olds at parties down there). Of course, this is sfraves, so I
> > doubt that applies here.

> > junglists or househeads because they tend to wear the clothes that they
> > would typically wear. I see a lot more possibility and combinations in
> > that
> > sort of approach, than compared to throwing on bracelets, phat pants,
> > and a
> > brightly colored t-shirt.

> > Yeah, I do not approve of elitism. Not only is it unfriendly, but it
> goes
> > against a lot of their (I'm speaking in generalities) personal ideals
> such
> > as love or equality. I think people should be able to dress however the
> > hell
> > they want at a party, and I'm pretty sure that's what happened when
> raves
> > first came about. It is about individual expression and freedom (pirate
> > utopias, temporary autonomous zones, etc.). You shouldn't feel forced t=
o
> > conform to an image when you party, but inspired to create your own. An=
d
> I
> > think we all have a responsibility to encourage behavior like this. Do
> you
> > enjoy parties where everyone hangs around in cliques and only certain
> > styles
> > of music are accepted (elitism doesn't only apply to fashion, it applie=
s
> > to
> > music too)? If not, then I suggest taking action about it. It's easy to
> > maintain silence and keep this within your thoughts, but then nothing
> will
> > change. Inspire people to make things better, rather than allowing them
> to
> > revel in their flaws.
> >
> > P.S. I suspect that burners wear fur a lot because of all the outdoor
> > parties. It makes sense to wear something warm, when you're dancing in
> the
> > cold. And I wouldn't be surprised if psychedelics had some influence on
> > the
> > abundance of fur either. That shit feels great.
> >
> > On Dec 7, 2007 12:06 PM, Ben Haus <benhaus@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > > In all realness, costumes, face paint, etc, have a long, long
> tradition
> > in
> > > just about every human culture with their rituals that involve music
> and
> > > dance.  I think costumes are a great thing to have at parties, BUT, I
> > > don't
> > > like the elitism and snobbery that occurs in some of these circles
> when
> > > people do not dress to what they view as the status quo of their
> > "scene."
> > > This seems to be most prevalent among the burners.
> > >
> > > Anyways, I'm serious about the fur trading business, we can go skin
> > pelts
> > > off the back of burners and hawk'm for some sort of profit or
> exchange!
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > On Dec 7, 2007 11:51 AM, Marco < electrofunk138@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > >
> > > > I don't understand why people feel the need to adopt a costume for
> > > > everyday
> > > > life. That's my problem with any scene "uniform". And let's face it=

> > > > Candy
> > > > is a fuckin' uniform.

> > > > friendly
> > > > and fun people. I pointed out that a possible reason why they have =

> > bad
> > > > reputation is because a lot of newcomers to the party scene often
> > adopt
> > > > the
> > > > candy style in order to fit in, and that these newcomers often have
> no
> > > > idea
> > > > what the party scene is about (thus the complaints about drugged up
> > > > candy
> > > > kids in e-puddles). It's not that pronounced here, but if you've
> been
> > to
> > > > parties in LA, then it would be blatantly obvious (it is not rare t=
o
> > see
> > > > 13
> > > > or 14 year olds at parties down there). Of course, this is sfraves,
> so
> > I
> > > > doubt that applies here.
> > > >
> > > > On the point about creativity, it mostly depends on your definition
> of
> > > > creativity. I personally find more creativity in the style of
> burners,
> > > > junglists or househeads because they tend to wear the clothes that
> > they
> > > > would typically wear. I see a lot more possibility and combinations
> in
> > > > that
> > > > sort of approach, than compared to throwing on bracelets, phat
> pants,
> > > > and a
> > > > brightly colored t-shirt.
> > > >
> > > > However, I'd say out of all of those that the burners are the most
> > > > creative.

> > > > lot
> > > > more deco and people dressed in eccentric outfits. I went to the

> > > > website and opened the first page of images from 2007 and I found

> > > > a

Here's my 2 cents on the whole uniform thing.  A costume when done in
complete weirdness and outside the norms of acceptability pushes a boundary
of mind and culture that helps make a rave what it is.  However! due the th=
e
phenomenon of mass kandi ravers, wearing kandi has no longer become a
costume pushing societal boundaries, but an accepted form of uniformity tha=
t
goes against almost everything that is rave.  The idea is to push peoples
boundaries that they hold of what is and ought to be.  Kandi (even if it ma=
y
have ONCE done this, and this im not even sure of) does not.  It may have
started with good intentions but it cheapifies the rave experience.  Beside=
s
the whole dress code argument, my biggest problem with kandi is that it is =
a
cheap "gift" used to try to acquire more for yourself.  In otherwords it ha=
s
moved from a gift giving process to a process of exchange.  Not to mention
the idea of continually giving beaded bracelets at EVERY party takes away
any kind of heart or creativity in the gift giving process, which ought to
be used to spread love energy

> > > conform to an image when you party, but inspired to create your own.

> > > change. Inspire people to make things better, rather than allowing

-------------------------------------------------------------------
Tiësto nominated for Grammy Award with Elements of Life
 On December 6th, Tiëstos album Elements of Life was nominated for one of the most prestigious awards in recorded music, a GRAMMY in the Best Electronic/Dance Album category. Elements of Life released by Black Hole Recordings, continues its success, having sold over 72,000 albums in the US to date and reaching golden and platinum status in numerous other countries globally. The other nominees in the category of Best Electronic/Dance Album are Justice, Shiny Toy Guns, LCD Soundsystem and The Chemical Brothers. 

To support his album Tiësto has been touring with his Elements of Life world tour, selling out venues in the US such as the LA Sports Arena with an attendance of 15,000 people and the prestigious Hammerstein Ballroom in New York two nights in a row. The tour lands in almost all continents from North-to-South America, Europe, South Africa and Asia, reaching hundreds of thousands of people with each single event on the globe being sold out in advance. 

It has always been a dream for me to be nominated for a Grammy. I have been working on this album for over a year and therefore am very happy with the nomination. says Tiësto, Its a recognition for all the hard work! 


Nominees are selected through a voting process with members and record companies submitting entries. Submissions are then screened for eligibility and category placement by 150 experts in various fields, to ensure that entered recordings meet specific qualifications. The Academy's voting members, all involved in the creative and technical processes of recording, then participate in (1) the nominating process that determines the five finalists in each category; and (2) the final voting process which determines the GRAMMY winners. 

This is the 50th Anniversary year for the Grammy organization, and the GRAMMY Award show will take place on February 10, 2008 in Los Angeles, CA. USA.

For more information on the GRAMMY organization, please visit the GRAMMY website:



» http://www.grammy.com

Chelsea Faith <chelcfaith@gmail.com> wrote: Radio Integrated is now live and online!  (8:45pm Pacific Standard Time on
Friday, December 7th)

Right now you're listening to a selection of tunes from DJ STML.  A live p.a.
set from me, Chel-C Faith, is coming up around 9:15.  At 10pm we'll host a
two hour DJ set from DJ Saya of FilterSF.   Lots of delicious techno
goodness ahead, so check it out!

Tune into Radio Integrated, broadcasting live from Bliss Factory Studios in
Alameda, California, tonight and every Friday evening from 8pm-12am PST at
http://www.zer01.net:1200/

Radio Integrated :: http://www.zer01.net:1200/ :: radiointegrated@gmail.com

I've always felt that showing up to a rave in shorts and a t-shirt is
expressing just as much individuality as wearing kandy.  Have you seen how
few people wear shorts?

On 12/7/07, Peter Farr <fender1212@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Here's my 2 cents on the whole uniform thing.  A costume when done in
> complete weirdness and outside the norms of acceptability pushes a
> boundary
> of mind and culture that helps make a rave what it is.  However! due the
> the
> phenomenon of mass kandi ravers, wearing kandi has no longer become a
> costume pushing societal boundaries, but an accepted form of uniformity
> that
> goes against almost everything that is rave.  The idea is to push peoples
> boundaries that they hold of what is and ought to be.  Kandi (even if it
> may
> have ONCE done this, and this im not even sure of) does not.  It may have
> started with good intentions but it cheapifies the rave
> experience.  Besides
> the whole dress code argument, my biggest problem with kandi is that it i=
s
> a
> cheap "gift" used to try to acquire more for yourself.  In otherwords it
> has
> moved from a gift giving process to a process of exchange.  Not to mentio=
n
> the idea of continually giving beaded bracelets at EVERY party takes away
> any kind of heart or creativity in the gift giving process, which ought t=
o
> be used to spread love energy
>

> Here's my 2 cents on the whole uniform thing.  A costume when done in=20
> complete weirdness and outside the norms of acceptability pushes a=20
> boundary of mind and culture that helps make a rave what it is. =20
> However! due the the phenomenon of mass kandi ravers, wearing kandi=20
> has no longer become a costume pushing societal boundaries, but an=20
> accepted form of uniformity that goes against almost everything that=20
> is rave.  The idea is to push peoples boundaries that they hold of=20
> what is and ought to be.  Kandi (even if it may have ONCE done this,=20
> and this im not even sure of) does not.  It may have started with good =

> intentions but it cheapifies the rave experience.  Besides the whole=20
> dress code argument, my biggest problem with kandi is that it is a=20
> cheap "gift" used to try to acquire more for yourself.  In otherwords=20
> it has moved from a gift giving process to a process of exchange.  Not =

> to mention the idea of continually giving beaded bracelets at EVERY=20

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Trippendicular 4

Yeah... that's the big difference.

I've never been given grief by a candy kid for not wearing candy.  It  
doesn't matter if you're at the cheesiest of the cheesy happy hardcore  
happy kids party.  Even if you don't have a single pony bead upon you,  
the candy kids won't look down upon you for not being one of them.   
Worst case scenario is that they try to give you some candy of your own.

That's a far cry from the treatment and attitude I've caught in jungle  
and house rooms of larger parties in the past when I've ventured in  
while I WAS wearing candy....  And the open mocking I was the object  
of, on the part of the burning man types, when I showed up at their  
little "decompression" block party thing a couple of years back for  
not being "proper playa attire".  (I wasn't even there to attend....  
just to give a friend a ride home.)


cya,
john


On Dec 7, 2007, at 12:06 PM, Ben Haus wrote:

> In all realness, costumes, face paint, etc, have a long, long  
> tradition in
> just about every human culture with their rituals that involve music  
> and
> dance.  I think costumes are a great thing to have at parties, BUT,  
> I don't
> like the elitism and snobbery that occurs in some of these circles  
> when
> people do not dress to what they view as the status quo of their  
> "scene."
> This seems to be most prevalent among the burners.
>
> Anyways, I'm serious about the fur trading business, we can go skin  
> pelts
> off the back of burners and hawk'm for some sort of profit or  
> exchange!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Trippendicular 4

Thing about shorts though, is that except for summer day parties, =20
they're not exactly practical.

This time of year especially, but even during the summer, it's bloody =20=

*COLD* at 4 or 6 am when I'm getting out of a party... usually moist =20
with my own sweat.  Baggy pants give room to breathe and circulate =20
some air when I'm inside the party and fairly warm; but also kelp keep =20=

me from freezing my ass off when I'm walking out of the party and it's =20=

forty degrees out.  Plus, if I do want to sit down at some point; phat =20=

pants insulate me somewhat from whatever nasty is on the ground.

It's the whole prostitot look (Even guys are doing it these days.) =20
that makes me go WTFH?!?!?!?


cya,
john

> On 12/7/07, Peter Farr <fender1212@gmail.com> wrote:
>>
>> Here's my 2 cents on the whole uniform thing.  A costume when done in
>> complete weirdness and outside the norms of acceptability pushes a
>> boundary of mind and culture that helps make a rave what it is.
>> However! due the the phenomenon of mass kandi ravers, wearing kandi
>> has no longer become a costume pushing societal boundaries, but an
>> accepted form of uniformity that goes against almost everything that
>> is rave.  The idea is to push peoples boundaries that they hold of
>> what is and ought to be.  Kandi (even if it may have ONCE done this,
>> and this im not even sure of) does not.  It may have started with =20
>> good
>> intentions but it cheapifies the rave experience.  Besides the whole
>> dress code argument, my biggest problem with kandi is that it is a
>> cheap "gift" used to try to acquire more for yourself.  In otherwords
>> it has moved from a gift giving process to a process of exchange.  =20=

>> Not
>> to mention the idea of continually giving beaded bracelets at EVERY
>> party takes away any kind of heart or creativity in the gift giving
>> process, which ought to be used to spread love energy

Yo I used to LOVE my phat pants. They're hard to be for sheer absurdity and
comfort while dancing. Plus you can hide midgets in there!

You know, I obviously can't speak for all of the candy ravers that ever
existed, but I know when I was doing the candy thing and I had little candy
making parties, it was ALL about making interesting things to give to peopl=
e
and NOT at all about what kind of candy I'd be getting back. Methinks you
shouldn't generalize so much?

Those junglists, though, they're hateful, mean, disgusting people. Every
last one of them.

On Dec 7, 2007 7:16 PM, Peter Farr <fender1212@gmail.com> wrote:

> Here's my 2 cents on the whole uniform thing.  A costume when done in
> complete weirdness and outside the norms of acceptability pushes a
> boundary
> of mind and culture that helps make a rave what it is.  However! due the
> the
> phenomenon of mass kandi ravers, wearing kandi has no longer become a
> costume pushing societal boundaries, but an accepted form of uniformity
> that
> goes against almost everything that is rave.  The idea is to push peoples
> boundaries that they hold of what is and ought to be.  Kandi (even if it
> may
> have ONCE done this, and this im not even sure of) does not.  It may have
> started with good intentions but it cheapifies the rave experience.
>  Besides
> the whole dress code argument, my biggest problem with kandi is that it i=
s
> a
> cheap "gift" used to try to acquire more for yourself.  In otherwords it
> has
> moved from a gift giving process to a process of exchange.  Not to mentio=
n
> the idea of continually giving beaded bracelets at EVERY party takes away
> any kind of heart or creativity in the gift giving process, which ought t=
o
> be used to spread love energy
>

> > > > > > candy style in order to fit in, and that these newcomers often
> > have
> > > no
> > > > > > idea
> > > > > > what the party scene is about (thus the complaints about drugge=
d
> > up
> > > > > > candy
> > > > > > kids in e-puddles). It's not that pronounced here, but if you'v=
e
> > > been
> > > > to
> > > > > > parties in LA, then it would be blatantly obvious (it is not
> rare
> > to
> > > > see
> > > > > > 13
> > > > > > or 14 year olds at parties down there). Of course, this is
> > sfraves,

> > > > I
> > > > > > doubt that applies here.
> > > > > >
> > > > > > On the point about creativity, it mostly depends on your
> > definition
> > > of

> > > burners,

> > > > they
> > > > > > would typically wear. I see a lot more possibility and

On Dec 7, 2007 8:46 PM, adriana <eesiad1@yahoo.com> wrote:

> hmmm!!
> -------------------------------------------------------------------
> Ti=EBsto nominated for Grammy Award with Elements of Life
>  On December 6th, Ti=EBsto's album 'Elements of Life' was nominated for o=
ne
> of the most prestigious awards in recorded music, a GRAMMY in the Best
> Electronic/Dance Album category. 'Elements of Life' released by Black Hol=
e
> Recordings, continues its success, having sold over 72,000 albums in the =
US
> to date and reaching golden and platinum status in numerous other countri=
es
> globally. The other nominees in the category of Best Electronic/Dance Alb=
um
> are Justice, Shiny Toy Guns, LCD Soundsystem and The Chemical Brothers.
>
> To support his album Ti=EBsto has been touring with his Elements of Life
> world tour, selling out venues in the US such as the LA Sports Arena with=
 an
> attendance of 15,000 people and the prestigious Hammerstein Ballroom in N=
ew
> York two nights in a row. The tour lands in almost all continents from
> North-to-South America, Europe, South Africa and Asia, reaching hundreds =
of
> thousands of people with each single event on the globe being sold out in
> advance.
>
> "It has always been a dream for me to be nominated for a Grammy. I have
> been working on this album for over a year and therefore am very happy wi=
th
> the nomination." says Ti=EBsto, "It's a recognition for all the hard work=
!"
>
>
> Nominees are selected through a voting process with members and record
> companies submitting entries. Submissions are then screened for eligibili=
ty
> and category placement by 150 experts in various fields, to ensure that
> entered recordings meet specific qualifications. The Academy's voting
> members, all involved in the creative and technical processes of recordin=
g,
> then participate in (1) the nominating process that determines the five
> finalists in each category; and (2) the final voting process which
> determines the GRAMMY winners.
>
> This is the 50th Anniversary year for the Grammy organization, and the
> GRAMMY Award show will take place on February 10, 2008 in Los Angeles, CA=
.
> USA.
>
> For more information on the GRAMMY organization, please visit the GRAMMY
> website:
>
>
>
> =BB http://www.grammy.com

Subject: RE: [sfraves] anyone have groove the movie???????

Heh plain old apache servers are making a comeback, 

I dl straight avi's off www.joox.net ... New movies disappear quick so check
daily.  As odd as this sounds, it seems to be some kinda legal loop hole
from stage6.divx.com.  This is an api that pulls newly uploaded movies to
that site, but there is some kind of approval process, so when new type
movies are pending, you can dl a copy.   NOT THAT I EVER DL NEW MOVIES cuz
that's bad mmkay? 

They dl as .divx, rename as .avi and all good. 

And uhm...

Torrents are still the way to go. 

h4x the planet!
-r4ph

Subject: [sfraves] Mel Cheren passed away yesterday.


Mel Cheren passed away yesterday.

This wonderful man was a seminal part of the dance music, nightclub, and
AIDS charity worlds. He was the innovator of the 12-inch DJ single, one =
of
the people most instrumental in commercially releasing a fledgling style =
of
music called "disco," and the co-founder of West End Records, which =
produced
legendary records by Karen Young ("Hot Shot") and Taana Gardner
("Heartbeat"), among others.

He was the financial backer behind The Paradise Garage. Try to find a =
copy
of his 2000 book My Life and the Paradise Garage: Keep Dancin' for a
terrific look at his life. He donated the office space for GMHC in its =
early
years, and in 1987 formed 24 Hours for Life, which served as the =
founding
fiscal sponsor for LIFEbeat, The Music Industry Fights AIDS. He was an
active board member at LIFEbeat until his death.

Mel was warm, witty, and sweet. He loved music, truly supported artists, =
and
never tired of looking for talented newcomers to promote. He =
revolutionized
dance music, opened one of the greatest nightclubs in history, and used =
his
energies and resources to help in the fight against AIDS for 25 years. =
When
you go out tonight =96 and you should =96 blow a kiss to the disco ball =
and
remember a wonderful man.



apollo@speakeasy.org
MySpace:=A0=A0http://www.myspace.com/DJApollo=A0
Tribenet:=A0=A0=A0http://people.tribe.net/djapollo2k
Moksha Tribe:=A0=A0www.mokshatribe.org=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0 =
=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0=A0
House Music =
101:=A0=A0http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is =
nothing
but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids look and =
look
and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

"Come Fairies, take me out of this dull world, for I would ride with you
upon the wind and dance upon the mountains like a flame!"=20
- W.B.YEATS=20

Heh plain old apache servers are making a comeback, 

I dl straight avi's off www.joox.net ... New movies disappear quick so check
daily.  As odd as this sounds, it seems to be some kinda legal loop hole
from stage6.divx.com.  This is an api that pulls newly uploaded movies to
that site, but there is some kind of approval process, so when new type
movies are pending, you can dl a copy.   NOT THAT I EVER DL NEW MOVIES cuz
that's bad mmkay? 

They dl as .divx, rename as .avi and all good. 

And uhm...

Torrents are still the way to go. 

h4x the planet!
-r4ph

> On 12/7/07, Peter Farr <fender1212@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> > Here's my 2 cents on the whole uniform thing. A costume when done in
> > complete weirdness and outside the norms of acceptability pushes a
> > boundary of mind and culture that helps make a rave what it is.
> > However! due the the phenomenon of mass kandi ravers, wearing kandi
> > has no longer become a costume pushing societal boundaries, but an
> > accepted form of uniformity that goes against almost everything that
> > is rave. The idea is to push peoples boundaries that they hold of
> > what is and ought to be. Kandi (even if it may have ONCE done this,
> > and this im not even sure of) does not. It may have started with good
> > intentions but it cheapifies the rave experience. Besides the whole
> > dress code argument, my biggest problem with kandi is that it is a
> > cheap "gift" used to try to acquire more for yourself. In otherwords
> > it has moved from a gift giving process to a process of exchange. Not
> > to mention the idea of continually giving beaded bracelets at EVERY
> > party takes away any kind of heart or creativity in the gift giving
> > process, which ought to be used to spread love energy
