>> On 12/7/07, Peter Farr <fender1212@gmail.com> wrote:
>>>
>>> Here's my 2 cents on the whole uniform thing. A costume when done in
>>> complete weirdness and outside the norms of acceptability pushes a
>>> boundary of mind and culture that helps make a rave what it is.
>>> However! due the the phenomenon of mass kandi ravers, wearing kandi
>>> has no longer become a costume pushing societal boundaries, but an
>>> accepted form of uniformity that goes against almost everything that
>>> is rave. The idea is to push peoples boundaries that they hold of
>>> what is and ought to be. Kandi (even if it may have ONCE done this,
>>> and this im not even sure of) does not. It may have started with good
>>> intentions but it cheapifies the rave experience. Besides the whole
>>> dress code argument, my biggest problem with kandi is that it is a
>>> cheap "gift" used to try to acquire more for yourself. In otherwords
>>> it has moved from a gift giving process to a process of exchange. Not
>>> to mention the idea of continually giving beaded bracelets at EVERY
>>> party takes away any kind of heart or creativity in the gift giving
>>> process, which ought to be used to spread love energy
>>>

> On Dec 7, 2007 7:16 PM, Peter Farr <fender1212@gmail.com> wrote:

>> Here's my 2 cents on the whole uniform thing.  A costume when done in
>> complete weirdness and outside the norms of acceptability pushes a
>> boundary
>> of mind and culture that helps make a rave what it is.  However! due the
>> the
>> phenomenon of mass kandi ravers, wearing kandi has no longer become a
>> costume pushing societal boundaries, but an accepted form of uniformity
>> that
>> goes against almost everything that is rave.  The idea is to push
>> peoples
>> boundaries that they hold of what is and ought to be.  Kandi (even if it
>> may
>> have ONCE done this, and this im not even sure of) does not.  It may
>> have
>> started with good intentions but it cheapifies the rave experience.
>>  Besides
>> the whole dress code argument, my biggest problem with kandi is that it
>> is
>> a
>> cheap "gift" used to try to acquire more for yourself.  In otherwords it
>> has
>> moved from a gift giving process to a process of exchange.  Not to
>> mention
>> the idea of continually giving beaded bracelets at EVERY party takes
>> away
>> any kind of heart or creativity in the gift giving process, which ought
>> to
>> be used to spread love energy

>> > > raves
>> > > > first came about. It is about individual expression and freedom

>> > > > utopias, temporary autonomous zones, etc.). You shouldn't feel

>> > to
>> > > > conform to an image when you party, but inspired to create your

>> > > > to

>> > to
>> > > > maintain silence and keep this within your thoughts, but then

>> > > will
>> > > > change. Inspire people to make things better, rather than allowing

>> > > to

Subject: [sfraves] MY Thursday Night adventure & The Drunk DieselBoy

ok... so the ride to the City that night was kinda interesting.. so i
hoped on BART I like sat across from this dude who was like on his cell
phone the whole time & i mean.. i tried not to keep looking... but he
would like grab his crotch & like squueze a few times,, scratch, then
smell his hand.. I mean.. it was kinda disgusting.. but fun to watch
'cause he was reeeeeeeally into it man... so i could only assume he was
having really good phone sex or talkin' on 1 of them call girl phone
services maybe to be that ummmm noticably involved!?

So i got to Temple early.. ok... fuck man... 2 Cents & Ivry... they
fuckin' opened up the night w/ alota floor bangin' choonage.. i could not
stop brockin' the fuck out on the floor & they oooh man.. Ok.. yeah... i i
think i heard some freshly made stuff they like made.. YUM!!!

Like the crowd built up during this set & oh man.. people from outta the
woodwork cme out & it felt like fuckin' Compression Old Skool Back in the
day stylee man... the vibe was sooo damn thick & the energy was way up
there man!!  LIke ummm.. yeah... lol.. Hello 2day.. it was just.. ok...
i'm getting like giggley & all tingley just thinkin' about it & it's like
hitting me again that it was that mondo YUm!!!  I mean.. there was a time
when you'd go to Compression, it'd be just like a local line up, but 90
people showed up & we all just took the dancefloor... yeah... it felt
kinda nostolgic like that!!!  Oh yeah.. & met a whole bunch of new yUmmy
Junglists too!!!  So Dope!!!

Oooh oh oh ohoh.. so on the mic... Colenel MC,Manny Vibes, & My Fuckin'
Homie fuckin' ZEZOone tore it up... Dirtyboy MC got on the mic later when
he was well.. drunk & couldn't rhyme, so he just did like ummm.. Circus
Announcement MCing stuff...

OK.. so here's story.. well... what i was told anyway... like they wren't
letting people in to SFO 'cause it was like weather hazzards & shit.... so
alota flights were delayed... when Dieselboy got in.. he went strait to
his Hotel & passed the fuck out!  So it was like 12 already & he still
wasn't @ the club... so the promoters called him & woke him up & he
managed to get a ride out & kinda started his set a lil late... well..
this is what i heard what happened... so i dunno...

But when he got on... he fuckin' brought it... but he brought it after the
1st 3 tracks he dropped 'cause he was havin' prblems w/ the sound & drunk
people in the DJ booth...  I mean... this is the 2nd time I've seen him
like spin.. & compared to the last time... he *waves head around*, I
mean... it was sooo Fuckin' Sick... he didn't do a strait trough Rock
Metal Hard Jungle set like @ 1015 ummm.. last year... I mean... I really
wasn't diggin' the Clownstep part of his set.. but OOoh Fuck man... like I
was all about the UK Upfront shit he dropped :)  I mean.. he did play some
totally classic dboy ch00nz which totally like ooh yeah... got me good
when i was dancing!!

OK.. so like dboy finished spinning & grabbed the mic from the MC.. then
like ok.. so i call this he pulled a Frankie Bones.. 'cause Frankie Bones
done this a few times when i saw him spin out here... but yeah... dboy
started talkin' & Thankin' everyone & well.. i think he did that 'cause he
was drunk... but it was cute.. lol.. then he played this last track.. this
"electro" dnb song that he just rmxed for an upcoming something or
another!

OK.. so here's where it started getting more fun... so like we were all
kickin' it in the DJ booth after 'cause the Compression guys know that i
wasn't all about goin' back to the Haight w/ them this time & i needed to
stay @ the club as long as possible so my BART wait wouldn't be that long
to wait like outside... anywaze... so all the Groovers left & it was like
just me, Icon, & dboy... & yeah... i mean.. there was just soo much
laughing 'cause dboy was kinda really drunk & managed to get more drinks
even though the bar was closed & he was kinda force feeding me & Icon his
boo's.... oooh yeah... he also kept calling me "Janet.. Ms Jackson if our
nasty" 'cause of my shirt!!!  But serioulsy.. a drunk dboy is soo cute & I
just wanted to keep that small dude in mny pocket & bring around with
me!!!  YAAAY!!

I mean... hangin out w/ him & GEtting to know him kinda better well..
kinda made me feel guilty 'cause i dunno... i've heard so much about him &
like i dunno... but he's not a diva at all & YAAAY.. I <3 my drunk dboy!

So the raver gypsy adventure after wasn't too exciting.. i walked up
Market to go to the Donut World 24/7 shop, but apparently they remodeled &
reworked the hours they stay open now 'cause they were closed :(  So i
remembered about All Star on 5th & Harrison.. but by the time i got to
5th, i remembered that 88 Flavors place & they wre open, so i went there..
YUM Crumb Donut & HazelNut coffee!!!  Oh yeah... i figured it was late/
early enough that it'b be ok if i sang out loud while like listening to my
ipod.. well... i probably gave the homeless people & crack heads a good
show.. LoL..

YAAAAY!!!  How fun!!!

this reminds me... i need to bug Minx again to see if we can have a 
Groove night at the Sanctuary.  she said she would re-create the altars 
she did for the movie, RA would do lights, and that we should try to 
get Viberation to do visuals. the idea was that we'd have a little 
party/movie viewing night, and it would be just like the movie, cuz it 
would be all the same props!

the only reason this event hasn't already happened is that the building 
(it's a church that was built in 1906) was being renovated.  i think 
the work is done now.

-philip-

Subject: [sfraves] NRR-Impending Destruction of the US Economy

--_36815b65-5005-42ea-928a-b63f145feeeb_
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable


Impending Destruction of the US EconomyBy Paul Craig Roberts[Dr. Roberts wa=
s Assistant Secretary of the US Treasury for Economic Policy in the Reagan =
administration.  He is credited with curing stagflation and eliminating =93=
Phillips curve=94 trade-offs between employment and inflation, an achieveme=
nt now on the verge of being lost by the worst economic mismanagement in US=
 history.]11/28/07 "ICH" -- --- Hubris and arrogance are too ensconced in W=
ashington for policymakers to be aware of the economic policy trap in which=
 they have placed the US economy.  If the subprime mortgage meltdown is hal=
f as bad as predicted, low US interest rates will be required in order to c=
ontain the crisis.  But if the dollar=92s plight is half as bad as predicte=
d, high US  interest rates will be required if foreigners are to continue t=
o hold dollars and to finance US budget and trade deficits.  Which will Was=
hington sacrifice, the domestic financial system and over-extended homeowne=
rs or its ability to finance deficits?  The answer seems obvious.  Everythi=
ng will be sacrificed in order to protect Washington=92s ability to borrow =
abroad.  Without the ability to borrow abroad, Washington cannot conduct it=
s wars of aggression, and Americans cannot continue to consume $800 billion=
 dollars more each year than the economy produces.A few years ago the euro =
was worth 85 cents.  Today it is worth $1.48.  This is an enormous decline =
in the exchange value of the US dollar.  Foreigners who finance the US budg=
et and trade deficits have experienced a huge drop in the value of their do=
llar holdings.  The interest rate on US Treasury bonds does not come close =
to compensating foreigners for the decline in the value of the dollar again=
st other traded currencies.  Investment returns from real estate and equiti=
es do not offset the losses from the decline in the dollar=92s value. China=
 holds over one trillion dollars, and Japan almost one trillion, in dollar-=
denominated assets.  Other countries have lesser but still substantial amou=
nts. As the US dollar is the reserve currency, the entire world=92s investm=
ent portfolio is over-weighted in dollars.No country wants to hold a deprec=
iating asset, and no country wants to acquire more depreciating assets.  In=
 order to reassure itself, Wall Street claims that foreign countries are lo=
cked into accumulating dollars in order to protect the value of their exist=
ing dollar holdings.  But this is utter nonsense.  The US dollar has lost 6=
0% of its value during the current administration.  Obviously, countries ar=
e not locked into accumulating dollars.The reason the dollar has not comple=
tely collapsed is that there is no clear alternative as reserve currency.  =
The euro is a currency without a country.  It is the monetary unit of the E=
uropean Union, but the countries of Europe have not surrendered their sover=
eignty to the EU.  Moreover, the UK, a member of the EU, retains the Britis=
h pound.  The fact that a currency as politically exposed as the euro can r=
ise in value so rapidly against the US dollar is powerful evidence of the w=
eakness of the US dollar.Japan and China have willingly accumulated dollars=
 as the counterpart of their penetration and capture of US domestic markets=
.  Japan and China have viewed the productive capacity and wealth created i=
n their domestic economies by the success of their exports as compensation =
for the decline in the value of their dollar holdings. However, both countr=
ies have seen the writing on the wall, ignored by Washington and American e=
conomists:  By offshoring production for US markets, the US has no prospect=
 of closing its trade deficit.  The offshored production of US firms counts=
 as imports when it returns to the US to be marketed. The more US productio=
n moves abroad, the less there is to export and the higher imports rise.  J=
apan and China, indeed, the entire world, realize that they cannot continue=
 forever to give Americans real goods and services in exchange for deprecia=
ting paper dollars.  China is endeavoring to turn its development inward an=
d to rely on its potentially huge domestic market.  Japan is pinning hopes =
on participating in Asia=92s economic development. The dollar=92s decline h=
as resulted from foreigners accumulating new dollars at a lower rate.  They=
 still accumulate dollars, but fewer.  As new dollars are still being produ=
ced at high rates, their value has dropped. If foreigners were to stop accu=
mulating new dollars, the dollar=92s value would plummet.  If foreigners we=
re to reduce their existing holdings of dollars, superpower America would i=
nstantly disappear. Foreigners have continued to accumulate dollars in the =
expectation that sooner or later Washington would address its trade and bud=
get deficits.  However, now these deficits seem to have passed the point of=
 no return.  The sharp decline in the dollar has not closed the trade defic=
it by increasing exports and decreasing imports.  Offshoring prevents the p=
ossibility of exports reducing the trade deficit, and Americans are now dep=
endent on imports (including offshored production) for which there are no l=
onger any domestically produced alternatives.  The US trade deficit will cl=
ose when foreigners cease to finance it.The budget deficit cannot be closed=
 by taxation without driving up unemployment and poverty.  American median =
family incomes have experienced no real increase during the 21st century.  =
Moreover, if the huge bonuses paid to CEOs for offshoring their corporation=
s=92 production and to Wall Street for marketing subprime derivatives are r=
emoved from the income figures, Americans have experienced a decline in rea=
l income.  Some studies, such as the Economic Mobility Project, find long-t=
erm declines in the real median incomes of some US population groups and a =
decline in upward mobility.The situation may be even more dire.  Recent wor=
k by Susan Houseman concludes that  US statistical data systems, which were=
 set in place prior to the development of offshoring, are counting some for=
eign production as part of US productivity and GDP growth, thus overstating=
 the actual performance of the US economy.The falling dollar has pushed oil=
 to $100 a barrel, which in turn will drive up other prices. The falling do=
llar means that the imports and offshored production on which Americans are=
 dependent will rise in price.  This is not a formula to produce a rise in =
US real incomes.In the 21st century, the US economy has been driven by cons=
umers going deeper in debt.  Consumption fueled by increases in indebtednes=
s received its greatest boost from Fed chairman Alan Greenspan=92s low inte=
rest rate policy.  Greenspan covered up the adverse effects of offshoring o=
n the US economy by engineering a housing boom.  The boom created employmen=
t in construction and financial firms and pushed up home prices, thus creat=
ing equity for consumers to spend to keep consumer demand growing. This sou=
rce of US economic growth is exhausted and imploding.  The full consequence=
s of the housing bust remain to be realized.  American consumers lack discr=
etionary income and can pay higher taxes only by reducing their consumption=
.  The service industries, which have provided the only source of new jobs =
in the 21st century, are already experiencing falling demand.  A tax increa=
se would cause widespread distress.As John Maynard Keynes and his followers=
 made clear, a tax increase on a recessionary economy is a recipe for falli=
ng tax revenues as well as economic hardship.Superpower America is a ship o=
f fools in denial of their plight.  While offshoring kills American economi=
c prospects, =93free market economists=94 sing its praises.  While war impo=
ses enormous costs on a bankrupt country, neoconservatives call for more wa=
r, and Republicans and Democrats appropriate war funds which can only be ob=
tained by borrowing abroad.  By focusing America on war in the Middle East,=
 the purpose of which is to guarantee Israel=92s territorial expansion, the=
 executive and legislative branches, along with the media, have let slip th=
e last opportunities the US had to put its financial house in order.  We ha=
ve arrived at the point where it is no longer bold to say that nothing now =
can be done.  Unless the rest of the world decides to underwrite our econom=
ic rescue, the chips will fall where they may.
_________________________________________________________________

Just saw this posting on tribe..
thought maybe someone may need info..

i would so go for it if i didnt have bad credit and i still need a fulltime job..

blah..here is the info..

                     pet-friendly live work loft - available mid-late january                           13 views since posting on           Sunday, December 9, 2007                                                                                                                                       Price:$1700/month                  Bdr/Ba:3/1      Location:          Calcot Place & Miller Avenue
             Oakland, CA             view map                Pets OK?Yes                                                                                i am looking for someone to take over my lease on a great live/work space in oakland. the space is ~1300 square feet, with three bedrooms currently set up, although you are free to construct additional rooms or take down existing rooms as you like. huge windows run along the entire outer wall, and the space gets great morning light. raw wood floors, perfect for industrial or artistic endeavors. the space is musician-friendly as well, we had a producer/guitarist here for quite a while. other amenities include: laundry on-site, gated parking, freight elevator and a great on-site building manager who takes care of maintenance requests at lightning-fast speed. the building is very pet friendly - pets of all kinds are welcome, with a deposit required for dogs/cats. easy access to i-880, as well as to alameda (3 mins), downtown
 oakland (5 mins) and berkeley (10 mins). 
 
looking for someone to move in late january or february 1. good credit required, as well as ability to sign a one-year lease. e-mail with questions or to set up a time to come by. 
                                                                                                                Posted byhttp://people.tribe.net/meredithk
http://sanfrancisco.tribe.net/listing/pet-friendly-live-work-loft-available-mid-late-january/oakland-ca/1f9c0c06-8a0c-46dd-9aef-8a4c1041bde3

Ah, Groove, where SFR got its 15 Seconds of Fame.

I can't vouch 4 this version:
http://www.mininova.org/get/881699

Zero comment, zero seeds, zero leechers, so you're own your own.

Speaking of "Groove" related items, this is the first "R" rated movie I 
ever saw.
http://www.mininova.org/get/889932

My parents actually wrote me a Permission Slip to go to it, it was on a 
Double Feature with
Monty Python & The Holy Grail, so there was no problem at the door.

This is when EDM took things out a whole new Groovy door that no one had 
heard b4:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GMhMrecqAVI
(See: "A Clockwork Orange")

Gotta go, Wavy Gravy is saying hi.

Groovy, Baybee, Groovy, nothing but teh Groooooveeeee.....

~Nyc

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR-Impending Destruction of the US Economy

Here's the retarded version.

America has lent China $1.5 Trillion Dollars.

Not counting the Wal-Mart:

"Made In China"

$$$....

That leaves the USA USA USA each and every day

The amount of Debt every working American *owes* China is $10K, per person.

$10,000.00

Oops.

How'd that happen?

Seen in reverse, it's like each & every every person in China, has 
*personally* lent the Citizens of The United States of America 
$1Thousand Dollars out of their own pocket.

Now bear in mind that most Chinese are doing well if they make $500 a year.l

Don't look now, my Libertarian Friends, but it wasn't Chinese Communism 
we needed to be scared of.

No, no, no.

but Chinese *Capitalism*

Chinese Capitalism.

Those bitches are about to eat our lunch.

Boo-fracking-hoo.

See you all after the 2008 Beijing Olympics, gonna be a Hootandannie 
Barn Burner.

:-P

Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] Filter:12.28: Fanon Flowers [live pa] :: Moving Detroit Techno Forward

------=_Part_25330_5265879.1197311144612
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

*Filter.SF at Anu presents:*

Fanon Flowers Live [Mechanical Industries, Nheoma, Dumb, Detroit/LA]

With Filter resident Djs ::
Solekandi
Saya
Kontakt

Friday, December 28, 2007
10:00 PM - 2:00 AM

 Anu
43 Sixth St
San Francisco, California 94102
$5

Flyer here: http://i5.tinypic.com/6phlopd.jpg

About Fanon Flowers:

With a history of solid techno productions dating back to 1992 and a 2000
DEMF performance to his credit, Detroit native Fanon Flowers combines the
funky, syncopated rhythms of techno with the soul of house music.

Performing a live PA during his first ever San Francisco performance at Anu,
expect a future classic sound from one of Detroit's own.

About Fanon Flowers:

Shunning overdone melodies and neo-minimalism for a more pure, mechanical
sound, Fanon Flowers' 2004 release "Slovakian nights" has entered into the
canon of techno classics - with remixes by Exium and Loktibrada on Numb.

In 1996, Fanon Flowers appeared under his Mode Selector alias on the
"Detroit: Beyond the Third Wave" Compilation. Released on Astralwerks,
Flowers appeared alongside Detroit techno stalwarts such as Claude Young,
Ectomorph, Sean Deason, and Anthony "Shake" Shakir.

That same year, Flowers started his own techno imprint, Mechanisms
Industries, to showcase his unique and funky approach to techno. In
2000-2003, a sub-label project entitled Cetron (short for Creative
Electronics) was launched as a platform for more percussion-based material.

Mechanisms Industries has developed a large following for its creative
interpretation of the techno sound. Famed techno DJs such as Jeff Mills,
Surgeon, and Adam Beyer have been spotted playing releases from both labels.



-- 

www.myspace.com/filtersf

On Dec 10, 2007, at 3:45 AM, Nyc W. Alberts wrote:

> Here's the retarded version

You said it yourself.

> America has lent China $1.5 Trillion Dollars.

I'm gonna let you in on a little secret- (shhhhh)...
By establishing our debt in worthless pieces of paper versus hard  
commodities we maintain absolute control of it and in effect never  
have to repay it.
As our money devalues our debt diminishes- the Fed Reserve (while  
admittedly corrupt, illegal, evil etc) most assuredly knows WTF it's  
doing.
>
> Not counting the Wal-Mart:
>
> "Made In China"
>
> $$$....
>
> Chinese Capitalism.
>
> Those bitches are about to eat our lunch.

Here's another secret- China is BY FAR more dependent upon us than we  
are upon them.
Imagine China was wiped off the map by a meteor impact- we've got a  
flood of Mexicans and a healthy number of domestic poor to cover the
"cheap laborer" needs.
Things might cost a little more and be in a shorter supply for a  
while- big deal.
Now imagine that WE were wiped off the map- suddenly China can make  
millions of HD televisions but has nobody to sell them to.
Factories -> instantly worthless. Millions -> jobless.
Sure, China could instafuck us by converting all that debt to Euros or  
something, but they're not going to- because if we're not buying,  
they're not selling.

>>
>> Those bitches are about to eat our lunch.
>
> Here's another secret- China is BY FAR more dependent upon us than  
> we are upon them.
> Imagine China was wiped off the map by a meteor impact- we've got a  
> flood of Mexicans and a healthy number of domestic poor to cover the
> "cheap laborer" needs.
> Things might cost a little more and be in a shorter supply for a  
> while- big deal.
> Now imagine that WE were wiped off the map- suddenly China can make  
> millions of HD televisions but has nobody to sell them to.
> Factories -> instantly worthless. Millions -> jobless.
> Sure, China could instafuck us by converting all that debt to Euros  
> or something, but they're not going to- because if we're not buying,  
> they're not selling.
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Tue)

I'm visiting some friends up in New York right now.  My friend was  
telling me how when he was a kid he decided he wanted chickens, you  
know for the eggs and stuff, raise them, and his dad was like, no  
chickens, they make a complete mess.  No way.  But he kept on him and  
finally his dad said, all right, we're going to the baseball game  
today, if you catch a fly ball, we'll get F***** chickens, all right?   
And so guess what happened, eh.

--

Why did the umpire throw the chicken out of the baseball game?
He suspected fowl play.

Support the beautiful fire pits of Ocean Beach!

Hello Friends, Family and Those who just love a good fire on a sandy
beach watching the waves caress the sand!

Join us for an evening of fun at the lovely Hunterspoint art space the
BOXSHOP located at 10 Hunterspoint blvd SF CA 94110

Saturday Dec 15th 7:00 pm - 1:00am

Sliding scale $5 - $500

100% of the proceeds will go to producing Fire pits for Ocean Beach!

Come support the artists and your community  and help make two more
fire pits come to life!

There will be unique handmade gifts for purchase, an assortment of
food and drink, and an opportunity to meet the artists that made the
Starfish and Fire Bloom fire pits.

More SeaStars! More Fire Blooms! More FIRE on the BEACH!

This event will be sponsored by:  Burners without Borders , the Surf
Riders Assoc. BRAF and others...

Music, Food, Fire and Fun

Come sit by the fire all night in front of two new fire pits one
SeaStar and one Fire Bloom that will soon be placed on Ocean Beach.

Save the Fire on California Beach's! Support this Project!

.

....or stand in the dark on a cold beach for the rest of your

website:
http://fireblooms.com/about/fundraiser

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Tips for recording vinyl to digital via computer?

so, i think i'm finally going to start the monumental process of
recording my vinyl to digital format.

my current setup is fairly simple. i'm on my old G4 iBook using a
Griffin iMic (RCA to USB) and recording using Final Vinyl, the free
software that came with the iMic.

i know, definitely not audiophile level here, but it's what i could afford.

for those of you who have done this, what setup did you use?  any
problems you encountered?  any particular process or recording
settings that made things go smoother?

-- 
--------------------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.getbammed.com
http://www.evilbreaks.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Tips for recording vinyl to digital via computer?

On Tue, Dec 11, 2007 at 03:24:15PM -0800, Bam wrote:
>so, i think i'm finally going to start the monumental process of
>recording my vinyl to digital format.

it's a pita, but hey, so much is only available on vinyl. long
live black crack.

>my current setup is fairly simple. i'm on my old G4 iBook using a
>Griffin iMic (RCA to USB) and recording using Final Vinyl, the free
>software that came with the iMic.

I have a DJPree II Phono Preamp[1] that I use for this.

They also offer a version with USB out[2].

I record using either an M-Audio FW 410 or an Echo Indigo IO.

>i know, definitely not audiophile level here, but it's what i could afford.

meh, it's for dj'ing which is not audiophile level.

>for those of you who have done this, what setup did you use?  any
>problems you encountered? 

clicks 'n pops. doh.

>any particular process or recording settings that made things go
>smoother?

On the Mac, Audio Hijack Pro and Fission work well. I like Adobe
Audition on the PC.

For click/crackle removal/reduction, you might try SoundSoap Pro, since
it supports Mac OS X.

I really wish Adobe would release Audition for Mac, since it's a great
program for working on audio when you need to clean it up or do other
granular work on audio.

You could probably run it inside Parallels after recording with Audio
Hijack Pro or the like. I just haven't tried that yet.

[1]
http://www.artproaudio.com/products.asp?type=90&cat=13&id=109

[2]
http://www.artproaudio.com/products.asp?type=90&cat=13&id=128

MIME-Version: 1.0

Message-ID: <870725.25309.qm@web32013.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Tips for recording vinyl to digital via computer?



If you're not already familar, you need to know about
the "RIAA Curve" as it's known.  There's a standard
for equalization that's applied to vinyl records to
keep consistency in playback (see
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RIAA_equalization ).  If
you plug a record player into a "line in" audio jack,
you'll notice that the sound coming through doesn't
sound right.  That's because line level inputs don't
have compensation for the RIAA curve.  You've got two
options on how to account for it:
1) use a pre-amp, such as a DJ mixer
2) use some other kind of in-line phono pre-amp

Basically, your signal chain is going to look like:
record player -> pre-amp -> iMic -> G4

Now, making your recording is all about sound quality.
 If at all possible, get yourself an elliptical stylus
for your record player.  Sphericals are better for
cutting and scratching, but ellipticals hold the
groove better and will give you better response for
tracking in music.

The other trick that I like to use is to run your
recordings wet.  I don't mean heavy on the effects - I
mean actually damp.  Get yourself some vinyl record
cleaning solution (like eBay item 310006579128 ) and
get your record's surface wet, and track in your
recording that way.  This will significantly cut down
on the hiss, pops and clicks that you get on your
master recording.

Processing your master recording with SoundSoap or
Soundtrack Pro is totally up to you -- it all depends
on how you want your masters to sound.  Some folks
like to run a set compression over all their masters,
some like to fudge with the EQ a little.  It's all up
to you.

Good luck!

Thread-Topic: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?
Thread-Index: Acg827YvA8IvfOfMSC+wM9YiGIpDEQAAYg0g
References: <20071212082254.S25010@kzsu.stanford.edu>
From: "Daniel Faustine" <DFaustine@procedesoftware.com>
To: "J.C." <dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu>,
	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?

When I graduated college, I sold my car for $300 bucks and moved 500
miles away to San Diego, only to be contacted by the CHP and Butte
County Courts 6 months later because the car died, and the dude
abandoned it on the freeway somewhere and never got it registered. Long
story short, CHP and the courts tried to get me to pay the
towing/destruction fees for the dead-ass car and I had to convince CHP
to drop the charges. (which they did, finally).

So... point is, unless you can prove you aren't liable with some
documentation, then yes they probably are within their rights to come
after you. I had to go to the DMV and have them give me a copy of the
release of liability form to prove I sold the car... but my guess is the
car technically still belongs to you so that probably doesn't help you
much.

Good luck anyway though. You might consider talking to an attorney about
this, especially if they try to get the courts involved.
=20
-Dan the Amoeba Man

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?

I guess the difference is that I did talk to the city it was towed from 
and they towed it for expired tags, not abandonment.  Does that change 
things?

On 12 December 2007, Daniel Faustine wrote:

> When I graduated college, I sold my car for $300 bucks and moved 500
> miles away to San Diego, only to be contacted by the CHP and Butte
> County Courts 6 months later because the car died, and the dude
> abandoned it on the freeway somewhere and never got it registered. Long
> story short, CHP and the courts tried to get me to pay the
> towing/destruction fees for the dead-ass car and I had to convince CHP
> to drop the charges. (which they did, finally).
>
> So... point is, unless you can prove you aren't liable with some
> documentation, then yes they probably are within their rights to come
> after you. I had to go to the DMV and have them give me a copy of the
> release of liability form to prove I sold the car... but my guess is the
> car technically still belongs to you so that probably doesn't help you
> much.
>
> Good luck anyway though. You might consider talking to an attorney about
> this, especially if they try to get the courts involved.
>
> -Dan the Amoeba Man
>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?


My '69 Beetle was towed once in LA for being parked
where it shouldn't have.  But, it was towed from
private property by a private company, not due to a
violation like the tags.  I had to pay a pretty stiff
fine to get the Bug O' Doom back (including a mileage
charge to the tow yard!) but I had it back the next
day.

My guess is that you've got no recourse but to pay,
unless you can demonstrate that you had some kind of
variance or extension on your tag registration.  :/

Towing sucks.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?


My best educated guess would be: Probably not. From my experience,
towing companies are generally heartless (to say the least), so I would
expect them to come after you one way or another.

If I were you, I would at least talk to the towing company and see what
your options are... maybe try to negotiate a deal with them or
something. Unless you expect to lose a significant amount of money over
this, then I'd definitely talk to a lawyer first.

-A.M.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?

On 12 December 2007, Daniel Faustine wrote:

>
> My best educated guess would be: Probably not. From my experience,
> towing companies are generally heartless (to say the least), so I would
> expect them to come after you one way or another.
>
> If I were you, I would at least talk to the towing company and see what
> your options are... maybe try to negotiate a deal with them or
> something. Unless you expect to lose a significant amount of money over
> this, then I'd definitely talk to a lawyer first.

Any lawyers on the list? :)

Or does anyone know how long fees will rack up?  In talking to them they 
say that they want the title PLUS the current impound fees.  (This is 
because they'll just end up selling it for scrap for $70.)  HOWEVER, I 
KNOW this is a lie, simply from this paragraph at the DMV site 
(http://www.dmv.ca.gov/vr/vr_info.htm)  (But still, the concern is the 
word "may" in the sentence "The lien may be satisfied by selling the 
vehicle through the lien sale process."):

Definition of a lien sale.

...
    If the vehicle is towed by a public agency or private towing company, 
the lien arises when the vehicle is towed or transported. The lien may 
be satisfied by selling the vehicle through the lien sale process.

    To conduct a lien sale, the person/lienholder must have possession of 
the vehicle and have lien sale authorization from DMV. Interested 
parties, including the registered and legal owners of record will be 
notified before the sale occurs.

    If the vehicle's value is $4,000 or less, the registered and legal 
owners of record will be notified by the party conducting the lien. If 
the vehicle's value is greater than $4,000, DMV notifies all interested 
parties.  You can call (916)-657-7617 between the hours of 8 a.m. and 5 
p.m. if you have questions regarding lien sales.
...


>
> -A.M.
>

In-Reply-To: <20071212092052.I25010@kzsu.stanford.edu>
Thread-Index: Acg84/2ZBsTHl0XjTIK2lsVrHLwJCwAATLkg
X-Identified-User: {996:box302.bluehost.com:djdragnf:djdragnfly.com} {sentby:smtp auth 66.166.146.126 authed with dragnfly@djdragnfly.com}
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?

Expired tags on a public roadway (and even a face front driveway) is in
itself a towable offense. Unfortunately, you'll still be responsible for the
towing fee, despite whoever it was that called in the vehicle to get towed.
On top of that, you'll be facing "storage fees" for every day it's in a
yard. If you want to abandon it, then more than likely you'll still have to
have to pay a salvage fee. This is definitely something you want to have
taken care of as more time = more expense.  
Sucky J.C.!!!

they'll just end up selling it for scrap for $70.)  HOWEVER, I KNOW this is
a lie, simply from this paragraph at the DMV site
(http://www.dmv.ca.gov/vr/vr_info.htm)  (But still, the concern is the word
"may" in the sentence "The lien may be satisfied by selling the vehicle
through the lien sale process."):

Definition of a lien sale.

...
    If the vehicle is towed by a public agency or private towing company,
the lien arises when the vehicle is towed or transported. The lien may be
satisfied by selling the vehicle through the lien sale process.

    To conduct a lien sale, the person/lienholder must have possession of
the vehicle and have lien sale authorization from DMV. Interested parties,
including the registered and legal owners of record will be notified before
the sale occurs.

    If the vehicle's value is $4,000 or less, the registered and legal
owners of record will be notified by the party conducting the lien. If the
vehicle's value is greater than $4,000, DMV notifies all interested parties.
You can call (916)-657-7617 between the hours of 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. if you
have questions regarding lien sales.
...


>
> -A.M.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?

You should try to take care of this sooner than later.  Usually there
is a tow fee, the city fees, AND the per day charge.  Some offenses
have a minimum amount of days that the car has to stay in impound.
Between 30 and 90 days usually, probably 30 in this case.

It's going to rack up quickly.  Negotiate with the tow company and see
what your options are.  Good luck.  I feel for ya.

On Dec 12, 2007 9:47 AM, Dragn'fly <dragnfly@djdragnfly.com> wrote:
> Expired tags on a public roadway (and even a face front driveway) is in
> itself a towable offense. Unfortunately, you'll still be responsible for the
> towing fee, despite whoever it was that called in the vehicle to get towed.
> On top of that, you'll be facing "storage fees" for every day it's in a
> yard. If you want to abandon it, then more than likely you'll still have to
> have to pay a salvage fee. This is definitely something you want to have
> taken care of as more time = more expense.
> Sucky J.C.!!!
>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?

After a period of probably 30 days, they will sell
your car to cover their storage fees, towing expenses,
etc... and I bet they will send you a bill for the
difference if the sale does not cover the fees.

I got my car impounded last year. After I moved, the
DMV never sent me a notice to re-register. It was 31
days past due. I got pulled over on the freeway but
the NHP, and basically told I was being left on the
side of the road and mt car impounded. Somehow, I
convinced the prick cop that leaving me on the freeway
was kinda dangerous. Although it is their POLICY to
leave you there, he graciously drove me home. Looks
good when your neighbors see you getting out of the
back of a cop car.

Being Nevada though, the storage fee was only $25 a
day, and the tow was $60. I got the care the same day,
after a trip to the DMV to renew my registration.

I know in SF that they sometimes charge like $250 a
day for storage. If you loook online, their is for
some reason ZERO regulation of the towing and storage
industry. AND I MEAN ZERO. It is the last totally
mobbed up business in the US.

E

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?

I'm not sure that this one carries any manditory impound days.  (At 
least I see that mentioned with other offences, and not with this.)  So 
I guess my thought is does going to them and handing them a signed 
title transferred over to them (with a witness, of course) INCREASE my 
liability in any way?

On 12 December 2007, Unagi wrote:

> You should try to take care of this sooner than later.  Usually there
> is a tow fee, the city fees, AND the per day charge.  Some offenses
> have a minimum amount of days that the car has to stay in impound.
> Between 30 and 90 days usually, probably 30 in this case.
>
> It's going to rack up quickly.  Negotiate with the tow company and see
> what your options are.  Good luck.  I feel for ya.
>
> On Dec 12, 2007 9:47 AM, Dragn'fly <dragnfly@djdragnfly.com> wrote:
>> Expired tags on a public roadway (and even a face front driveway) is in
>> itself a towable offense. Unfortunately, you'll still be responsible for the
>> towing fee, despite whoever it was that called in the vehicle to get towed.
>> On top of that, you'll be facing "storage fees" for every day it's in a
>> yard. If you want to abandon it, then more than likely you'll still have to
>> have to pay a salvage fee. This is definitely something you want to have
>> taken care of as more time = more expense.
>> Sucky J.C.!!!
>>
>>
>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: J.C. [mailto:dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu]
>>
>> Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2007 9:25 AM
>> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>> Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?
>>
>> On 12 December 2007, Daniel Faustine wrote:
>>
>>>
>>> My best educated guess would be: Probably not. From my experience,
>>> towing companies are generally heartless (to say the least), so I
>>> would expect them to come after you one way or another.
>>>
>>> If I were you, I would at least talk to the towing company and see
>>> what your options are... maybe try to negotiate a deal with them or
>>> something. Unless you expect to lose a significant amount of money
>>> over this, then I'd definitely talk to a lawyer first.
>>
>> Any lawyers on the list? :)
>>
>> Or does anyone know how long fees will rack up?  In talking to them they say
>> that they want the title PLUS the current impound fees.  (This is because
>> they'll just end up selling it for scrap for $70.)  HOWEVER, I KNOW this is
>> a lie, simply from this paragraph at the DMV site
>> (http://www.dmv.ca.gov/vr/vr_info.htm)  (But still, the concern is the word
>> "may" in the sentence "The lien may be satisfied by selling the vehicle
>> through the lien sale process."):
>>
>> Definition of a lien sale.
>>
>> ...
>>     If the vehicle is towed by a public agency or private towing company,
>> the lien arises when the vehicle is towed or transported. The lien may be
>> satisfied by selling the vehicle through the lien sale process.
>>
>>     To conduct a lien sale, the person/lienholder must have possession of
>> the vehicle and have lien sale authorization from DMV. Interested parties,
>> including the registered and legal owners of record will be notified before
>> the sale occurs.
>>
>>     If the vehicle's value is $4,000 or less, the registered and legal
>> owners of record will be notified by the party conducting the lien. If the
>> vehicle's value is greater than $4,000, DMV notifies all interested parties.
>> You can call (916)-657-7617 between the hours of 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. if you
>> have questions regarding lien sales.
>> ...
>>
>>
>>>
>>> -A.M.
>>>
>>> -----Original Message-----
>>> From: J.C. [mailto:dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu]
>>> Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2007 8:55 AM
>>> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>> Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?
>>>
>>> I guess the difference is that I did talk to the city it was towed
>>> from and they towed it for expired tags, not abandonment.  Does that
>>> change things?
>>>
>>> On 12 December 2007, Daniel Faustine wrote:
>>>
>>>> When I graduated college, I sold my car for $300 bucks and moved 500
>>>> miles away to San Diego, only to be contacted by the CHP and Butte
>>>> County Courts 6 months later because the car died, and the dude
>>>> abandoned it on the freeway somewhere and never got it registered.
>>> Long
>>>> story short, CHP and the courts tried to get me to pay the
>>>> towing/destruction fees for the dead-ass car and I had to convince
>>>> CHP to drop the charges. (which they did, finally).
>>>>
>>>> So... point is, unless you can prove you aren't liable with some
>>>> documentation, then yes they probably are within their rights to come
>>>> after you. I had to go to the DMV and have them give me a copy of the
>>>> release of liability form to prove I sold the car... but my guess is
>>> the
>>>> car technically still belongs to you so that probably doesn't help
>>>> you much.
>>>>
>>>> Good luck anyway though. You might consider talking to an attorney
>>> about
>>>> this, especially if they try to get the courts involved.
>>>>
>>>> -Dan the Amoeba Man
>>>>
>>>> -----Original Message-----
>>>> From: J.C. [mailto:dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu]

>>>> towed.  Basically, since I didn't legally contract with the towing
>>>> company to tow it (the tags were expired), if I just give up the car
>>> to
>>>> them can they take me to collections to try to get any additional

>>>>

how much are the fees?  If you want to just give the car to the towing
company anyway, might be able to find someone who needs a cheap car to pay
the fees for you.  Like a starving student or someone.

>>>>> would expect them to come after you one way or another.

>>>>> If I were you, I would at least talk to the towing company and see
>>>>> what your options are... maybe try to negotiate a deal with them or
>>>>> something. Unless you expect to lose a significant amount of money
>>>>> over this, then I'd definitely talk to a lawyer first.
>>>>
>>>> Any lawyers on the list? :)
>>>>
>>>> Or does anyone know how long fees will rack up?  In talking to them
>> they say
>>>> that they want the title PLUS the current impound fees.  (This is
>> because
>>>> they'll just end up selling it for scrap for $70.)  HOWEVER, I KNOW
>> this is
>>>> a lie, simply from this paragraph at the DMV site
>>>> (http://www.dmv.ca.gov/vr/vr_info.htm)  (But still, the concern is the
>> word
>>>> "may" in the sentence "The lien may be satisfied by selling the vehicle
>>>> through the lien sale process."):
>>>>
>>>> Definition of a lien sale.
>>>>
>>>> ...
>>>>     If the vehicle is towed by a public agency or private towing
>> company,
>>>> the lien arises when the vehicle is towed or transported. The lien may
>> be
>>>> satisfied by selling the vehicle through the lien sale process.
>>>>
>>>>     To conduct a lien sale, the person/lienholder must have possession
>> of
>>>> the vehicle and have lien sale authorization from DMV. Interested
>> parties,
>>>> including the registered and legal owners of record will be notified
>> before
>>>> the sale occurs.
>>>>
>>>>     If the vehicle's value is $4,000 or less, the registered and legal
>>>> owners of record will be notified by the party conducting the lien. If
>> the
>>>> vehicle's value is greater than $4,000, DMV notifies all interested
>> parties.
>>>> You can call (916)-657-7617 between the hours of 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. if
>> you
>>>> have questions regarding lien sales.
>>>> ...
>>>>
>>>>
>>>>>
>>>>> -A.M.
>>>>>
>>>>> -----Original Message-----
>>>>> From: J.C. [mailto:dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu]
>>>>> Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2007 8:55 AM
>>>>> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>>>>> Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?
>>>>>
>>>>> I guess the difference is that I did talk to the city it was towed
>>>>> from and they towed it for expired tags, not abandonment.  Does that
>>>>> change things?
>>>>>
>>>>> On 12 December 2007, Daniel Faustine wrote:
>>>>>
>>>>>> When I graduated college, I sold my car for $300 bucks and moved 500
>>>>>> miles away to San Diego, only to be contacted by the CHP and Butte
>>>>>> County Courts 6 months later because the car died, and the dude
>>>>>> abandoned it on the freeway somewhere and never got it registered.
>>>>> Long
>>>>>> story short, CHP and the courts tried to get me to pay the
>>>>>> towing/destruction fees for the dead-ass car and I had to convince
>>>>>> CHP to drop the charges. (which they did, finally).
>>>>>>
>>>>>> So... point is, unless you can prove you aren't liable with some
>>>>>> documentation, then yes they probably are within their rights to come
>>>>>> after you. I had to go to the DMV and have them give me a copy of the
>>>>>> release of liability form to prove I sold the car... but my guess is
>>>>> the
>>>>>> car technically still belongs to you so that probably doesn't help
>>>>>> you much.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> Good luck anyway though. You might consider talking to an attorney
>>>>> about
>>>>>> this, especially if they try to get the courts involved.
>>>>>>
>>>>>> -Dan the Amoeba Man

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?

What kind of car was it: year/model? 

-----Original Message-----
From: J.C. [mailto:dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu] 
Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2007 9:25 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?

On 12 December 2007, Daniel Faustine wrote:

>
> My best educated guess would be: Probably not. From my experience, 
> towing companies are generally heartless (to say the least), so I 
> would expect them to come after you one way or another.
>
> If I were you, I would at least talk to the towing company and see 
> what your options are... maybe try to negotiate a deal with them or 
> something. Unless you expect to lose a significant amount of money 
> over this, then I'd definitely talk to a lawyer first.

Any lawyers on the list? :)

Or does anyone know how long fees will rack up?  In talking to them they say
that they want the title PLUS the current impound fees.  (This is because
they'll just end up selling it for scrap for $70.)  HOWEVER, I KNOW this is
a lie, simply from this paragraph at the DMV site
(http://www.dmv.ca.gov/vr/vr_info.htm)  (But still, the concern is the word
"may" in the sentence "The lien may be satisfied by selling the vehicle
through the lien sale process."):

Definition of a lien sale.

...
    If the vehicle is towed by a public agency or private towing company,
the lien arises when the vehicle is towed or transported. The lien may be
satisfied by selling the vehicle through the lien sale process.

    To conduct a lien sale, the person/lienholder must have possession of
the vehicle and have lien sale authorization from DMV. Interested parties,
including the registered and legal owners of record will be notified before
the sale occurs.

    If the vehicle's value is $4,000 or less, the registered and legal
owners of record will be notified by the party conducting the lien. If the
vehicle's value is greater than $4,000, DMV notifies all interested parties.
You can call (916)-657-7617 between the hours of 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. if you
have questions regarding lien sales.
...


>
> -A.M.
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: J.C. [mailto:dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu]
> Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2007 8:55 AM
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?
>
> I guess the difference is that I did talk to the city it was towed 
> from and they towed it for expired tags, not abandonment.  Does that 
> change things?
>
> On 12 December 2007, Daniel Faustine wrote:
>
>> When I graduated college, I sold my car for $300 bucks and moved 500 
>> miles away to San Diego, only to be contacted by the CHP and Butte 
>> County Courts 6 months later because the car died, and the dude 
>> abandoned it on the freeway somewhere and never got it registered.
> Long
>> story short, CHP and the courts tried to get me to pay the 
>> towing/destruction fees for the dead-ass car and I had to convince 
>> CHP to drop the charges. (which they did, finally).
>>
>> So... point is, unless you can prove you aren't liable with some 
>> documentation, then yes they probably are within their rights to come 
>> after you. I had to go to the DMV and have them give me a copy of the 
>> release of liability form to prove I sold the car... but my guess is
> the
>> car technically still belongs to you so that probably doesn't help 
>> you much.
>>
>> Good luck anyway though. You might consider talking to an attorney
> about
>> this, especially if they try to get the courts involved.
>>
>> -Dan the Amoeba Man
>>
>> -----Original Message-----
>> From: J.C. [mailto:dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu]
>> Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2007 8:26 AM
>> To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>> Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?
>>
>> I've basically got a simple question if you have, since my car got 
>> towed.  Basically, since I didn't legally contract with the towing 
>> company to tow it (the tags were expired), if I just give up the car
> to
>> them can they take me to collections to try to get any additional 
>> fees from me?
>>
>> Thanks for any information.  This is really driving me crazy.
>>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?



I ended up doing this with my old gti.  short answer:  nope, the impound
fee is if you want access to your car to get crap out and stuff, but with
expired tags it also usually requires a smog cert and any back reg fees
(never mind how you're supposed to get a smog check before you can get
the car.  I think you can get a temp reg for that purpose).  Basically,
if you pay their signover fee, they're accepting liability for the car and
you're done.  The DMV doesn't care since they got a POS off the street.
$500 seems to be the standard signover fee for the non-asshole places, sort
of worth it if you've actually lost interest in the car anyway to save
any more grief.  They're happy because it takes care of their tow costs
(those trucks are actually pretty expensive to maintain) and anything they
get from selling it is theirs to keep.



On Wed, Dec 12, 2007 at 12:08:57PM -0800, J.C. wrote:
> I'm not sure that this one carries any manditory impound days.  (At 
> least I see that mentioned with other offences, and not with this.)  So 
> I guess my thought is does going to them and handing them a signed 
> title transferred over to them (with a witness, of course) INCREASE my 
> liability in any way?
> 
> On 12 December 2007, Unagi wrote:
> 
> >You should try to take care of this sooner than later.  Usually there
> >is a tow fee, the city fees, AND the per day charge.  Some offenses
> >have a minimum amount of days that the car has to stay in impound.
> >Between 30 and 90 days usually, probably 30 in this case.
> >
> >It's going to rack up quickly.  Negotiate with the tow company and see
> >what your options are.  Good luck.  I feel for ya.
> >
> >On Dec 12, 2007 9:47 AM, Dragn'fly <dragnfly@djdragnfly.com> wrote:
> >>Expired tags on a public roadway (and even a face front driveway) is in
> >>itself a towable offense. Unfortunately, you'll still be responsible for 
> >>the
> >>towing fee, despite whoever it was that called in the vehicle to get 
> >>towed.
> >>On top of that, you'll be facing "storage fees" for every day it's in a
> >>yard. If you want to abandon it, then more than likely you'll still have 
> >>to
> >>have to pay a salvage fee. This is definitely something you want to have
> >>taken care of as more time = more expense.
> >>Sucky J.C.!!!
> >>
> >>

Game over man. GAME OVER!

On Dec 13, 2007 3:06 AM, Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net> wrote:

>
>
> I ended up doing this with my old gti.  short answer:  nope, the impound
> fee is if you want access to your car to get crap out and stuff, but with
> expired tags it also usually requires a smog cert and any back reg fees
> (never mind how you're supposed to get a smog check before you can get
> the car.  I think you can get a temp reg for that purpose).  Basically,
> if you pay their signover fee, they're accepting liability for the car and
> you're done.  The DMV doesn't care since they got a POS off the street.
> $500 seems to be the standard signover fee for the non-asshole places,
> sort
> of worth it if you've actually lost interest in the car anyway to save
> any more grief.  They're happy because it takes care of their tow costs
> (those trucks are actually pretty expensive to maintain) and anything they
> get from selling it is theirs to keep.
>
>
>
> On Wed, Dec 12, 2007 at 12:08:57PM -0800, J.C. wrote:
> > I'm not sure that this one carries any manditory impound days.  (At
> > least I see that mentioned with other offences, and not with this.)  So
> > I guess my thought is does going to them and handing them a signed
> > title transferred over to them (with a witness, of course) INCREASE my
> > liability in any way?
> >
> > On 12 December 2007, Unagi wrote:
> >
> > >You should try to take care of this sooner than later.  Usually there
> > >is a tow fee, the city fees, AND the per day charge.  Some offenses
> > >have a minimum amount of days that the car has to stay in impound.
> > >Between 30 and 90 days usually, probably 30 in this case.
> > >
> > >It's going to rack up quickly.  Negotiate with the tow company and see
> > >what your options are.  Good luck.  I feel for ya.
> > >
> > >On Dec 12, 2007 9:47 AM, Dragn'fly <dragnfly@djdragnfly.com> wrote:
> > >>Expired tags on a public roadway (and even a face front driveway) is
> in
> > >>itself a towable offense. Unfortunately, you'll still be responsible
> for
> > >>the
> > >>towing fee, despite whoever it was that called in the vehicle to get
> > >>towed.
> > >>On top of that, you'll be facing "storage fees" for every day it's in
> a
> > >>yard. If you want to abandon it, then more than likely you'll still
> have
> > >>to
> > >>have to pay a salvage fee. This is definitely something you want to
> have
> > >>taken care of as more time = more expense.
> > >>Sucky J.C.!!!
> > >>
> > >>
> > >>-----Original Message-----
> > >>From: J.C. [mailto:dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu]
> > >>
> > >>Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2007 9:25 AM
> > >>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> > >>Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone ever have their car impounded?
> > >>
> > >>On 12 December 2007, Daniel Faustine wrote:
> > >>
> > >>>
> > >>>My best educated guess would be: Probably not. From my experience,
> > >>>towing companies are generally heartless (to say the least), so I
> > >>>would expect them to come after you one way or another.
> > >>>
> > >>>If I were you, I would at least talk to the towing company and see
> > >>>what your options are... maybe try to negotiate a deal with them or
> > >>>something. Unless you expect to lose a significant amount of money
> > >>>over this, then I'd definitely talk to a lawyer first.
> > >>
> > >>Any lawyers on the list? :)
> > >>
> > >>Or does anyone know how long fees will rack up?  In talking to them
> they
> > >>say
> > >>that they want the title PLUS the current impound fees.  (This is
> because
> > >>they'll just end up selling it for scrap for $70.)  HOWEVER, I KNOW
> this
> > >>is
> > >>a lie, simply from this paragraph at the DMV site
> > >>(http://www.dmv.ca.gov/vr/vr_info.htm)  (But still, the concern is the
> > >>word
> > >>"may" in the sentence "The lien may be satisfied by selling the
> vehicle
> > >>through the lien sale process."):
> > >>
> > >>Definition of a lien sale.
> > >>
> > >>...
> > >>    If the vehicle is towed by a public agency or private towing
> company,
> > >>the lien arises when the vehicle is towed or transported. The lien may
> be
> > >>satisfied by selling the vehicle through the lien sale process.
> > >>
> > >>    To conduct a lien sale, the person/lienholder must have possession
> of
> > >>the vehicle and have lien sale authorization from DMV. Interested
> parties,
> > >>including the registered and legal owners of record will be notified
> > >>before
> > >>the sale occurs.
> > >>
> > >>    If the vehicle's value is $4,000 or less, the registered and legal
> > >>owners of record will be notified by the party conducting the lien. If
> the
> > >>vehicle's value is greater than $4,000, DMV notifies all interested
> > >>parties.
> > >>You can call (916)-657-7617 between the hours of 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. if
> you
> > >>have questions regarding lien sales.
> > >>...
> > >>
> > >>
> > >>>
> > >>>-A.M.
> > >>>
> > >>>-----Original Message-----
> > >>>From: J.C. [mailto:dougm@kzsu.stanford.edu]
> > >>>Sent: Wednesday, December 12, 2007 8:55 AM

> > >>>
> > >>>I guess the difference is that I did talk to the city it was towed
> > >>>from and they towed it for expired tags, not abandonment.  Does that
> > >>>change things?
> > >>>
> > >>>On 12 December 2007, Daniel Faustine wrote:
> > >>>
> > >>>>When I graduated college, I sold my car for $300 bucks and moved 500
> > >>>>miles away to San Diego, only to be contacted by the CHP and Butte
> > >>>>County Courts 6 months later because the car died, and the dude
> > >>>>abandoned it on the freeway somewhere and never got it registered.
> > >>>Long
> > >>>>story short, CHP and the courts tried to get me to pay the
> > >>>>towing/destruction fees for the dead-ass car and I had to convince
> > >>>>CHP to drop the charges. (which they did, finally).
> > >>>>
> > >>>>So... point is, unless you can prove you aren't liable with some
> > >>>>documentation, then yes they probably are within their rights to
> come
> > >>>>after you. I had to go to the DMV and have them give me a copy of
> the
> > >>>>release of liability form to prove I sold the car... but my guess is
> > >>>the
> > >>>>car technically still belongs to you so that probably doesn't help
> > >>>>you much.
> > >>>>
> > >>>>Good luck anyway though. You might consider talking to an attorney
> > >>>about
> > >>>>this, especially if they try to get the courts involved.
> > >>>>
> > >>>>-Dan the Amoeba Man
> > >>>>

On Dec 13, 2007 3:06 AM, Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net> wrote:

>
>
> I ended up doing this with my old gti.  short answer:  nope, the 
> impound fee is if you want access to your car to get crap out and 
> stuff, but with expired tags it also usually requires a smog cert and 
> any back reg fees (never mind how you're supposed to get a smog check 
> before you can get the car.  I think you can get a temp reg for that 
> purpose).  Basically, if you pay their signover fee, they're accepting 
> liability for the car and you're done.  The DMV doesn't care since they
got a POS off the street.
> $500 seems to be the standard signover fee for the non-asshole places, 
> sort of worth it if you've actually lost interest in the car anyway to 
> save any more grief.  They're happy because it takes care of their tow 
> costs (those trucks are actually pretty expensive to maintain) and 
> anything they get from selling it is theirs to keep.
>

Subject: [sfraves] Raindance Winter Solstice 12/22

------=_Part_36778_32885869.1197567821264
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Got this invite from Little John off of tribe.  Looks like a good mix of
local talent and sounds, at a fraction of the door price of their bash a
week later at the Regency ($50 - $65)


Date & Time: 2007-12-22 9:00 PM
Location: Cell Space Raindance and Cell Space invite you

HOME - Sat DEC 22nd

A winter Solstice Celebration


Returning to the Cell Space bringing that old familiar feeling in a brand
new way

Things have been shifting at Cell and some of original care takers are back
!!! And we could not be happier to be doing this event there. Generating
funds and energy for the future of Cell.

There will be a short midnight ritual to honor the Solstice, and an alter to
place offerings

There will be two area's of music as they have created a new 2nd zone

DJs thus far

An-Ten-Nae (Get Freaky, Zero Ground )
Brother (Rain Dance, 13 Moon Tribe)
Hypnotech (Addictech.com <http://addictech.com/>, Love and Bass)
Little John (Rain Dance, Nexus,13 Moon Tribe, Zero Ground )
Mozaic (Raindance, Nexus)
EPROM (addictech.com)
Dave Jolley
Mr. Projectile (Semisexual records)
Neuronaut (Addictech.com <http://addictech.com/>)
Stridah (13 Moon Tribe)
Satsi ( general Freak)
Clay

Donations will be on a sliding scale $15 min, Please give as much as you can
afford
(all profits going to the saving the Cell Space )

9pm - 5 am 2050 Bryant St. SF (18th & Bryant in the Mission)

------=_Part_36778_32885869.1197567821264--

Gee, thanks. :)

I just learned that City Tow used to have the policy of accepting the 
towing fee and the pink slip.  That's something I can stomach right now.

On 13 December 2007, pinkko wrote:

> Game over man. GAME OVER!
>
> On Dec 13, 2007 3:06 AM, Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net> wrote:
>
>>
>>
>> I ended up doing this with my old gti.  short answer:  nope, the impound
>> fee is if you want access to your car to get crap out and stuff, but with
>> expired tags it also usually requires a smog cert and any back reg fees
>> (never mind how you're supposed to get a smog check before you can get
>> the car.  I think you can get a temp reg for that purpose).  Basically,
>> if you pay their signover fee, they're accepting liability for the car and
>> you're done.  The DMV doesn't care since they got a POS off the street.
>> $500 seems to be the standard signover fee for the non-asshole places,
>> sort
>> of worth it if you've actually lost interest in the car anyway to save
>> any more grief.  They're happy because it takes care of their tow costs
>> (those trucks are actually pretty expensive to maintain) and anything they
>> get from selling it is theirs to keep.
>>
>>
>>

from the Awakenings festival in Amsterdam this past Thanksgiving

> >>
> >>
> >> I ended up doing this with my old gti.  short answer:  nope, the
> impound
> >> fee is if you want access to your car to get crap out and stuff, but
> with
> >> expired tags it also usually requires a smog cert and any back reg fees
> >> (never mind how you're supposed to get a smog check before you can get
> >> the car.  I think you can get a temp reg for that purpose).  Basically,
> >> if you pay their signover fee, they're accepting liability for the car
> and
> >> you're done.  The DMV doesn't care since they got a POS off the street.
> >> $500 seems to be the standard signover fee for the non-asshole places,
> >> sort
> >> of worth it if you've actually lost interest in the car anyway to save
> >> any more grief.  They're happy because it takes care of their tow costs
> >> (those trucks are actually pretty expensive to maintain) and anything
> they
> >> get from selling it is theirs to keep.

> On Dec 13, 2007 3:06 AM, Ray Wong <rayw@rayw.net> wrote:
>
> >
> >
> > I ended up doing this with my old gti.  short answer:  nope, the
> > impound fee is if you want access to your car to get crap out and
> > stuff, but with expired tags it also usually requires a smog cert and
> > any back reg fees (never mind how you're supposed to get a smog check
> > before you can get the car.  I think you can get a temp reg for that
> > purpose).  Basically, if you pay their signover fee, they're accepting
> > liability for the car and you're done.  The DMV doesn't care since they
> got a POS off the street.
> > $500 seems to be the standard signover fee for the non-asshole places,
> > sort of worth it if you've actually lost interest in the car anyway to
> > save any more grief.  They're happy because it takes care of their tow
> > costs (those trucks are actually pretty expensive to maintain) and
> > anything they get from selling it is theirs to keep.
> >
> >
> >
> > On Wed, Dec 12, 2007 at 12:08:57PM -0800, J.C. wrote:
> > > I'm not sure that this one carries any manditory impound days.  (At
> > > least I see that mentioned with other offences, and not with this.)
> > > So I guess my thought is does going to them and handing them a
> > > signed title transferred over to them (with a witness, of course)
> > > INCREASE my liability in any way?
> > >
> > > On 12 December 2007, Unagi wrote:
> > >
> > > >You should try to take care of this sooner than later.  Usually
> > > >there is a tow fee, the city fees, AND the per day charge.  Some
> > > >offenses have a minimum amount of days that the car has to stay in
> impound.
> > > >Between 30 and 90 days usually, probably 30 in this case.
> > > >
> > > >It's going to rack up quickly.  Negotiate with the tow company and
> > > >see what your options are.  Good luck.  I feel for ya.
> > > >
> > > >On Dec 12, 2007 9:47 AM, Dragn'fly <dragnfly@djdragnfly.com> wrote:

> > > >>is
> > in
> > > >>itself a towable offense. Unfortunately, you'll still be
> > > >>responsible
> > for
> > > >>the
> > > >>towing fee, despite whoever it was that called in the vehicle to
> > > >>get towed.
> > > >>On top of that, you'll be facing "storage fees" for every day it's
> > > >>in
> > a
> > > >>yard. If you want to abandon it, then more than likely you'll
> > > >>still
> > have
> > > >>to
> > > >>have to pay a salvage fee. This is definitely something you want
> > > >>to
> > have
> > > >>taken care of as more time = more expense.

> > > >>selling the
> > vehicle
> > > >>through the lien sale process."):
> > > >>
> > > >>Definition of a lien sale.
> > > >>
> > > >>...
> > > >>    If the vehicle is towed by a public agency or private towing
> > company,
> > > >>the lien arises when the vehicle is towed or transported. The lien
> > > >>may
> > be
> > > >>satisfied by selling the vehicle through the lien sale process.
> > > >>
> > > >>    To conduct a lien sale, the person/lienholder must have
> > > >> possession
> > of
> > > >>the vehicle and have lien sale authorization from DMV. Interested
> > parties,
> > > >>including the registered and legal owners of record will be
> > > >>notified before the sale occurs.
> > > >>
> > > >>    If the vehicle's value is $4,000 or less, the registered and
> > > >>legal owners of record will be notified by the party conducting
> > > >>the lien. If
> > the
> > > >>vehicle's value is greater than $4,000, DMV notifies all
> > > >>interested parties.
> > > >>You can call (916)-657-7617 between the hours of 8 a.m. and 5 p.m.
> > > >>if
> > you
> > > >>have questions regarding lien sales.
> > > >>...
> > > >>

>> impound

>> with
>>>> expired tags it also usually requires a smog cert and any back reg fees
>>>> (never mind how you're supposed to get a smog check before you can get
>>>> the car.  I think you can get a temp reg for that purpose).  Basically,
>>>> if you pay their signover fee, they're accepting liability for the car
>> and
>>>> you're done.  The DMV doesn't care since they got a POS off the street.
>>>> $500 seems to be the standard signover fee for the non-asshole places,
>>>> sort
>>>> of worth it if you've actually lost interest in the car anyway to save
>>>> any more grief.  They're happy because it takes care of their tow costs
>>>> (those trucks are actually pretty expensive to maintain) and anything
>> they
>>>> get from selling it is theirs to keep.

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Hate to be asking for your vote again, but...

It's that time of the year again!  Nitevibe's Annual DJ Dreamteam 
Poll.....

I'm on the list as well as a few other of my fellow AuraSF mates; 
Koroma, Iyad & Floorcraft.  We would ALL greatly appreciate your vote 
and support!

Who's your Favorite DJ?

What better way to kick-off the giving season then to give a big fat 
Thank You! to the local DJs that's most moved & grooved your nights 
away. Folks - It's time once again for San Francisco's 6th Annual DJ 
Dreamteam celebrating our local sonic messiahs who show us how to 
meditate, radiate and proliferate good vibes through dance music. There 
are DJs representing all genres including hip-hop, dancehall, house, 
world, brokenbeat, drum n' bass, breaks, techno and trance, to name a 
few. Ultimately it's your choice. Your voice is what this poll is all 
about, and as always, your votes directly affect the outcome. This is 
the one time where you have a say on the lineup for the annual 
DJDreamteam massive event scheduled early next year. Please remember 
that this poll is supposed to be a fun thing for the community, it's not 
about who's necessarily the best, it's about who's your favorite! So 
keep it fair, keep it fun and let the voting begin! Poll closes on Dec 
14th, results will be announced on Dec 18th.

The voting page is here:
http://www.nitevibe.com/dt07/page1.asp

Be happy.


--

Subject: [sfraves] My Evil White Xmas Breaks Yummy Weekend

So for most of last week... my relatives from the Phillipines were stayin'
here... My cousin Marley (who's my Mom's Twin Sister's Daughter), her
hubby, my newphew Diego, & my Neice Bianca.. it's CooL 'cause Diego is
this really smart 7 yr old kid who speaks really good english for his age
& Biana is 3 yrs old, barely speaks any English, & well.. i'm the scary
Uncle she runs away from... oh well...

Anywaze.. i wanted to spend as much time w/ them b4 they left for LA & I
wasn't sure when they'd leave.. so i said my Byes & my Homegirl Ali picked
me up & took me to the EB White Xmas shindig...  ok.. The Bliss Factory is
a yummy lil spot & was so Dope!!!  I mean... OK.. the decorations cute,
nice, yummy... there's a lil raver Cat that lives there & got outta her
room a few times to dance... alota people showed up & it was just ya
konw... Dope!!  I was like all in this yummy dreamy state the whole night
'cause the music was just sooo good & i found myself dancing alot.. like
OK.. MODDIE even busted out fuckin' Techno towards the end of his set & I
was alll WTF.. Hello 2day... & it just made the night more like good
things on the way forshadowing kinda dealie... & it was... so much good
energy, good vibes all around... so Dope!!!

So like there was also the White Elephant gift Exchange... I managed to
give a lil warm blanket throw thingie... yummy soft green fabric as my
gift.. & ended up getting this stuffed animal that sings the ABCs as my
gift!!  Some guy who was celebrating his Bday that night oipened his gift
& it was ummm.. this tangerine alsolute mini bottle & he gave me the 1st
swig & WOW... so yummy!!

OK.. i will admit, I loved all the sets.. esp when Bamdon opened up w/
this Ambient, downtempo-iwh stuff then like went into breaks after that...
YUM!!!  But my fave set was the ghetto tech @ 5AM.. that just made
everything so much more YAAAAY & oooh yeah... totally Groovy!!!

So i managed to get a ride home from Drue, my HOmie form Santa Cruz.. oh
yeah.. 1 year anniversaries... so last Saturday marked the 1 year
anniversaries for me meeting Matthew Phillips, Drue, & Zarah since I met
them & also the green fuzzy Jacket:)  Like Beanie told me to wear it last
Saturday & i did for Matthew & LoL.. yeah.. I Love that thing lots, but
man... after lke 1/2 an hour of wearing it when it's not that cold it
kinda WOW!!!  Burrito kinda dealie hot!!!  I mean.. it's cumfy as fuck &
yeah... in some case can be yummy to cuddle with too... but man... so
HOT.. But i Love it!!!  People told me that I need to burner out & gear up
so I have the complete look when i wear that jacket.. so we'll see ;)

But yeah.. Drue gave me a ride home despite him having to travel the
opposite direction & ooooooh.. so apprciated.. totally!!!  I mean... the
gypsy raver commute home after a rave adventures are fun & all.. but
lately they been kinda well... i dunno... but yeah... it was Dope getting
a ride home!!!

I even made it home in time to see my realtives b4 they took off for LA...
so that was Dope!!  I stayed up a lil & hung out with them before they
left.. YAAAAY!!  Yeah... & Bianca still is like hella scared of me... oh
well!

So Yeah.. Groovy way to start the Holiday Festivities!!!  YAAAAAY!!!

OK.. i hope y'all SFRers had a Groovy weekend too!!  So Dope!
-- 
Take Care <3
Peace=->Jus' Me =-> O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Tue)

I'm really excited that I recently visited Monticello, I found the  
visit much more personal and interesting in a way than going to Mt.  
Vernon, which I last visited a few years ago.  There are tons of  
artifacts that Jefferson owned himself, including much of his original  
library, the chair he sat in as President of the Senate, a job which  
he called an easy and honorable job, as compared to the Presidency,  
which he called a joyful misery, and even Jefferson's shoes!  It's a  
must see for any architecture or history buffs!

--

When the government fears the people, there is liberty.  When the  
people fear the government, there is tyranny.

- Thomas Jefferson

event.  And others possiby did, but didn't have it go as they had 
imagined.  If you're one of the above, there's actually another SAN 
FRANCISCO santarchy event happening this Sunday.  Read below for the 
details.  Ho!



Tired of Santacon being a daytime activity instead of a nighttime bar
crawl? Tired of ideas like going to Oakland and not being able to get
on the ferry? Tired of having to hike two miles in between drinks?

We are taking back the Santa this Sunday. We're going to have an
old-fashioned bar crawl in the dark with Santas ending up passed out
on the sidewalk with their pants around their ankles.

We'll meet at the Ha-Ra club at 875 Geary at 9 p.m. on Sunday night.
Santas will drink and drink and drink. Bad things will happen.

Bring rape whistles and candles and we'll march through the
Tenderloin. This is all about taking back the Santa. It's Christmas
Eve Eve! We need to get stinking drunk before having to bring toys to
ungrateful children.

Details:

Ha-Ra bar
9 p.m.
Sunday, December 23rd
Then through the Tenderloin and probably to lower Haight afterward.

Need more info? Email to Damnesp.com.

Take Back the Santa!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (nrr) QOD (Tue)

Speaking of Jefferson, there's a really good book that is simply a 
collection of quotes from the massive amount of writings he did.  It's 
called Light And Liberty; Reflections on The Pursuit Of Happiness 
(http://tinyurl.com/29w75m)

I interviewed the author a couple of years ago.  And during that 
interview he reminded us all of another really good resource into the 
thoughts of one of our founders, which is The Jefferson Bible 
(http://tinyurl.com/yuce4g)

Both are good reads and both give you a much greater understanding of 
the man.
