Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Tips for recording vinyl to digital via computer?

------=_Part_15580_5515311.1198012375832
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

That said, if you want to get the highest quality, using a good pre-amp is
critical.  I actually have a C-1 I could let you borrow Brandon.  If it were
me, I would also take the time to calibrate the deck used for playback so it
caters more towards the needs for high-quality vs vibration-resistance.
Back the tracking force down as much as you can get away with on your
cartridges.  Then adjust the anti-skating (since it will now be a factor
after removing all that "DJ-spec" weight.  Of course listening is the final
test but remember, you're listening for dynamic range now rather than
compression.  Louder overall isn't better.  You can compress the $%&# out of
it in post but you can never get that dynamic range back later.

3 minutes spent cleaning the record with a quality phono lint brush will
save you 300 minutes trying to clean up the pops and clicks in post.  If you
have some extremely poor plates that are irreplaceable and are fearful they
may be completely unplayable in a few years -hence your desire to digitize
them for all posterity- you can use various types of lubricant to try and
get one last good play from them.  Water is typically the first tried as it
does relatively little damage to the already worn out record.  The worst
case is it doesn't sound right so you let it dry, then are stuck with
perhaps a bit more dust to clean out of it.  I've also used isopropol
alcohol, silicon spray lubricant, gizz, you name it - anything in the name
of audio quality ! ! ! ;)

For a budget recording/edit app, look to Audacity.  Open-source...  sorry
but 100% off is the lowest they can offer =p

It's too bad you can't get a better A/D solution other than the iMic.  It is
truly garbage and seems a waste of your hard effort in doing this.  I have a
very decent Philips card but it samples native only at 48k/16 and 96k/24.
All other frequencies are in fact converted from one of the aforementioned
rates upon getting written to disk (like almost every card made outside of a
pro card from M-Audio or the like).  If you're looking for 44.1k/16 native
you'd have to jump to an M-Audio product at a minimum and at that point,
your back to where you are now, not fitting into the shoestring budget.

For formats, if it works out with your recording app of choice, I would go
with Apple Lossless, FLAC, or uncompressed AIFF.  Apple Lossless or FLAC
will each save you about 50% space over uncompressed AIFF. FLAC is
open-source but also a pain in the ass to work with due to compatibility
issues so the added space savings probably isn't worth it.  Any of these
choices isn't chiseled in stone since you can opt to batch-convert to any
other lossless format in the future with zero degradation.

Good luck and let me know if you want to borrow my audiophile phono preamp.
It is a gazzillion times more accurate than any dj gear.  You're welcome to
the PC with the Philips audio card as well if you decide to capture to
either 48k/16 or 96k/24... I just can't stand to see all that effort put out
for mediocre results from lackluster A/D equipment.

-=dave

On Dec 11, 2007 4:50 PM, Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com> wrote:

>
>
> If you're not already familar, you need to know about
> the "RIAA Curve" as it's known.  There's a standard
> for equalization that's applied to vinyl records to
> keep consistency in playback (see
> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RIAA_equalization ).  If
> you plug a record player into a "line in" audio jack,
> you'll notice that the sound coming through doesn't
> sound right.  That's because line level inputs don't
> have compensation for the RIAA curve.  You've got two
> options on how to account for it:
> 1) use a pre-amp, such as a DJ mixer
> 2) use some other kind of in-line phono pre-amp
>
> Basically, your signal chain is going to look like:
> record player -> pre-amp -> iMic -> G4
>
> Now, making your recording is all about sound quality.
>  If at all possible, get yourself an elliptical stylus
> for your record player.  Sphericals are better for
> cutting and scratching, but ellipticals hold the
> groove better and will give you better response for
> tracking in music.
>
> The other trick that I like to use is to run your
> recordings wet.  I don't mean heavy on the effects - I
> mean actually damp.  Get yourself some vinyl record
> cleaning solution (like eBay item 310006579128 ) and
> get your record's surface wet, and track in your
> recording that way.  This will significantly cut down
> on the hiss, pops and clicks that you get on your
> master recording.
>
> Processing your master recording with SoundSoap or
> Soundtrack Pro is totally up to you -- it all depends
> on how you want your masters to sound.  Some folks
> like to run a set compression over all their masters,
> some like to fudge with the EQ a little.  It's all up
> to you.
>
> Good luck!
>
>
> --- Bam <invibe@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> > so, i think i'm finally going to start the
> > monumental process of
> > recording my vinyl to digital format.
> >
> > my current setup is fairly simple. i'm on my old G4
> > iBook using a
> > Griffin iMic (RCA to USB) and recording using Final
> > Vinyl, the free
> > software that came with the iMic.
> >
> > i know, definitely not audiophile level here, but
> > it's what i could afford.
> >
> > for those of you who have done this, what setup did
> > you use?  any
> > problems you encountered?  any particular process or
> > recording
> > settings that made things go smoother?
> >
> > --
> > --------------------------
> > < Brandon / DJ Bam >
> >
> > DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
> > http://www.getbammed.com
> > http://www.evilbreaks.com
> >
> >

> > To unsubscribe, e-mail:
> > sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> > For additional commands, e-mail:
> > sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] SRR: Tips for recording vinyl to digital via computer?

 > It's too bad you can't get a better A/D solution other than the  
iMic.  It is
truly garbage and seems a waste of your hard effort in doing this.

Yeah- what he said in the whole post- I know shit-all about specific  
phono preamps but my experience in the ADC realm can let me put  
emphasis on that.
You've spent how much $$$ over the years on records?
If you're archiving them now, it makes sense to spend the $$$ on a  
pristine ADC.
I'm not entirely up on the current scene (still using an SBLive AKA  
Emu10k from 1997 or so) but M-Audio seems to provide the goodness  
these days for only $99 list: http://www.m-audio.com/products/en_us/Transit-main.html

Buy 3 good cables for phono->preamp->interface and call it done.

-N7

> From: Nathan Seven [mailto:n7@nathanseven.com]

> 
>  > It's too bad you can't get a better A/D solution other than the
> iMic.  It is
> truly garbage and seems a waste of your hard effort in doing this.
> 
> Yeah- what he said in the whole post- I know shit-all about specific
> phono preamps but my experience in the ADC realm can let me put
> emphasis on that.
> You've spent how much $$$ over the years on records?
> If you're archiving them now, it makes sense to spend the $$$ on a
> pristine ADC.
> I'm not entirely up on the current scene (still using an SBLive AKA
> Emu10k from 1997 or so) but M-Audio seems to provide the goodness
> these days for only $99 list:
http://www.m-audio.com/products/en_us/Transit-
> main.html
> 
> Buy 3 good cables for phono->preamp->interface and call it done.

I use M-Audio's Transit USB with my G4 and it does an excellent job.  Please
note, however, that Transit drivers do not yet support Leopard.

Subject: [sfraves] movie recommendation

here's a great movie to watch
"The Man from Earth (2007)":
http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/1809935183/info
"At his farewell bash in a cabin in the remote woods,
Professor John Oldman (David Lee Smith) makes a
shocking confession to his fellow scholars: he is
actually an immortal who has been living on earth for
the past 14,000 years. So begins this
thought-provoking sci-fi drama which follows his
colleagues as they struggle to figure out whether
Oldman is telling the truth or merely deranged. A
long-running project of STAR TREK and TWILIGHT ZONE
scribe Jerome Bixby, the film's screenplay was finally
completed on his deathbed in 1998."

You can download it from:
http://www.mininova.org/tor/1042591


It has many ideas that are very similar to mine. If
you're interested, some of the things I've been saying
are posted at:
http://www.geocities.com/truthseek3r2007/

Subject: [sfraves] Oh, 1 more thing about White Xmas last Sat

or maybe 2 or 3 things more :)

--OK.. so at some point during the night... i follwed Chel-C to the other
room, her neighbor's space, where they wre havin' their Saturday night lil
Jam thingie where they play Brazilian EDM music (some with vocals, & I
swear I heard a Brazillian Ghetto Tech song) while they jam on drums, a
bass guitar, & other percussion stuff.... well.. so Chel_c & the guy who
lives there, Travis, well, they had this collab thingie goin' on where
Chel-C played this Techno/ Electro/ Hardcore/ Almost Gabber Music & Travis
sang.... so when they were warming up, Chel-C passed the Mic to me & I
well... I was in kinda a "dunk" fuzzy state & all i could do is harmonize
like these long ass notes that like reverbed & echoed while i sang &
eventually melded into the music Chelsea was playing.. it was kinda neato
actually... i feel bad i couldn't like think of any words to sing or what
to sing other than "Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaah" in various high
octaves.. almost hitting falceto once...  but that was fun!!!

--During someone's set ummm... i think it mighta been the cowboys.. well..
it was so like trippy 'cause he busted out this track that had the "Our
Father" prayer on it which i guess was fitting since it was early Sunday
Morning,,, but man.. that totally trip me out though 'cause i was still
fluffy "drunk"

--ok... yeah.. ithought i had more.. but that's it!!! :)  OK.. the end!!

-- 
Take Care <3

Subject: RE: [sfraves] movie recommendation

Thanks for the tip, I dl'ed and watched.  Awesome movie.

On an unrelated but kinda related side note... 

I watched Groove for the first time after Trip.  I thought it would put me
to sleep as I was just going to bed after about 19 hours of partying, but it
kept me awake.  Some parts were funny, some were dead on.  Either way, I
thought it was just plain cool when I saw this e-mail alias on there.  I had
no idea, and am almost jealous I wasn't around here at that time.  My first
rave was in '00-'01 but down south.  I only went to a handful since then and
am sad I missed all those years, but I am making up for lost time in full
force.  

Have a good evening.

-r4ph

"At his farewell bash in a cabin in the remote woods, Professor John Oldman
(David Lee Smith) makes a shocking confession to his fellow scholars: he is

Subject: Re: [sfraves] movie recommendation

Good lord-

I just started this movie and have no comment beyond "The first five  
minutes of dialog are making me twitch".

It's like it was written by a 10yo for a 4yo- "Hi John, Hi Bill. Hi  
Sally. You remember Jim. Is that a painting John?  It looks like a Van  
gogh.  Yes it is.  That's beautiful John"

Good Fuck- yes I remember the guys fucking name is John- you don't  
have to remind me by saying it every 30 seconds.

We've now spent 9 minutes establishing that yes, in fact John is  
moving away under curious circumstances.

I have a feeling this trains gonna come off the rails in a hurry...

-N7

Subject: Re: [sfraves] movie recommendation

Good lord-

I just started this movie and have no comment beyond "The first five minutes
of dialog are making me twitch".

It's like it was written by a 10yo for a 4yo- "Hi John, Hi Bill. Hi Sally.
You remember Jim. Is that a painting John?  It looks like a Van gogh.  Yes
it is.  That's beautiful John"

Good Fuck- yes I remember the guys fucking name is John- you don't have to
remind me by saying it every 30 seconds.

We've now spent 9 minutes establishing that yes, in fact John is moving away
under curious circumstances.

I have a feeling this trains gonna come off the rails in a hurry...

-N7

Subject: Re: [sfraves] movie recommendation

Wow, I am in awe.

I think this is the second-worst movie I've ever seen.

Almost-unbelievably wooden "actors", cliched characters and plot  
twists, ping-pong dialog? Check.
Constant plot explanation treating you like a mentally deficient 10yo?  
Check.
Horrible "jokes" that, like that person driving backwards on the  
freeway, make me NEED TO SEE THE FACE of whoever was responsible for  
them? Check.

You know how some movies are so bad they're comically bad, or bad but  
still interesting?
This is not one of them- It's just bad.
And if I hear "Now that's going too far!" one more FUCKING time, I'm  
going to kick my dog.

So- I have to ask- and I do so because I'm somewhat notorious for  
recommending movies that many other people find utterly unwatchable-  
but I can always explain *why* I found them interesting.
Caligula is a good example- interesting to me for a number of reasons.

So- what on Earth could possibly make you and Peter think this is a  
good movie?

-N7

hiya

how's it going with you? i hope all is good in your
life and that your existence is in harmony...

we are the gathering family and it is time to gather
once again. 16 years ago a group of people came
together to give life to many powerful and life
changing experiences for so many people. i know for
one i became a different person through my experiences
and i am blessed to have been able to contribute.

the gathering will happen at the DNA lounge on
saturday december 29th 2007, from 10pm till very
late... :-)

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: breaks and dubstep blog / podcast

------=_Part_23283_5705721.1198176092605
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

I wanted to wait until I had several episodes under my belt, so I am now
proud to announce my music blog / podcast:
6th Floor Sessions
http://zombie-j.com

Every week(ish) I'll post a new mix I've done or track I've written.  I
focus primarily on dancefloor breaks and dubstep, but anything that has me
spinning around in my office chair is fair game.  It will always be new
material - you read enough blogs that post content from other blogs already.

The podcast is available via iTunes, and podcast reader that accepts XML
feeds, and of course the blog.  More tech details @
http://zombie-j.com/wordpress/?page_id=2

This week's entry (so far) is a new dubstep track hot off the ol' macbook
pro.  turn up the bass and warn the neighbors, this is serious bizness.
 many thanks to my good friend jake boswell for mastering this one.

-- 
jason
6th Floor Sessions Podcast
http://zombie-j.com
aim deceptajason

------=_Part_23283_5705721.1198176092605--

hiya

how's it going with you? i hope all is good in your
life and that your existence is in harmony...

we are the gathering family and it is time to gather
once again. 16 years ago a group of people came
together to give life to many powerful and life
changing experiences for so many people. i know for
one i became a different person through my experiences
and i am blessed to have been able to contribute.

the gathering will happen at the DNA lounge on
saturday december 29th 2007, from 10pm till very
late... :-)

thumps...
jeno
galen
garth
spun
matt

not so...
solar
darkhorse
global culture
bobert
mycilium walker

visuals...
mark johns

art...
michael k matel

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: Anyone familiar with EastBay Hills -Sibley  Volcanic Regional Preserve..

Sibley is south of Tilden near where Grizzly Peak hits Skyline.  Used to go=
 there quite a bit back in the day, but the labyrinth wasn't there at that =
time.  =0A=0APark near the visitor center and follow these directions: http=
://www.bahiker.com/eastbayhikes/sibley.html=0A=0AThere's also a second less=
 well formed labyrinth further up the trail.=0A=0A"The Labyrinth is located=
 precisely at:=0A=0ALongitude: 122 degrees west,  11 minutes, 25 seconds  (=
-122.19043)=0ALatitude:       37 degrees north, 51 minutes, 11 seconds  (  =
 37.85304)"=0A=0ASee http://maps.google.com/maps?f=3Dd&hl=3Den&geocode=3D&t=
ime=3D&date=3D&ttype=3D&saddr=3D&daddr=3D37.85468,-122.191586&mra=3Dmi&mrsp=
=3D0&sz=3D19&sll=3D37.854697,-122.191634&sspn=3D0.001216,0.002178&ie=3DUTF8=
&t=3Dh&z=3D19&om=3D1=0A=0A"From Post #4, take the short, narrow dirt road t=
hat leads south (to your right, when facing the Labyrinth from above), then=
 loops back north and down into the quarry pit, ending at the Labyrinth. Av=
oid scrambling down any trails directly to the Labyrinth as the slopes at t=
he quarry (actually a gravel quarry) are steep, unstable and quite dangerou=
s. It=E2=80=99s not uncommon for visitors to experience at least one minor =
landslide at some time during their short visit. It=E2=80=99s just a remind=
er of nature reclaiming itself, taking on a more natural, stable configurat=
ion to the landscape."=0A  =0AFrom: http://home.earthlink.net/~friendsofthe=
labyrinth/ which has a bunch of info about the labyrinth as well.=0A=0AFWIW=
 Grace Catherdral in SF also has two labyrinths including one indoors for r=
ainy days...=0A=0ABest,=0A=0APeter=0A=0A=0AAt 09:29 AM 12/20/2007, adriana =
wrote:=0A>I'm looking to find the Labyrinth, i hear it's somewhere in the =

know where exactly is the Labyrinth..Has anyone =0A>gone? i need to go..so =
if anyone can give me a clue it will help..Thanks

----- Original Message ----
From: jason hemmenway <deceptakahn@gmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Thursday, December 20, 2007 10:41:32 AM
Subject: [sfraves] BSP: breaks and dubstep blog / podcast

I wanted to wait until I had several episodes under my belt, so I am now
proud to announce my music blog / podcast:
6th Floor Sessions
http://zombie-j.com

Every week(ish) I'll post a new mix I've done or track I've written.  I
focus primarily on dancefloor breaks and dubstep, but anything that has me
spinning around in my office chair is fair game.  It will always be new
material - you read enough blogs that post content from other blogs already.

The podcast is available via iTunes, and podcast reader that accepts XML
feeds, and of course the blog.  More tech details @
http://zombie-j.com/wordpress/?page_id=2

This week's entry (so far) is a new dubstep track hot off the ol' macbook
pro.  turn up the bass and warn the neighbors, this is serious bizness.
many thanks to my good friend jake boswell for mastering this one.

-- 
jason
6th Floor Sessions Podcast
http://zombie-j.com
aim deceptajason

Content-Disposition: inline

bahiker.com  is a great site in general if you want to explore the bay
area.

On Dec 20, 2007 11:39 AM, <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:

> Sibley is south of Tilden near where Grizzly Peak hits Skyline.  Used to
> go there quite a bit back in the day, but the labyrinth wasn't there at that
> time.
>
> Park near the visitor center and follow these directions:
> http://www.bahiker.com/eastbayhikes/sibley.html
>
> There's also a second less well formed labyrinth further up the trail.
>
> "The Labyrinth is located precisely at:
>
> Longitude: 122 degrees west,  11 minutes, 25 seconds  (-122.19043)
> Latitude:       37 degrees north, 51 minutes, 11 seconds  (   37.85304)"
>
> See
> http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&hl=en&geocode=&time=&date=&ttype=&saddr=&daddr=37.85468,-122.191586&mra=mi&mrsp=0&sz=19&sll=37.854697,-122.191634&sspn=0.001216,0.002178&ie=UTF8&t=h&z=19&om=1
>
> "From Post #4, take the short, narrow dirt road that leads south (to your
> right, when facing the Labyrinth from above), then loops back north and down
> into the quarry pit, ending at the Labyrinth. Avoid scrambling down any
> trails directly to the Labyrinth as the slopes at the quarry (actually a
> gravel quarry) are steep, unstable and quite dangerous. It's not uncommon
> for visitors to experience at least one minor landslide at some time during
> their short visit. It's just a reminder of nature reclaiming itself, taking
> on a more natural, stable configuration to the landscape."
>
> From: http://home.earthlink.net/~friendsofthelabyrinth/<http://home.earthlink.net/%7Efriendsofthelabyrinth/>which has a bunch of info about the labyrinth as well.
>
> FWIW Grace Catherdral in SF also has two labyrinths including one indoors
> for rainy days...
>
> Best,
>
> Peter
>
>
> At 09:29 AM 12/20/2007, adriana wrote:
> >I'm looking to find the Labyrinth, i hear it's somewhere in the
> >Eastbay Hills - Sibley Volcanic Regional Preserve..
> >but does anyone know where exactly is the Labyrinth..Has anyone
> >gone? i need to go..so if anyone can give me a clue it will help..Thanks
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>

I took my then GF at the time to see Guccione's Caligula in the theatre 
when it first came out, this was when the uber-pretentious I, Claudius 
was all the rage on teh PBS.

Boy, did she have a melt-down afterwards, but I did manage to talk her 
down, but the sex was never the same afterwards.

Actually ran into her about a month ago after not seeing her for a very, 
very, long time, and then talked with a friend of mine who went out 
w/her afterwards and he confirmed that she really is/was the one that's 
out to lunch.

I also like Tarantino's stuff, he writes scenes of man/woman domestic 
bliss better than anybody else in the business.

The wedding scene in NBK on the bridge between Mickey & Mallory is the 
only representation I've seen on film on how people used to get married, 
*for centuries* before the Catholic Church stuck its slimy paws into it 
and ruined marriage for everybody.

.....

> > Speaking of labyrinths, any of you been to the rock labyrinth near
> Land's
> > End in SF?  Cool spot.
> >
> > On Dec 20, 2007 1:36 PM, Ben Haus <benhaus@gmail.com> wrote:
> >
> >> bahiker.com  is a great site in general if you want to explore the bay
> >> area.
> >>
> >>
> >> On Dec 20, 2007 11:39 AM, <dangrsmind@yahoo.com > wrote:
> >>
> >> > Sibley is south of Tilden near where Grizzly Peak hits Skyline.  Used
> >> > to
> >> > go there quite a bit back in the day, but the labyrinth wasn't there
> at
> >> > that
> >> > time.
> >> >
> >> > Park near the visitor center and follow these directions:
> >> > http://www.bahiker.com/eastbayhikes/sibley.html
> >> >
> >> > There's also a second less well formed labyrinth further up the
> trail.
> >> >
> >> > "The Labyrinth is located precisely at:
> >> >
> >> > Longitude: 122 degrees west,  11 minutes, 25 seconds  (-122.19043)
> >> > Latitude:       37 degrees north, 51 minutes, 11 seconds  (
> >> > 37.85304)"
> >> >
> >> > See
> >> >
> http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&hl=en&geocode=&time=&date=&ttype=&saddr=&daddr=37.85468,-122.191586&mra=mi&mrsp=0&sz=19&sll=37.854697,-122.191634&sspn=0.001216,0.002178&ie=UTF8&t=h&z=19&om=1
> >> >
> >> >
> >> > "From Post #4, take the short, narrow dirt road that leads south (to
> >> > your right, when facing the Labyrinth from above), then loops back
> >> > north and
> >> > down into the quarry pit, ending at the Labyrinth. Avoid scrambling
> >> > down any
> >> > trails directly to the Labyrinth as the slopes at the quarry
> (actually
> >> > a
> >> > gravel quarry) are steep, unstable and quite dangerous. It's not
> >> > uncommon
> >> > for visitors to experience at least one minor landslide at some time
> >> > during
> >> > their short visit. It's just a reminder of nature reclaiming itself,
> >> > taking
> >> > on a more natural, stable configuration to the landscape."
> >> >
> >> > From:
> >> > http://home.earthlink.net/~friendsofthelabyrinth/<http://home.earthlink.net/%7Efriendsofthelabyrinth/>
> <http://home.earthlink.net/%7Efriendsofthelabyrinth/>which
> >> > has a bunch of info about the labyrinth as well.
> >> >
> >> > FWIW Grace Catherdral in SF also has two labyrinths including one
> >> > indoors for rainy days...
> >> >
> >> > Best,
> >> >
> >> > Peter

>>>> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>>>> ~~~~~ It's not love for music, ~~~~~~
>>>> ~~~~~~~~ it's a passion, and ~~~~~~~~
>>>> ~~~~~~~ it goes beyond liking ~~~~~~~
>>>> ~~~~~~~~ and beyond a hobby, ~~~~~~~~
>>>> ~~~~ it's about a way of living. ~~~~
>>>> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>>>> ~~~~~~ Music is sound, hear it. ~~~~~
>>>> ~~~ Trance is an emotion, feel it. ~~
>>>> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>>>> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>>>> ~~~~~~ http://www.djSonix.com ~~~~~~~
>>>> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

>> >> >
>> >> > "The Labyrinth is located precisely at:
>> >> >
>> >> > Longitude: 122 degrees west,  11 minutes, 25 seconds  (-122.19043)
>> >> > Latitude:       37 degrees north, 51 minutes, 11 seconds  (
>> >> > 37.85304)"

>> >> > See
>> >> >

>> >> >
>> >> > "From Post #4, take the short, narrow dirt road that leads south (to
>> >> > your right, when facing the Labyrinth from above), then loops back
>> >> > north and
>> >> > down into the quarry pit, ending at the Labyrinth. Avoid scrambling
>> >> > down any
>> >> > trails directly to the Labyrinth as the slopes at the quarry
>> (actually
>> >> > a
>> >> > gravel quarry) are steep, unstable and quite dangerous. It's not
>> >> > uncommon
>> >> > for visitors to experience at least one minor landslide at some time
>> >> > during
>> >> > their short visit. It's just a reminder of nature reclaiming itself,
>> >> > taking
>> >> > on a more natural, stable configuration to the landscape."
>> >> >
>> >> > From:
>> >> > http://home.earthlink.net/~friendsofthelabyrinth/<http://home.earthlink.net/%7Efriendsofthelabyrinth/>
>> <http://home.earthlink.net/%7Efriendsofthelabyrinth/>which
>> >> > has a bunch of info about the labyrinth as well.

Subject: [sfraves] NYE - An Underground Resolution

In less than 2 weeks, on Monday December 31st, history is in
the making. An Underground Resolution was specially designed to
bring together the disparate factions in SF's electronic music
scene for the purpose of rockin' out one of SF's finest
locations, the SomArts Cultural Center. Brought to you by the
Get Freaky, Tantra, Know:Audio, the Ambient Mafia, and Word of
Mouth crews, and showcasing the incredible light shows of
Radiant Atmospheres, this party will be going all night until
8AM (at least). Here you can have your cake and eat it too!
Dance to Breaks, Psytrance, Techno, Electro, Drum & Bass,
Downtempo, and Ambient. No need to play favorites. We've got
them all!

--- Know:Audio Electro/Techno Room ---
Praxis (Omniscient Records) *live pa*
Forest Green (Cloud Factory/ Cute Things with Fangs)
Naked Slice (Renegade Virus/ Otherworld)
SirNod (Cloud Factory/ Friends and Family)
Toro Toro (rEvolution/ Friends and Family)
Mike Sims (Otherworld)
Saturnia (Phoenix Family/ Celestial Dragon)

--- Tantra Return to Goa Room ---
Dutch (Thump Radio)
Random (Vaporvent Records)
Liam Shy (Tantra)
Olowanpi (Dropout Productions)
Tim Tryptamine (CCC)
Surge (Space Children)
KJ (Tantra)

--- An-ten-nae/ Get Freaky Room ---
Freq Nasty (U.K)
An-ten-nae (Get Freaky)
Random Rab (El Circo)
El Papa Chango (El Circo)
Laura (El Circo)
Little John (Raindance)
Mozaic (Raindance)
Dov (Multi Music)
Jocelyn (Get Freaky)

--- Ambient Mafia/ Word of Mouth Chill Area ---
Actual Rafiq (:AM/ the dRow)
Boomerang Fidget (:AM/ HATFYR)
The Captain (:AM/ Chill Syndicate)
Chiral (WOM-SF/ MK2 Systems)
Cumulus (WOM-SF)
Djeeno (WOM-SF)
DJ Fieldsoe vs Harken (:AM/ Epiphany)
Mino (WOM-SF/ MK2 Systems)
Redstickman (:AM/ Friends and Family)
Seventh Swami (:AM/ Wantit)
DJ Unagi (WOM-SF)

~ Full Light Show by Radiant Atmospheres ~
~ Sound by Know:Audio and Tantra ~
~ Heated Outdoor Chill Space ~
~ Fully Stocked Bars ~ Coat Check ~
~ Friendly Black Rock Security ~

For more info and online tickets visit:
www.tantrasf.com/
www.an-ten-nae.net/

Or buy yourself a hard ticket and skip the will-call
line. Available at either Ceiba or Distractions in
SF on Haight St., or Skills in Berkeley.

-----------------------------------------------------
 www.redstickman.com

 new downtempo mix online, you should check it out.

> ~ Sound by Know:Audio and Tantra ~
> ~ Heated Outdoor Chill Space ~
> ~ Fully Stocked Bars ~ Coat Check ~
> ~ Friendly Black Rock Security ~
>
> For more info and online tickets visit:
> www.tantrasf.com/
> www.an-ten-nae.net/
>
> Or buy yourself a hard ticket and skip the will-call
> line. Available at either Ceiba or Distractions in
> SF on Haight St., or Skills in Berkeley.

>  new downtempo mix online, you should check it out.

posting earlier this year? That time, he really loved
Jungle, had never been to a a rave, had been to a
rave, didn't know what to listen to on his ipod, then
knew everything about music for his ipod, then knew
everything about raves, then his sister did, then his
brain imploded from trying to keep track of all the
lies....

When making up an internet character, for whatever
purpose, might I advise that you keep it simple enough
as to not have to remember what you do and do not
know.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Wow what a suprise

>From Wikipedia:

Despite the mainstream popularity of the word "electronica" today, it is often shunned or met with disgust by electronic musicians or former ravers. Many of the people who were actually part of the electronic and rave movements firmly believe that the word was invented by the music industry, and is just a press-word for electronic music. This is understandable, because a major part of the rave and electronic movement was an outcry against the "media machine", and many ravers and musicians did not wish for the music industry to have a large part in their lives. This part of the electronic movement has similarities to the punk movement, in that it was not meant to be mainstream.[citation needed]
In 1998, David Reilly of God Lives Underwater denounced the use of "electronica" in reference to his band, suggesting "Some marketing team probably came up with it to make sure there was a separate section at Virgin Megastore." He went on to say that he would prefer the label of "pop band", and also distanced the band from the rave movement: "They just want to take Ecstasy and dance, not listen to lyrics. And we aren't about that."[22]

>From poisoned love
Memories with traces of
What knocked me out
Knocked me out
Act as if I'm just alright
But I've already lost my sight
And you're treading ground
Without a sound

BRIDGE
Something
For nothing
I know that I haven't given
You that I haven't risen (above)

Fight for love
Or love to fight
Never knew my
Wrong from right
Patiently
I wait for the day
When it hits me
Hardest yet
And it's real
Not second best
My hearts for you
You know it's true

BRIDGE

CHORUS
Please
Believe me
Round and round
Hear the sound
Reality
Crashing into me
I hear the sound
But I can't come down

> Despite the mainstream popularity of the word "electronica"
> today, it is often shunned or met with disgust by electronic
> musicians or former ravers. Many of the people who were
> actually part of the electronic and rave movements firmly
> believe that the word was invented by the music industry, and
> is just a press-word for electronic music. This is
> understandable, because a major part of the rave and
> electronic movement was an outcry against the "media
> machine", and many ravers and musicians did not wish for the
> music industry to have a large part in their lives. This part
> of the electronic movement has similarities to the punk
> movement, in that it was not meant to be mainstream.[citation
> needed]
> In 1998, David Reilly of God Lives Underwater denounced the
> use of "electronica" in reference to his band, suggesting
> "Some marketing team probably came up with it to make sure
> there was a separate section at Virgin Megastore." He went on
> to say that he would prefer the label of "pop band", and also
> distanced the band from the rave movement: "They just want to
> take Ecstasy and dance, not listen to lyrics. And we aren't
> about that."[22]
> 
> ----- Original Message ----

Some people take that rave shiit too far. Im like get a life. No offence to=
 those that dont posses one. Wether you call it house or drum and bass its =
still music. There is such a thing called balance. Something i rarelly see =
when I post on here. But like i said i appreciate good music. If i had a ch=
oice between being a musician and a groupie i would choose to be the musici=
an. Its sad when low lifes ruin a good thing. Its cool to go to parties but=
 its not cool when partying becomes your life. Some are here for the music,=
 some are here for the women, and some are here because they have nothing b=
etter to do. im not goin to waste my time helping people to see where they =
fit in. but it is funny to me when i see someone with no life try to fit in=
to something they know nothing about. so next time you choose to talk out y=
our ass, dont. All the mature adults that havent fried all their brain cell=
s i will probably respond with normal conversation. everyone else make a cl=
ick of idiots and go sit in the middle of the dance floor. thank you.

Subject: [sfraves] what were we talking about again?

Oh yes, the two decades of excess known hereabouts as "rave culture"...=0A=
=0A"Yet a torrent of inquiry issues from our initial question. Is the rave =
a nascent rite de passage and, if so, what is its telos? What is its level =
and quality of efficacy? Is it a ritual of communion, a mass 'return' to a =
'womb' which sees co-inhabitants secure in a nutrient rich and numinous pre=
-separation stage, or an anomic post-partum 'dead-zone' catering for 'escap=
ist' desires and tragic careers in over-expenditure? An 'oceanic experience=
' or a kind of prolonged youth suicide? Does the rave or post-rave more clo=
sely approximate a Church, Disney World=E2=84=A2 or a =E2=80=9Cdetention ca=
mp for youth=E2=80=9D (Reynolds, Energy Flash 424). Has the cyber-chemical-=
millenarianism which flourished under the roof of the original acid house b=
een domesticated - the rapture contained and smothered in regulated and com=
modified leisure sites? Or has its technospiritual fervour been smuggled aw=
ay into furtive temporary autonomous zones where it percolates still? "=0A=
=0AFrom http://www.livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101-abstract.htm=
  thnx Apollo!=0A=0A"Last year I took a 70 year-old Zen monk to a rave part=
y. He was curious enough to overcome his dislike of the music until his fac=
e lit up with a revelation. 'This is meditation!', he shouted above the noi=
se. Later he explained that the walking meditation he taught involved being=
 fully aware 'in the moment' without any internal dialogue separating actio=
ns from intentions, and that the same definition applied to the dancers all=
 around him. His branch of Buddhism had been brought from Japan where there=
 was emphasis on the need to develop and balance the complementary qualitie=
s of contraction and expansion, akin to extrovert and introvert states of m=
ind. His school of Zen had concentrated on contraction with the idea that W=
esterners were too outgoing, but he now realised that those Westerners who =
were drawn to his school were introverts, and their need was for free expre=
ssion in the way he had witnessed at the rave." from http://ecstasy.org/inf=
o/rave.html=0A=0AFrom Karina: http://innerrave.org/=0A=0ASee also: http://b=
ooks.google.com/books?id=3DL4TRQGTa4IMC&pg=3DPA75&lpg=3DPA75&dq=3Drave+exce=
ss&source=3Dweb&ots=3DZ-ef0WFcFy&sig=3D-axC_wu4BDCx0VeUMPa8uht2bsM=0A=0AMay=
be raving is spiritual or maybe its just excess.  Maybe we're just hedonist=
s.  Maybe we're frying our brain cells.  Maybe.=0A=0ABut its definitely not=

he Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994.=0A=0AFrom Wikipedia:=0A=0AA =

There are some levels of failure that can be measured, if only =20
relatively against previous failures.

evaluated by that first-read metallic taste in your mouth- any further =20=

contemplation serves only to dilute the experience.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Wow what a suprise

In our psycho American culture anything that is pleasurable = bad, bad, bad.

You have heard the phrase, "You can't just go around doing whatever you 
like," as if what people naturally like is presumed to be wrong right 
off the bat.

Been that way here since before the USA was founded and it's not going 
to end anytime soon, rave is just another of many cultural sub-sets that 
got caught in the cross-hairs of that fucked-up mentality.

......

Subject: [sfraves] commercial vs underground

What is the real difference between commercial music and underground music?=
 What is the difference between commercial events and underground events? I=
m only here to expand my knowledge on the rave culture. I like to collect r=
ecords and Ive noticed a difference. The commercial records tend to have mo=
re emotion and talent while the underground records tend to be more repetat=
ive and emotionless. What do you consider to be the main goal of rave music=
? Is it really just dance music? Or is it meant to make you respond emotion=
ally? With every genre of electronica there is always a style that effects =
the soul. (uplifting trance, soulful house, happy hardcore, atmospheric dru=
m and bass, etc.) I want to know if it was just me or if these are what rav=
es are about and the rest is just garbage.

> You think rave culture is a failure?  Certainly that's true  
> depending on how you want to look at it.

You severely overestimate the amount of mental cycles I spend on "rave  
culture"- whatever that is :)

-N7

----- Original Message ----

relatively against previous failures.
Then there are failures that defy measurement, and can only be
evaluated by that first-read metallic taste in your mouth- any further
contemplation serves only to dilute the experience.

Post of the year.

-N7

----- Original Message ----
From: Ribonucliec Acid <dj.import@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Sunday, December 23, 2007 8:43:26 AM
Subject: [sfraves] commercial vs underground

What is the real difference between commercial music and underground music? What is the difference between commercial events and underground events? Im only here to expand my knowledge on the rave culture. I like to collect records and Ive noticed a difference. The commercial records tend to have more emotion and talent while the underground records tend to be more repetative and emotionless. What do you consider to be the main goal of rave music? Is it really just dance music? Or is it meant to make you respond emotionally? With every genre of electronica there is always a style that effects the soul. (uplifting trance, soulful house, happy hardcore, atmospheric drum and bass, etc.) I want to know if it was just me or if these are what raves are about and the rest is just garbage.

i <3 the walking meditation.



On Dec 22, 2007 11:22 PM,  <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Oh yes, the two decades of excess known hereabouts as "rave culture"...
>
> "Yet a torrent of inquiry issues from our initial question. Is the rave a=
 nascent rite de passage and, if so, what is its telos? What is its level a=
nd quality of efficacy? Is it a ritual of communion, a mass 'return' to a '=
womb' which sees co-inhabitants secure in a nutrient rich and numinous pre-=
separation stage, or an anomic post-partum 'dead-zone' catering for 'escapi=
st' desires and tragic careers in over-expenditure? An 'oceanic experience'=
 or a kind of prolonged youth suicide? Does the rave or post-rave more clos=
ely approximate a Church, Disney World=99 or a "detention camp for youth" (=
Reynolds, Energy Flash 424). Has the cyber-chemical-millenarianism which fl=
ourished under the roof of the original acid house been domesticated - the =
rapture contained and smothered in regulated and commodified leisure sites?=
 Or has its technospiritual fervour been smuggled away into furtive tempora=
ry autonomous zones where it percolates still? "
>
> From http://www.livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101-abstract.htm =
 thnx Apollo!
>
> "Last year I took a 70 year-old Zen monk to a rave party. He was curious =
enough to overcome his dislike of the music until his face lit up with a re=
velation. 'This is meditation!', he shouted above the noise. Later he expla=
ined that the walking meditation he taught involved being fully aware 'in t=
he moment' without any internal dialogue separating actions from intentions=
, and that the same definition applied to the dancers all around him. His b=
ranch of Buddhism had been brought from Japan where there was emphasis on t=
he need to develop and balance the complementary qualities of contraction a=
nd expansion, akin to extrovert and introvert states of mind. His school of=
 Zen had concentrated on contraction with the idea that Westerners were too=
 outgoing, but he now realised that those Westerners who were drawn to his =
school were introverts, and their need was for free expression in the way h=
e had witnessed at the rave." from http://ecstasy.org/info/rave.html
>
> From Karina: http://innerrave.org/
>
> See also: http://books.google.com/books?id=3DL4TRQGTa4IMC&pg=3DPA75&lpg=
=3DPA75&dq=3Drave+excess&source=3Dweb&ots=3DZ-ef0WFcFy&sig=3D-axC_wu4BDCx0V=
eUMPa8uht2bsM
>
> Maybe raving is spiritual or maybe its just excess.  Maybe we're just hed=
onists.  Maybe we're frying our brain cells.  Maybe.
>
> But its definitely not political right?
>
> Raving is all but dead in  the UK as a result of the Criminal Justice and=
 Public Order Act 1994.
>
> From Wikipedia:
>
> A July 2005 violent raid by police on CzechTek, an annual teknival, the C=
zech Republic's Prime Minister said the festival's attendees were "no danci=
ng children but dangerous people" and that many were "obsessed people with =
anarchist proclivities and international links," who "provoke massive viole=
nt demonstrations, fueled by alcohol and drugs, against the peaceful societ=
y."
>
> A nice picture from CzechTek: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image:Freetekn=
o_police_czech.jpg

Speaking of near misses I had one the other day driving through Baton Rouge,
I was coming onto this bridge and someone was stopped in the right lane
unexpectedly. Had a semi to my left and two stopped cars in front of me all
whilst I was doing 90 or so, had to slam the gas to get outta that one. Came
about *this close* to being worm food, it was the shit.

----- Original Message ----
From: Ribonucliec Acid <dj.import@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sent: Sunday, December 23, 2007 8:43:26 AM
Subject: [sfraves] commercial vs underground

What is the real difference between commercial music and underground
music? What is the difference between commercial events and underground
events? Im only here to expand my knowledge on the rave culture. I like to
collect records and Ive noticed a difference. The commercial records tend to
have more emotion and talent while the underground records tend to be more
repetative and emotionless. What do you consider to be the main goal of rave
music? Is it really just dance music? Or is it meant to make you respond
emotionally? With every genre of electronica there is always a style that
effects the soul. (uplifting trance, soulful house, happy hardcore,
atmospheric drum and bass, etc.) I want to know if it was just me or if
these are what raves are about and the rest is just garbage.

Subject: [sfraves] Trance Article

--_1478e230-2cf1-4cf7-9f1b-e620908cc5d0_
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-2022-jp"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Trance $B"v(B
Trance did a very promising start in the early nineties (1990's) in Europe, and is currently one of the most promising and influential music genres on the music scene. Trance itself is very wide-scoped, it occupies a lot of territory with a lot of space and brings its influence deeply outside and well beyond its own bounds, that seem to be quite obscure. At the time, many of the currently popular groups, artists, titles of mainstream music are starting to incorporate trance sound into their recordings. Initially trance was mostly non-commercial, but trance is getting more and more publicity now, on TV channels such as Viva and MTV, and in the press. Trance becomes more popularized, thanks to talented trance music DJ's and producers, trance music labels, and even large recording companies. Pop and rock stars are starting to collaborate with or even outsource their recordings to trance music composers and producers. An excellent example, Madonna with their mature, high-quality, semi-trance album Ray Of Light (1998), almost half tracks of which have explicitly clear trance sounding.


Building Blocks 
History and Evolution 
Euro Trance 
Goa Trance 
Psychedelic Trance 
Progressive Trance 
Trance Labels, DJ's and Producers 

Characteristics
Perhaps the most ambiguous genre of dance music, trance could be described as a melodic, more or less freeform style of music, partially derived from house. While there is no strict definition for trance, songs of this genre are usually characterized as being accessible and having anthemic and epic and rifting and psychedelic qualities. Using that as a starting point, a basic trance track could then be described as being comprised of a particular melodic or vocal hook which is given presence over a bassline, a drum pattern, which often includes snare or kick drum rolls to mark important moments, and perhaps one or two other semi-quantified aural elements to provide texture and enhance the rhythm. However, not all trance fits that profile, and often times a song's classification as trance has just as much to do with who is playing it as what it sounds like.
The best way to generally describe the trance genre is that of dance music based around rifts and anthems, which can be either highly energetic or very chilled out. Trance tracks often intermix major and minor chords to create "epic" sounding, similar to classical organ music. Most trance is built around the 4/4 beat, and a lot of trance can be very uplifting. Uptempo, uplifting and often euphoric energetic synthesized sounds pumped by a beat and massive hooks, often with long breakdowns building slowly to create a tension and expectancy on the dance floor. Often with driving off-the-beat basslines and utilizing major and minor chords in sequence, trance tracks can take a central epic form of commercial trance or the form of one of several sub-genres including Euro (Epic) Trance, Goa (Psychedelic, Psy) trance, Hard Trance, and Progressive Trance.
Building Blocks
You can very well understand what trance is all about if you consider both house and techno a 'power supply' or a 'fuel' of trance. Yes, in some ways trance is derived from house and techno, but this derivation is just a matter of taking the proper power supply. Look, airplanes consume diesel oil in order to be capable of flight. They just cannot fly without fuel, yet they are not fuel! They are much more complex than plain, simple diesel petrolium oil. Now draw and see an analogy, airplanes is trance, and diesel fuel is house, that's it. A more important, fundamental baseline of trance is derived from religious and spiritual roots of the East and ancient Eastern culture. It is astonishing, in fact, ambient, beatless form of trance has been there for ages! More information on this is forth below this page. From a pure music producer's standpoint, the following elements build up a basic trance track on top of a solid, house-powered beat and energetic, techno-powered progressive sound:

Rifts, rolls, breakdowns and buildups. 
Short samples often going into 16th and 32nd notes. 
Anthems. 
Highly intermixed major and minor chords. 
These are the essential elements of trance, all of them are very important as they completely change the music sound. Applying even one of them changes the sound to trance-alike. House is a mature, developed musical genre. House music can be very good, but house can never be (and has never been and never supposed to be) as uplifting and as emotional as trance. That's because trance, by its definition, has at least some or all of the above unique characteristics appertaining to trance only, which are not attributable to house in any way. Suppose you have a good house track. Once you start adding/incorporating the above qualities into it, it no longer sounds as house, it first becomes progressive house, and then it simply turns into trance.
History & Evolution
You can arguably trace trance music back to religious roots emanating from a spiritual state of mind reminiscent of shamanism and elements of bhuddism. With this in mind, it's very important that trance age in aggregate can be estimated as hundreds and thousands years. The actual sound of contemporary trance, however, was born as early as 1990 in Germany, and through pioneering trance labels like Dragonfly the sound started to take on a slightly more mainstream appeal during the later 90's. Goa and Psy-trance are arguably older, with their characteristic sounds purportedly emerging in Israel and India. The repetitive nature of much of the early trance tracks provided club-goers with the ideal chance to immerse themselves in a new style of music after a period of relative quiet on what had been termed the "dance" scene.
Arguably a fusion of techno and house, early trance shared much with techno in terms of the tempo and rhythmic structures but also added more melodic overtones which were appropriated from the style of house popular in Europe's club scene at that time. However, the melodies in trance differed from euro/club house in that although they tended to be emotional and uplifting, they did not "bounce around" in the same way that house did. This early trance tended to be characterized by the anthemic qualities described above, and typically involved a break-down portion of the song in which the beat was dropped for a few bars to focus on the melody before bringing the beat back with a renewed intensity. The trance became instantly popular in Europe and spread very quickly. Inevitably, the style was to evolve and as more and more mainstream DJ's picked up on the sound of trance, so the sound became more commercial and more diverse often relegating the traditional trance styles into background sub-genres.
By the mid-1990's, trance had emerged commercially as one of the dominant genres of dance music. Immensely popular, trance found itself filling a niche as edgier than house, more soothing than drum-n-bass, and more accessible than techno. By this time, trance had become synonymous with progressive house and both genres essentially subsumed each other under the commercial banner of "progressive." Artists like Brian Transeau (BT), Paul Van Dyk, Ferry Corsten (Art of Trance), and Underworld came to the forefront as premier producers and remixers, bringing with them the emotional, epic feel of the style. Meanwhile, DJ's like Paul Oakenfold, Sasha, and John Digweed were championing the sound in the clubs and through the sale of pre-recorded mixes. By the end of the 1990's, trance remained commercially huge but had fractured into an extremely diverse genre. Perhaps as a consequence, similar things were happening with the DJ's as well; for example, Sasha and Digweed, who together had helped bring the progressive sound to the forefront, all but abandoned it by 2000, instead spinning a darker mix of the rising "deep trance" style.
In 1996, the UK became the core of the new trance phenomenon taking trance to new heights in UK clubs and out to the clubber's island of Ibiza. DJ's like Paul Oakenfold, Sasha and John Digweed started to open the eyes of the clubbing population to what would probably be best now described as euro trance: epic winding tracks with monumental breakdowns and uplifting lead lines culminating in the ATB and Delirium sounds of 2000. Assisted by well-known producers like Robert Miles, Sash and BT, these tunes struck to the hearts of an audience looking for new energy and excitement in their music. Just as interesting to observe is the creeping effect of trance around the world. While the Israelis and Swedes in particular continue to produce new sounds, American and the new Eastern European markets are absorbed in the trance sounds of a once frenetic European market. Meantime the UK and Canada are pushing the boundaries of hard trance with new genres cropping up like Hard House, a fusion of trance and house.
With such a diverse range of music to satisfy within the genre, it is inevitable that trance becomes a victim of its own success. We've already seen the likes of trance-made DJ's like Paul Van Dyk denounce the genre and its becoming de-facto to slate the genre as old hat. However, for many true trance fans of the mid-nineties, this is ultimately leading bringing their genre back round to what it was designed to be: music for the mind, not music for the masses. The likely path for commercial trance music is either back into the "dance" fold or to once more re-badge itself, maybe as progressive, maybe as epic dance music - whichever route it transpires to follow, trance should be remembered for providing a renaissance of dance music. Currently trance continues to expand the diversity of the genre as expressed through many of its brightest DJ talents.
Euro Trance
A central, neutral form of trance which is probably the simplest to understand. Euro trance is often very uplifting, it is usually around 140 - 145 bpm and has a lot of big rifts. The bass is generally quite heavy and it will often have a female vocal. Due to the big rifts, breakdowns and vocals this style of trance can also be referred to as commercial trance. This form of trance definitely falls into the instant "feel good" category - for many trance-heads, this is how it all started. Currently much harder edged Euro Trance is being referred to as "Hard Trance", in many ways it is similar to Euro, with big, but usually not so "euphoric", rifts and a bit faster, usually around 145 - 150 bpm, often using acid lines.
Goa Trance
Goa trance is form of electronic music and is a style of trance music which originated in the Indian region of Goa. The music has its roots in the popularity of the Goa region in the late 1960's and early 1970's as a hippie mecca, although the actual Goa trance style would not appear until much later. As the tourist influx tapered off in the 1970's and 1980's, a core group remained in Goa, concentrating on improvements in music along with other activities such as yoga, recreational drug use, and various New Age pursuits.
The introduction of techno style and technique to Goa led to what would eventually become the Goa trance style; early pioneers included Goa Gil and Mark Allen. Many "parties" (similar to raves) in Goa revolve entirely around this genre of music; Goa is also often played in other countries at raves, festivals and parties often in conjunction with other styles of trance and techno.
Goa is essentially "dance-trance" music (and was referred to as "Trance Dance" in its formative years), and as such has an energetic beat, almost always at 4/4 and often going into 16th or 32nd notes. A typical number will generally build up to a much more energetic movement in the second half of the track, and then taper off fairly quickly toward the end. Generally 8-12 minutes long, Goa tracks usually have a noticeably stronger bassline than other trance music and incorporate more organic "squelchy" sounds.
Goa trance parties have a visual aspect as well, the use of "fluoro" (fluorescent paint) is common in clothing and decoration. The images are often associate with topics like aliens, hinduism and other religious (especially eastern) images, mushrooms (and other psychedelic imagery), shamanism and technology. Goa trance has a significant following in Israel, brought to that country by former soldiers returning from recreational "post-army trips" to Goa. A great deal of Goa trance is now produced in Israel, but its production and consumption is a global phenomenon.
Goa Trance effectively morphed into psychedelic trance during the latter half of the 1990's. Both styles are generally non-commercial and underground compared to other forms of trance. The goa sound is more likely to be heard at outdoor parties and festivals than in clubs and places like Ibiza. For a short period in the mid-'90's it enjoyed significant commercial success with support from DJ's like Paul Oakenfold. The artist man with no name probably came the closest to being a goa trance "star".
Psychedelic Trance
Psychedelic trance (often referred to as psy trance) is a form of trance music, developed in the late 1990's. Trance has a fast beat, in the range 125 to 150 beats per minute (bpm), compared to ambient trance music and other forms like house and techno. It has a strong bass sound that beats continuously without change and is overlaid by many other rhythms. This type of trance is popular in the UK, but is a truly global phenomenon, and interestingly there is an underrepresentation of American artists, although Israeli artists are well represented. As of 2002 many Japanese artists have started to take in this genre from the influence of UK DJ's.
The club and dance scenes worldwide have been using psychedelic trance in performances along with Goa trance, ambient trance, progressive trance, and minimalist trance. The mixture of Goa and psychedelic trance music is the popular kind of trance performance to many trance listeners. Psychedelic trance can be considered an offshoot of Goa trance. Popular artists that make psychedelic trance include Astral Projection, Space Tribe, Infected Mushroom, Atmos, Total Eclipse, Cosmosis and Simon Posford. Psychedelic trance is often played at outdoor festivals. People at these festivals sometimes consume psychedelic drugs like LSD, ecstasy and psychedelic mushrooms. The festivals often take place over a few days with music being played 24 hours a day.
Ambient Trance
The precursor to Progressive Trance, Ambient Trance is a dreamy, hypnotic and intelligent style of trance, mostly German, that utilizes atmospheric pads, epic melodic progressions and occasionally symphonic arrangements. It is not to be confused with commercial, mainstream trance from artists such as ATB or Darude. At times borrowing elements from the earlier acid movement, such as rezzy 303 leads and minimal percussion, but based more on the spiritual experience that Goa Trance has since trademarked, Ambient Trance is an often-forgotten but extremely influential style that took rave music to a higher and more profound level. Sometimes called "Oldschool Trance" because it has since been left behind for the harder styles popular today.
Ambient Trance is not as much a specific genre as it is a period in the history of dance music's most notorious style. When The Orb and other early dance pioneers were mixing ambient records with current club-oriented sounds, many producers and DJs in the UK and Germany began taking notice. As early as 1990, German musician Harald Bluechel (aka Cosmic Baby) was experimenting with classical piano and synthesizer melodies contrasted against techno rhythms, and in 1993 released one of the most popular trance songs of all time, "Cafe del Mar" (under the pseudonym Energy 52) which is still being remixed today.
Perhaps the most prolific figure in trance, then and now, is Oliver Lieb. Recording under the aliases Paragliders, The Ambush, Spicelab and LSG, Lieb remixed almost every trance producer of note during the 90's and continues to do so today. His albums spanned entire genres, from tribal, ethnic fusion to spacey trance to rough and tough techno. Considered by many to be one of the gods of trance alongside Paul van Dyk, Lieb was a huge reason why the style remained powerful and important in dance cultures around the world.
As with all styles, Ambient Trance eventually morphed into something different and by the mid 90's, it was almost entirely abandoned for harder and more progressive sounds. However, a few producers of that time still remain today producing intelligent trance, among them Humate, Salt Tank, Lieb and Paul van Dyk, albeit in a more modern setting. But most fans of dance music will fondly remember the early and mid-90's as the "good old days" of trance, with some of the most beautiful and profound tracks produced during this time.
Progressive Trance 
This trance is generally more laid back than Euro, it tends to be a lot deeper and has a less commercial edge. It is also usually slower (130 - 140 bpm) and has a wider variety of sounds - many progressive tunes use a lot of tribal techno and breakbeat sounds. The rifts in progressive music are much more subtle than that of Euro and never as uplifting. Progressive music relies more on subtle builds and drops guided by the DJ throughout the night, whereas Euro builds and drops in each individual tune. Recently much progressive trance has moved towards deep tribal sounds and breaks. This is often referred to as "progressive house".
Hard Trance
Hard Trance, as the title suggests, blends traditional trance sounds and structure with harder elements more reminiscent of Acid and Techno. The tempo is generally increased to between 145 and 155 and the kick drum and bass is usually a focus for a clubbing audience.
Trance Labels

Platipus, Kinetic, Ministry Of Sound, Dragonfly, Perfecto, Bedrock 
Trance DJ's & Producers

Paul Van Dyk, DJ Tiesto, Armin Van Buuren, Paul Oakenfold, John Digweed, Ferry Corsten, Rank 1, Sander Kleinenberg, Deep Dish, Delerium, Humate, Nick Warren, Blank & Jones, BT, Chicane, Kai Tracid, Sasha, Carl Cox, Christopher Lawrence, Yahel 
And remember... Trance can give you feelings you never forget!

On Dec 24, 2007, at 9:53 PM, Ribonucliec Acid wrote:

> Trance $B"v(B
> Trance did a very promising start in the early nineties (1990's) in  
> Europe, and is currently one of the most promising and influential  
> music genres on the music scene. Trance itself is very wide-scoped,  
> it occupies a lot of territory with a lot of space and brings its  
> influence deeply outside and well beyond its own bounds, that seem  
> to be quite obscure. At the time, many of the currently popular  
> groups, artists, titles of mainstream music are starting to  
> incorporate trance sound into their recordings. Initially trance  
> was mostly non-commercial, but trance is getting more and more  
> publicity now, on TV channels such as Viva and MTV, and in the  
> press. Trance becomes more popularized, thanks to talented trance  
> music DJ's and producers, trance music labels, and even large  
> recording companies. Pop and rock stars are starting to collaborate  
> with or even outsource their recordings to trance music composers  
> and producers. An excellent example, Madonna with their mature,  
> high-quality, semi!
>  -trance album Ray Of Light (1998), almost half tracks of which  
> have explicitly clear trance sounding.
>
>
> Building Blocks
> History and Evolution
> Euro Trance
> Goa Trance
> Psychedelic Trance
> Progressive Trance
> Trance Labels, DJ's and Producers
>
> Characteristics
> Perhaps the most ambiguous genre of dance music, trance could be  
> described as a melodic, more or less freeform style of music,  
> partially derived from house. While there is no strict definition  
> for trance, songs of this genre are usually characterized as being  
> accessible and having anthemic and epic and rifting and psychedelic  
> qualities. Using that as a starting point, a basic trance track  
> could then be described as being comprised of a particular melodic  
> or vocal hook which is given presence over a bassline, a drum  
> pattern, which often includes snare or kick drum rolls to mark  
> important moments, and perhaps one or two other semi-quantified  
> aural elements to provide texture and enhance the rhythm. However,  
> not all trance fits that profile, and often times a song's  
> classification as trance has just as much to do with who is playing  
> it as what it sounds like.
> The best way to generally describe the trance genre is that of  
> dance music based around rifts and anthems, which can be either  
> highly energetic or very chilled out. Trance tracks often intermix  
> major and minor chords to create "epic" sounding, similar to  
> classical organ music. Most trance is built around the 4/4 beat,  
> and a lot of trance can be very uplifting. Uptempo, uplifting and  
> often euphoric energetic synthesized sounds pumped by a beat and  
> massive hooks, often with long breakdowns building slowly to create  
> a tension and expectancy on the dance floor. Often with driving off- 
> the-beat basslines and utilizing major and minor chords in  
> sequence, trance tracks can take a central epic form of commercial  
> trance or the form of one of several sub-genres including Euro  
> (Epic) Trance, Goa (Psychedelic, Psy) trance, Hard Trance, and  
> Progressive Trance.
> Building Blocks
> You can very well understand what trance is all about if you  
> consider both house and techno a 'power supply' or a 'fuel' of  
> trance. Yes, in some ways trance is derived from house and techno,  
> but this derivation is just a matter of taking the proper power  
> supply. Look, airplanes consume diesel oil in order to be capable  
> of flight. They just cannot fly without fuel, yet they are not  
> fuel! They are much more complex than plain, simple diesel  
> petrolium oil. Now draw and see an analogy, airplanes is trance,  
> and diesel fuel is house, that's it. A more important, fundamental  
> baseline of trance is derived from religious and spiritual roots of  
> the East and ancient Eastern culture. It is astonishing, in fact,  
> ambient, beatless form of trance has been there for ages! More  
> information on this is forth below this page. From a pure music  
> producer's standpoint, the following elements build up a basic  
> trance track on top of a solid, house-powered beat and energetic,  
> techno-powered progressive sou!
>  nd:
>
> Rifts, rolls, breakdowns and buildups.
> Short samples often going into 16th and 32nd notes.
> Anthems.
> Highly intermixed major and minor chords.
> These are the essential elements of trance, all of them are very  
> important as they completely change the music sound. Applying even  
> one of them changes the sound to trance-alike. House is a mature,  
> developed musical genre. House music can be very good, but house  
> can never be (and has never been and never supposed to be) as  
> uplifting and as emotional as trance. That's because trance, by its  
> definition, has at least some or all of the above unique  
> characteristics appertaining to trance only, which are not  
> attributable to house in any way. Suppose you have a good house  
> track. Once you start adding/incorporating the above qualities into  
> it, it no longer sounds as house, it first becomes progressive  
> house, and then it simply turns into trance.
> History & Evolution
> You can arguably trace trance music back to religious roots  
> emanating from a spiritual state of mind reminiscent of shamanism  
> and elements of bhuddism. With this in mind, it's very important  
> that trance age in aggregate can be estimated as hundreds and  
> thousands years. The actual sound of contemporary trance, however,  
> was born as early as 1990 in Germany, and through pioneering trance  
> labels like Dragonfly the sound started to take on a slightly more  
> mainstream appeal during the later 90's. Goa and Psy-trance are  
> arguably older, with their characteristic sounds purportedly  
> emerging in Israel and India. The repetitive nature of much of the  
> early trance tracks provided club-goers with the ideal chance to  
> immerse themselves in a new style of music after a period of  
> relative quiet on what had been termed the "dance" scene.
> Arguably a fusion of techno and house, early trance shared much  
> with techno in terms of the tempo and rhythmic structures but also  
> added more melodic overtones which were appropriated from the style  
> of house popular in Europe's club scene at that time. However, the  
> melodies in trance differed from euro/club house in that although  
> they tended to be emotional and uplifting, they did not "bounce  
> around" in the same way that house did. This early trance tended to  
> be characterized by the anthemic qualities described above, and  
> typically involved a break-down portion of the song in which the  
> beat was dropped for a few bars to focus on the melody before  
> bringing the beat back with a renewed intensity. The trance became  
> instantly popular in Europe and spread very quickly. Inevitably,  
> the style was to evolve and as more and more mainstream DJ's picked  
> up on the sound of trance, so the sound became more commercial and  
> more diverse often relegating the traditional trance styles into  
> backgrou!
>  nd sub-genres.
> By the mid-1990's, trance had emerged commercially as one of the  
> dominant genres of dance music. Immensely popular, trance found  
> itself filling a niche as edgier than house, more soothing than  
> drum-n-bass, and more accessible than techno. By this time, trance  
> had become synonymous with progressive house and both genres  
> essentially subsumed each other under the commercial banner of  
> "progressive." Artists like Brian Transeau (BT), Paul Van Dyk,  
> Ferry Corsten (Art of Trance), and Underworld came to the forefront  
> as premier producers and remixers, bringing with them the  
> emotional, epic feel of the style. Meanwhile, DJ's like Paul  
> Oakenfold, Sasha, and John Digweed were championing the sound in  
> the clubs and through the sale of pre-recorded mixes. By the end of  
> the 1990's, trance remained commercially huge but had fractured  
> into an extremely diverse genre. Perhaps as a consequence, similar  
> things were happening with the DJ's as well; for example, Sasha and  
> Digweed, who together had hel!
>  ped bring the progressive sound to the forefront, all but  
> abandoned it by 2000, instead spinning a darker mix of the rising  
> "deep trance" style.
> In 1996, the UK became the core of the new trance phenomenon taking  
> trance to new heights in UK clubs and out to the clubber's island  
> of Ibiza. DJ's like Paul Oakenfold, Sasha and John Digweed started  
> to open the eyes of the clubbing population to what would probably  
> be best now described as euro trance: epic winding tracks with  
> monumental breakdowns and uplifting lead lines culminating in the  
> ATB and Delirium sounds of 2000. Assisted by well-known producers  
> like Robert Miles, Sash and BT, these tunes struck to the hearts of  
> an audience looking for new energy and excitement in their music.  
> Just as interesting to observe is the creeping effect of trance  
> around the world. While the Israelis and Swedes in particular  
> continue to produce new sounds, American and the new Eastern  
> European markets are absorbed in the trance sounds of a once  
> frenetic European market. Meantime the UK and Canada are pushing  
> the boundaries of hard trance with new genres cropping up like Hard  
> House, a fusion o!
>  f trance and house.
> With such a diverse range of music to satisfy within the genre, it  
> is inevitable that trance becomes a victim of its own success.  
> We've already seen the likes of trance-made DJ's like Paul Van Dyk  
> denounce the genre and its becoming de-facto to slate the genre as  
> old hat. However, for many true trance fans of the mid-nineties,  
> this is ultimately leading bringing their genre back round to what  
> it was designed to be: music for the mind, not music for the  
> masses. The likely path for commercial trance music is either back  
> into the "dance" fold or to once more re-badge itself, maybe as  
> progressive, maybe as epic dance music - whichever route it  
> transpires to follow, trance should be remembered for providing a  
> renaissance of dance music. Currently trance continues to expand  
> the diversity of the genre as expressed through many of its  
> brightest DJ talents.
> Euro Trance
> A central, neutral form of trance which is probably the simplest to  
> understand. Euro trance is often very uplifting, it is usually  
> around 140 - 145 bpm and has a lot of big rifts. The bass is  
> generally quite heavy and it will often have a female vocal. Due to  
> the big rifts, breakdowns and vocals this style of trance can also  
> be referred to as commercial trance. This form of trance definitely  
> falls into the instant "feel good" category - for many trance- 
> heads, this is how it all started. Currently much harder edged Euro  
> Trance is being referred to as "Hard Trance", in many ways it is  
> similar to Euro, with big, but usually not so "euphoric", rifts and  
> a bit faster, usually around 145 - 150 bpm, often using acid lines.
> Goa Trance
> Goa trance is form of electronic music and is a style of trance  
> music which originated in the Indian region of Goa. The music has  
> its roots in the popularity of the Goa region in the late 1960's  
> and early 1970's as a hippie mecca, although the actual Goa trance  
> style would not appear until much later. As the tourist influx  
> tapered off in the 1970's and 1980's, a core group remained in Goa,  
> concentrating on improvements in music along with other activities  
> such as yoga, recreational drug use, and various New Age pursuits.
> The introduction of techno style and technique to Goa led to what  
> would eventually become the Goa trance style; early pioneers  
> included Goa Gil and Mark Allen. Many "parties" (similar to raves)  
> in Goa revolve entirely around this genre of music; Goa is also  
> often played in other countries at raves, festivals and parties  
> often in conjunction with other styles of trance and techno.
> Goa is essentially "dance-trance" music (and was referred to as  
> "Trance Dance" in its formative years), and as such has an  
> energetic beat, almost always at 4/4 and often going into 16th or  
> 32nd notes. A typical number will generally build up to a much more  
> energetic movement in the second half of the track, and then taper  
> off fairly quickly toward the end. Generally 8-12 minutes long, Goa  
> tracks usually have a noticeably stronger bassline than other  
> trance music and incorporate more organic "squelchy" sounds.
> Goa trance parties have a visual aspect as well, the use of  
> "fluoro" (fluorescent paint) is common in clothing and decoration.  
> The images are often associate with topics like aliens, hinduism  
> and other religious (especially eastern) images, mushrooms (and  
> other psychedelic imagery), shamanism and technology. Goa trance  
> has a significant following in Israel, brought to that country by  
> former soldiers returning from recreational "post-army trips" to  
> Goa. A great deal of Goa trance is now produced in Israel, but its  
> production and consumption is a global phenomenon.
> Goa Trance effectively morphed into psychedelic trance during the  
> latter half of the 1990's. Both styles are generally non-commercial  
> and underground compared to other forms of trance. The goa sound is  
> more likely to be heard at outdoor parties and festivals than in  
> clubs and places like Ibiza. For a short period in the mid-'90's it  
> enjoyed significant commercial success with support from DJ's like  
> Paul Oakenfold. The artist man with no name probably came the  
> closest to being a goa trance "star".
> Psychedelic Trance
> Psychedelic trance (often referred to as psy trance) is a form of  
> trance music, developed in the late 1990's. Trance has a fast beat,  
> in the range 125 to 150 beats per minute (bpm), compared to ambient  
> trance music and other forms like house and techno. It has a strong  
> bass sound that beats continuously without change and is overlaid  
> by many other rhythms. This type of trance is popular in the UK,

> are well represented. As of 2002 many Japanese artists have started  
> to take in this genre from the influence of UK DJ's.
> The club and dance scenes worldwide have been using psychedelic  
> trance in performances along with Goa trance, ambient trance,  
> progressive trance, and minimalist trance. The mixture of Goa and  
> psychedelic trance music is the popular kind of trance performance  
> to many trance listeners. Psychedelic trance can be considered an  
> offshoot of Goa trance. Popular artists that make psychedelic  
> trance include Astral Projection, Space Tribe, Infected Mushroom,  
> Atmos, Total Eclipse, Cosmosis and Simon Posford. Psychedelic  
> trance is often played at outdoor festivals. People at these  
> festivals sometimes consume psychedelic drugs like LSD, ecstasy and  
> psychedelic mushrooms. The festivals often take place over a few  
> days with music being played 24 hours a day.
> Ambient Trance
> The precursor to Progressive Trance, Ambient Trance is a dreamy,  
> hypnotic and intelligent style of trance, mostly German, that  
> utilizes atmospheric pads, epic melodic progressions and  
> occasionally symphonic arrangements. It is not to be confused with  
> commercial, mainstream trance from artists such as ATB or Darude.  
> At times borrowing elements from the earlier acid movement, such as  
> rezzy 303 leads and minimal percussion, but based more on the  
> spiritual experience that Goa Trance has since trademarked, Ambient  
> Trance is an often-forgotten but extremely influential style that  
> took rave music to a higher and more profound level. Sometimes  
> called "Oldschool Trance" because it has since been left behind for  
> the harder styles popular today.
> Ambient Trance is not as much a specific genre as it is a period in  
> the history of dance music's most notorious style. When The Orb and  
> other early dance pioneers were mixing ambient records with current  
> club-oriented sounds, many producers and DJs in the UK and Germany  
> began taking notice. As early as 1990, German musician Harald
