	 <a4e46f21313f3deb9c42a04171f72333@earthlink.net>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] A report from late 2007-era Berlin, plus my musings (rant) on why SF is not Berlin.

jaded chelsea!

i'm going to quite raving, now.


On Dec 27, 2007 1:58 AM, Philip. X. Diaz <st_indigo@earthlink.net> wrote:
> POST OF THE YEAR!
>
>
>
> On Dec 26, 2007, at 10:23 PM, Chelsea Faith wrote:
>
> > Hello hello.  This is Chelsea Faith, reporting from Berlin.  I thought
> > I'd
> > give a little report, after having been here for a week of my month
> > stay.
> >
> > Ahh Berlin.... a very special place where you can go out, take
> > ecstasy, and
> > dance to techno in a packed club until 10am... on *Christmas*.  Gotta
> > love
> > this place.
> >
> > Last time I was here (in March) I was surprised to hear so much melodic
> > techno- Fairmont, Extrawelt, Patrick Chadronnet, etc etc.  Apparently
> > now
> > this sound has been relegated to more mainstream clubs where raver
> > thugs from Brandenburg hang out.  (Brandenburg is to Berlin what the
> > suburbs
> > of the South Bay are to SF).  So, most people are over it.  Things
> > change
> > quickly here.
> >
> > I've been hearing a bit of a retro thing going on here- not retro as
> > in the
> > 80s electro business that's taken over almost everything in SF, but
> > more of
> > a return to Berlin's early 90s techno roots.  I've been hearing techno
> > that's deep, driving, hypnotic, and heady, much like the minimal of
> > yore.
> > There's still the klicker-klacker minimal stuff around too, but in
> > general
> > things have taken a bit of a turn for the deeper. Classic minimal
> > sounds,
> > not minimal as in short, clipped, digital stuff, but more minimal as in
> > structure- gradual, evolving changes. I am hearing the influence of
> > "Energy
> > Flash" in so many tracks, namely the use of crash cymbal, deep deep
> > bass,
> > and those heavily verbed-out claps that still give me shivers. This is
> > music
> > made with new technology by people who still know how to program a
> > real drum
> > machine. A good balance of old and new.
> >
> > Another sound I've been hearing is this very sparse, percussive,
> > effected,
> > and rhythmically complex techno.  The arrangements are extremely
> > sparse, but
> > continually changing - almost the opposite of what used to be called
> > 'minimal'.  What I love about these tracks is that they are so heady
> > and
> > spaced out, but still major dancefloor movers, designed for that
> > special
> > moment around 7:30am.  Hi-hats will pan from one side to the other, a
> > heavily delayed "blooooooop!" might just pop up when you least expect
> > it,
> > and bursts of white noise are everywhere.  It's psychedelic without
> > being in
> > your face about it, maintaining its elegance. Though the percussion is
> > relatively thin, the beats are still driving and the bass is mega
> > deep.  A
> > friend of mine here described this sound as techno created with the
> > techniques and aesthetic of minimal.  It's stripped down and tripped
> > out,
> > but still pretty bangin by 2007 standards.
> >
> > Berlin is pretty special, of course we know this.  The musical climate
> > here
> > is so open, fresh, and fertile.  We have a pretty solid minimal scene
> > in SF
> > now (as I'm sure you've noticed by now), but it's nothing like Berlin.
> > There are tons of reasons why there is such a unique and amazing music
> > scene
> > here, I won't go over all the history and other blah blah blah stuff,
> > but
> > there is one huge difference I see between the two cities: emphasis on
> > local
> > talent.  Techno is made here in Berlin, there are so many great DJs,
> > producers, record labels, record shops, clubs, etc.  Parties here are
> > often
> > driven by local acts. SF has a strong techno community as well, as you
> > can
> > see from the near-nightly minimal club events happening in the city,
> > but I
> > see a couple major issues that prevent SF from reaching the level of a
> > city
> > like Berlin-
> >
> > For one, everything is imported.  From the headliners flying in from
> > Sweden,
> > Germany, or Detroit, to the legions of DJs playing the Latest Techno
> > MegaHit
> > from M_nus, it all comes from outside.  I don't think this is because
> > of any
> > shortage on talent, there are many people creating techno in the Bay
> > Area, I
> > know a lot of you!  The party scene is strong in SF, but that's just
> > it -
> > it's a party scene, not a music scene. It's a promoter scene. The
> > two-headliners-two-residents formula that pretty much rules all techno
> > events in the Bay Area is stifling. There is little room for growth. I
> > know
> > there are local DJs that play out regularly, but there are only, what,
> > seven
> > of you? And you only get booked because you're a promoter who books
> > yourself
> > to play at every party you throw (I mean... ahem... you're a
> > "resident")...
> > am I wrong?  I know how great it feels to bring out a headliner you
> > love and
> > watch hundreds of smiling people get off to the music you selected for
> > them.
> > And I know that it's important to get some cross-pollination going,
> > getting
> > new sounds and ideas coming in from other places. I also know that many
> > promoters feel entitled to play at every event they throw because....
> > well,
> > it's their event, they can do what they want (or, they worked hard for
> > it,
> > they deserve it, they paid for it, etc, whatever). But another
> > important
> > thing is balance, and we don't have very much of that.  Sure, bringing
> > out
> > fantastic headliners from around the world brings exposure to the
> > music, but
> > haven't we passed that phase yet?  Minimal is everywhere- I'm
> > expecting to
> > hear Loco Dice in a supermarket any day now.  Isn't there room to
> > support
> > and develop local talent by now, as well as continue to bring
> > headliners
> > from other parts of the world? Can't we do both?  It's been proven that
> > techno works pretty well here, so now would be a good time to
> > experiment
> > with the formula, while people are still paying attention.
> >
> > Another thing I see holding SF back is its identity crisis.  The local
> > DJs/residents here are trying so hard to emulate what they perceive to
> > be a
> > European sound.  There isn't a whole lot of originality.  I hear the
> > same
> > tracks over and over, played by every DJ.  (If I hear 'RUOK' one more
> > time... good lord, enough with that shit! Yes, I am ok. No, I don't
> > have to
> > puke!)  We obsess over the latest tracks from Europe and Detroit, and
> > strive
> > to emulate whatever's hot in Berlin right now, but never think to just
> > be
> > ourselves.  Sure, imitation can lead to new innovations - Berlin was
> > imitating Detroit, after all. But originality is worth almost nothing
> > in SF.
> > Part of the magic of Berlin is the way DJs and producers are so simply
> > being
> > themselves, effortlessly. They aren't pretending to be something
> > they're not
> > - Berlin is Berlin, and that's it.  SF is just buying into the global
> > minimal explosion, rather than creating its own sound.  There is no SF
> > techno sound.  This also goes with the over-emphasis on
> > out-of-town headliners.  Without creating something original, and
> > without
> > creating something locally, techno in San Francisco is going to fade
> > out
> > like any other normal fad. (Nuskool breaks anyone?)
> >
> > So, yes, ok, maybe I am a little biased about all this, being a local
> > techno
> > live pa. Really biased, in fact.  On the one hand, I feel like I
> > should be
> > happy that the music I love is finally popular in my city. On the other
> > hand, the minimal boom has killed the local techno scene that used to
> > exist.
> > Funny, we used to bitch about how none of us ever got booked because
> > there
> > were no techno parties, nowhere for us to play - now there are more
> > techno
> > parties than you can count, laptop DJs and minimal club nights are a
> > dime a
> > dozen, but my American passport doesn't really help me get gigs in my
> > European-headliner-obsessed city. (A friend of mine here in Berlin
> > suggested
> > I re-import myself - move to Europe and then get booked to play in San
> > Francisco. Ha.) I've heard people complain about local techno folks
> > moving
> > to Berlin.... "Another local producer moved to Berlin. They keep
> > leaving,
> > one after another!"  As if techno producers moving to Berlin are
> > giving up,
> > quitters, going AWOL. But they're smart.  There's a reason why we're
> > all
> > leaving. San Francisco's party scene (or rather, promoter scene) does
> > not
> > support local producers, period. Nope. Does not. Why should we stay
> > here?
> > To support the local scene or whatever?  What's the point of staying
> > when
> > the scene does not support us? We're just here to take your flyers,
> > help you
> > reach your bar minimum for the night, believe your hype, and be pawns.
> > Maybe
> > we won't get booked in Berlin either, but at least in Berlin there is
> > better
> > music and more efficient public transportation!
> >
> > There is TONS of interest in techno in San Francisco right now, and
> > this is
> > a great time to start something (well, I've been saying that for a long
> > time, but now is really a good time I think).  So, I conclude, here
> > are a
> > couple things we need to get over in order to elevate our music scene-
> >
> > -Kill the headliner/residents formula, or party formulas in general.
> > Try
> > something different. There are all kinds of different parties here in
> > Berlin, with out of town headliners, locals, DJs, live pa's, laptops,
> > hardware, vinyl, etc. Parties happen in all types of venues too, not
> > the
> > same club each time. (My favorite example is Reclaim the Sparkasse,
> > renegade
> > parties that are held in the front room of banks, where the ATMs are.)
> >
> > -Be yourself, be original, create something.  Sorry, I know, this is
> > tired
> > advice that you've been hearing from your mom and athletic shoe
> > commercials
> > since you were born, but it's still the truest thing ever.  Forget
> > about the
> > top 10 on Beatport, and just do your thing.
> >
> > I could go on, but I don't want to rant and nag too much.  You catch my
> > drift.  I don't usually post long, opinionated rants on SFR, for fear
> > of
> > being shit on and looked down upon, but I feel like I don't have much
> > to
> > lose.
> >
> > Oh no.  I truly am one of you now.  It happened. I am jaded.
> >
> >
> > Love Chelsea
> > reporting from Berlin
> > <3
> >
> > More Berlin reports to come, if you guys are interested.
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------

I loved this posting Chelsea and hope to hear more reports from Berlin.  

One thing I found interesting is contrasting your description of the local techno scene, "There is no SF techno sound" with the late nineties house scene.  There definitely was/is a unique SF house sound, but still many of the same issues with imported headliners, closed lineups, little innovation party-wise, and often just boring music.    IMO anyhow.

Peter

Thread-Topic: [sfraves] commercial vs underground

References: <BLU117-W163FD3D94219C72541E5AFF2580@phx.gbl>
From: "Daniel Faustine" <DFaustine@procedesoftware.com>

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] commercial vs underground

I'd like to take a stab at this one if I may.

For me the difference between commercial and underground is, and has
always been, about the connections you make with people. The quality of
people you meet in each of those scenes is always different. I met
people at some underground events 10 years ago that I am still friends
with today.

It's the same when you're talking about any music scene, not just EDM.
It's easier to find good quality people that you have a lot in common
with at a small punk club than, say, at Lollapalooza or Woodstock.=20

Hands down, I've ALWAYS had more fun and met more cool people at small
underground events rather than at massives... and it's those parties
that always stick out in my mind and make me smile when I think back to
those days.


Thanks,
=20
-Dan=20

-----Original Message-----
From: Ribonucliec Acid [mailto:dj.import@hotmail.com]=20
Sent: Sunday, December 23, 2007 8:43 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] commercial vs underground

What is the real difference between commercial music and underground
music? What is the difference between commercial events and underground
events? Im only here to expand my knowledge on the rave culture. I like
to collect records and Ive noticed a difference. The commercial records
tend to have more emotion and talent while the underground records tend
to be more repetative and emotionless. What do you consider to be the
main goal of rave music? Is it really just dance music? Or is it meant
to make you respond emotionally? With every genre of electronica there
is always a style that effects the soul. (uplifting trance, soulful
house, happy hardcore, atmospheric drum and bass, etc.) I want to know
if it was just me or if these are what raves are about and the rest is
just garbage.

From: filter.sf@gmail.com
To: "dangrsmind@yahoo.com" <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>, SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <711594.522.qm@web32408.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0

	boundary="----=_Part_7305_22089352.1198783791758"
References: <711594.522.qm@web32408.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] A report from late 2007-era Berlin, plus my musings (rant) on why SF is not Berlin.

------=_Part_7305_22089352.1198783791758
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

With music's digital explosion, and all the opportunities for music making
collaboration technology affords us there's a ton of global
cross-pollination that could easily drown out the sound of M_nus and other
copy-cats.

Because of this, I'm observing that the two main references for techno :
Berlin and Detroit, are going to give way to a variety of sounds drawn from
a huge variety of traditions, technologies and methods.

It's really exciting to participate in sample making, swapping and
collaboration with folks all over the world with none of the typical frames
of reference, even shunning the standard fave 303 or 808s. In fact, there's
a huge role for indigenous music and rhythm here in the modern-primal
dancefloor (no, I'm not talking about Samim's "Heater" accordians either).

Another perspective: We heard recently from producers and promoters in
Switzerland who were once fueling the minimal bandwagon that their main
source of inspiration these days is 90's era San Fran and Chicago house.

-Jennifer/Solekandi




On 12/27/07, dangrsmind@yahoo.com <dangrsmind@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> I loved this posting Chelsea and hope to hear more reports from Berlin.
>
> One thing I found interesting is contrasting your description of the local
> techno scene, "There is no SF techno sound" with the late nineties house
> scene.  There definitely was/is a unique SF house sound, but still many of
> the same issues with imported headliners, closed lineups, little innovation
> party-wise, and often just boring music.    IMO anyhow.
>
> Regards,
>
> Peter

Subject: RE: [sfraves] commercial vs underground

------_=_NextPart_001_01C848F4.015EAA04
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

It's not location that makes an event underground, it's the attitudes of
the people involved with the event.

=20

You have to look at the mentality of the people involved. What is their
motivation for throwing an event? Are they interested in booking major
headliners, packing people in like sardines, and making money hand over
fist selling bottles of water for $6 a piece? Or are they interested in
hosting an event that is comfortable, that has a fun and relaxed
atmosphere, that not only is a good place for music but is also a good
place to collaborate, meet cool new people and share ideas... perform
random acts of self-expression... and sell water for a buck (or give it
away for free)?

=20

Where is the best place to hold an event is the wrong question to be
asking. You should be asking yourself, what kind of event to I want to
hold? What is my motivation? How do I want my event to be remembered?=20

=20

The bottom line here is this: Do you want a bunch of DJ's to be the
entire focus of the party experience, or do you want your partygoers to
create their own experiences? That's the difference between commercial
and underground to me.

=20

-D

=20

________________________________

------_=_NextPart_001_01C848F5.75DDAA5C
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Here's another way to look at it...

=20

Commercial vs underground are complete polar opposites, coming strictly
from a marketing standpoint. A true underground event doesn't have any
promotion other than word of mouth and *maybe* a flyer with a date and a
phone number. True underground events aren't sponsored, endorsed, or
otherwise affiliated with any products or services that would be
considered in the commercial market. That includes venues and sometimes
even DJ's. People who throw underground events aren't interested in
making money, they are more about the people and the experiences they
will create.

=20

Either way, it still boils down to motivation. And attitude.

=20

-D

________________________________

Subject: Re: [sfraves] A report from late 2007-era Berlin, plus my musings (rant) on why SF is not Berlin.

Ditto.  This one goes in my "save" box.  :)

--- "Philip.X.Diaz" <st_indigo@earthlink.net> wrote:

> POST OF THE YEAR!
> 
> 
> On Dec 26, 2007, at 10:23 PM, Chelsea Faith wrote:
> 
> > Hello hello.  This is Chelsea Faith, reporting from Berlin.
>  I thought 
> > I'd
> > give a little report, after having been here for a week of
> my month 
> > stay.
> >
> > Ahh Berlin.... a very special place where you can go out,
> take 
> > ecstasy, and
> > dance to techno in a packed club until 10am... on
> *Christmas*.  Gotta 
> > love
> > this place.
> >
> > Last time I was here (in March) I was surprised to hear so
> much melodic
> > techno- Fairmont, Extrawelt, Patrick Chadronnet, etc etc. 
> Apparently 
> > now
> > this sound has been relegated to more mainstream clubs
> where raver
> > thugs from Brandenburg hang out.  (Brandenburg is to Berlin
> what the 
> > suburbs
> > of the South Bay are to SF).  So, most people are over it. 
> Things 
> > change
> > quickly here.
> >
> > I've been hearing a bit of a retro thing going on here- not
> retro as 
> > in the
> > 80s electro business that's taken over almost everything in
> SF, but 
> > more of
> > a return to Berlin's early 90s techno roots.  I've been
> hearing techno
> > that's deep, driving, hypnotic, and heady, much like the
> minimal of 
> > yore.
> > There's still the klicker-klacker minimal stuff around too,
> but in 
> > general
> > things have taken a bit of a turn for the deeper. Classic
> minimal 
> > sounds,
> > not minimal as in short, clipped, digital stuff, but more
> minimal as in
> > structure- gradual, evolving changes. I am hearing the
> influence of 
> > "Energy
> > Flash" in so many tracks, namely the use of crash cymbal,
> deep deep 
> > bass,
> > and those heavily verbed-out claps that still give me
> shivers. This is 
> > music
> > made with new technology by people who still know how to
> program a 
> > real drum
> > machine. A good balance of old and new.
> >
> > Another sound I've been hearing is this very sparse,
> percussive, 
> > effected,
> > and rhythmically complex techno.  The arrangements are
> extremely 
> > sparse, but
> > continually changing - almost the opposite of what used to
> be called
> > 'minimal'.  What I love about these tracks is that they are
> so heady 
> > and
> > spaced out, but still major dancefloor movers, designed for
> that 
> > special
> > moment around 7:30am.  Hi-hats will pan from one side to
> the other, a
> > heavily delayed "blooooooop!" might just pop up when you
> least expect 
> > it,
> > and bursts of white noise are everywhere.  It's psychedelic
> without 
> > being in
> > your face about it, maintaining its elegance. Though the
> percussion is
> > relatively thin, the beats are still driving and the bass
> is mega 
> > deep.  A
> > friend of mine here described this sound as techno created
> with the
> > techniques and aesthetic of minimal.  It's stripped down
> and tripped 
> > out,
> > but still pretty bangin by 2007 standards.
> >
> > Berlin is pretty special, of course we know this.  The
> musical climate 
> > here
> > is so open, fresh, and fertile.  We have a pretty solid
> minimal scene 
> > in SF
> > now (as I'm sure you've noticed by now), but it's nothing
> like Berlin.
> > There are tons of reasons why there is such a unique and
> amazing music 
> > scene
> > here, I won't go over all the history and other blah blah
> blah stuff, 
> > but
> > there is one huge difference I see between the two cities:
> emphasis on 
> > local
> > talent.  Techno is made here in Berlin, there are so many
> great DJs,
> > producers, record labels, record shops, clubs, etc. 
> Parties here are 
> > often
> > driven by local acts. SF has a strong techno community as
> well, as you 
> > can
> > see from the near-nightly minimal club events happening in
> the city, 
> > but I
> > see a couple major issues that prevent SF from reaching the
> level of a 
> > city
> > like Berlin-
> >
> > For one, everything is imported.  From the headliners
> flying in from 
> > Sweden,
> > Germany, or Detroit, to the legions of DJs playing the
> Latest Techno 
> > MegaHit
> > from M_nus, it all comes from outside.  I don't think this
> is because 
> > of any
> > shortage on talent, there are many people creating techno
> in the Bay 
> > Area, I
> > know a lot of you!  The party scene is strong in SF, but
> that's just 
> > it -
> > it's a party scene, not a music scene. It's a promoter
> scene. The
> > two-headliners-two-residents formula that pretty much rules
> all techno
> > events in the Bay Area is stifling. There is little room
> for growth. I 
> > know
> > there are local DJs that play out regularly, but there are
> only, what, 
> > seven
> > of you? And you only get booked because you're a promoter
> who books 
> > yourself
> > to play at every party you throw (I mean... ahem... you're
> a 
> > "resident")...
> > am I wrong?  I know how great it feels to bring out a
> headliner you 
> > love and
> > watch hundreds of smiling people get off to the music you
> selected for 
> > them.
> > And I know that it's important to get some
> cross-pollination going, 
> > getting
> > new sounds and ideas coming in from other places. I also
> know that many
> > promoters feel entitled to play at every event they throw
> because.... 
> > well,
> > it's their event, they can do what they want (or, they
> worked hard for 
> > it,
> > they deserve it, they paid for it, etc, whatever). But
> another 
> > important
> > thing is balance, and we don't have very much of that. 
> Sure, bringing 
> > out
> > fantastic headliners from around the world brings exposure
> to the 
> > music, but
> > haven't we passed that phase yet?  Minimal is everywhere-
> I'm 
> > expecting to
> > hear Loco Dice in a supermarket any day now.  Isn't there
> room to 
> > support
> > and develop local talent by now, as well as continue to
> bring 
> > headliners
> > from other parts of the world? Can't we do both?  It's been
> proven that
> > techno works pretty well here, so now would be a good time
> to 
> > experiment
> > with the formula, while people are still paying attention.
> >
> > Another thing I see holding SF back is its identity crisis.
>  The local
> > DJs/residents here are trying so hard to emulate what they
> perceive to 
> > be a
> > European sound.  There isn't a whole lot of originality.  I
> hear the 
> > same
> > tracks over and over, played by every DJ.  (If I hear
> 'RUOK' one more
> > time... good lord, enough with that shit! Yes, I am ok. No,
> I don't 
> > have to
> > puke!)  We obsess over the latest tracks from Europe and
> Detroit, and 
> > strive
> > to emulate whatever's hot in Berlin right now, but never
> think to just 
> > be
> > ourselves.  Sure, imitation can lead to new innovations -
> Berlin was
> > imitating Detroit, after all. But originality is worth
> almost nothing 
> > in SF.
> > Part of the magic of Berlin is the way DJs and producers
> are so simply 
> > being
> > themselves, effortlessly. They aren't pretending to be
> something 
> > they're not
> > - Berlin is Berlin, and that's it.  SF is just buying into
> the global
> > minimal explosion, rather than creating its own sound. 
> There is no SF
> > techno sound.  This also goes with the over-emphasis on
> > out-of-town headliners.  Without creating something
> original, and 
> > without
> > creating something locally, techno in San Francisco is
> going to fade 
> > out
> > like any other normal fad. (Nuskool breaks anyone?)
> >
> > So, yes, ok, maybe I am a little biased about all this,
> being a local 
> > techno
> > live pa. Really biased, in fact.  On the one hand, I feel
> like I 
> > should be
> > happy that the music I love is finally popular in my city.
> On the other
> > hand, the minimal boom has killed the local techno scene
> that used to 
> > exist.
> > Funny, we used to bitch about how none of us ever got
> booked because 
> > there
> > were no techno parties, nowhere for us to play - now there
> are more 
> > techno
> > parties than you can count, laptop DJs and minimal club
> nights are a 
> > dime a
> > dozen, but my American passport doesn't really help me get
> gigs in my
> > European-headliner-obsessed city. (A friend of mine here in
> Berlin 
> > suggested
> > I re-import myself - move to Europe and then get booked to
> play in San
> > Francisco. Ha.) I've heard people complain about local
> techno folks 
> > moving
> > to Berlin.... "Another local producer moved to Berlin. They
> keep 
> > leaving,
> > one after another!"  As if techno producers moving to
> Berlin are 
> > giving up,
> > quitters, going AWOL. But they're smart.  There's a reason
> why we're 
> > all
> > leaving. San Francisco's party scene (or rather, promoter
> scene) does 
> > not
> > support local producers, period. Nope. Does not. Why should
> we stay 
> > here?
> > To support the local scene or whatever?  What's the point
> of staying 
> > when
> > the scene does not support us? We're just here to take your
> flyers, 
> > help you
> > reach your bar minimum for the night, believe your hype,
> and be pawns. 
> > Maybe
> > we won't get booked in Berlin either, but at least in
> Berlin there is 
> > better
> > music and more efficient public transportation!
> >
> > There is TONS of interest in techno in San Francisco right
> now, and 
> > this is
> > a great time to start something (well, I've been saying
> that for a long
> > time, but now is really a good time I think).  So, I
> conclude, here 
> > are a
> > couple things we need to get over in order to elevate our
> music scene-
> >
> > -Kill the headliner/residents formula, or party formulas in
> general. 
> > Try
> > something different. There are all kinds of different
> parties here in
> > Berlin, with out of town headliners, locals, DJs, live
> pa's, laptops,
> > hardware, vinyl, etc. Parties happen in all types of venues
> too, not 
> > the
> > same club each time. (My favorite example is Reclaim the
> Sparkasse, 
> > renegade
> > parties that are held in the front room of banks, where the
> ATMs are.)
> >
> > -Be yourself, be original, create something.  Sorry, I
> know, this is 
> > tired
> > advice that you've been hearing from your mom and athletic
> shoe 
> > commercials
> > since you were born, but it's still the truest thing ever. 
> Forget 
> > about the
> > top 10 on Beatport, and just do your thing.
> >
> > I could go on, but I don't want to rant and nag too much. 
> You catch my
> > drift.  I don't usually post long, opinionated rants on
> SFR, for fear 
> > of
> > being shit on and looked down upon, but I feel like I don't
> have much 
> > to
> > lose.
> >
> > Oh no.  I truly am one of you now.  It happened. I am
> jaded.
> >
> >
> > Love Chelsea
> > reporting from Berlin
> > <3
> >
> > More Berlin reports to come, if you guys are interested.
> 
> 
>

On Thu, Dec 27, 2007 at 07:42:19PM -0800, michael, the red stickman wrote:
> Ditto.  This one goes in my "save" box.  :)
> 
> m
> 
> --- "Philip.X.Diaz" <st_indigo@earthlink.net> wrote:
> 
> > POST OF THE YEAR!
> > 
> > 
> > On Dec 26, 2007, at 10:23 PM, Chelsea Faith wrote:
> > 
> > > Hello hello.  This is Chelsea Faith, reporting from Berlin.
> >  I thought 
> > > I'd
> > > give a little report, after having been here for a week of
> > my month 
> > > stay.
> > >
> > > Ahh Berlin.... a very special place where you can go out,
> > take 
> > > ecstasy, and
> > > dance to techno in a packed club until 10am... on
> > *Christmas*.  Gotta 
> > > love
> > > this place.
> > >
> > > Last time I was here (in March) I was surprised to hear so
> > much melodic
> > > techno- Fairmont, Extrawelt, Patrick Chadronnet, etc etc. 
> > Apparently 
> > > now
> > > this sound has been relegated to more mainstream clubs
> > where raver
> > > thugs from Brandenburg hang out.  (Brandenburg is to Berlin
> > what the 
> > > suburbs
> > > of the South Bay are to SF).  So, most people are over it. 
> > Things 
> > > change
> > > quickly here.
> > >
> > > I've been hearing a bit of a retro thing going on here- not
> > retro as 
> > > in the
> > > 80s electro business that's taken over almost everything in
> > SF, but 
> > > more of
> > > a return to Berlin's early 90s techno roots.  I've been
> > hearing techno
> > > that's deep, driving, hypnotic, and heady, much like the
> > minimal of 
> > > yore.
> > > There's still the klicker-klacker minimal stuff around too,
> > but in 
> > > general
> > > things have taken a bit of a turn for the deeper. Classic
> > minimal 
> > > sounds,
> > > not minimal as in short, clipped, digital stuff, but more
> > minimal as in
> > > structure- gradual, evolving changes. I am hearing the
> > influence of 
> > > "Energy
> > > Flash" in so many tracks, namely the use of crash cymbal,
> > deep deep 
> > > bass,
> > > and those heavily verbed-out claps that still give me
> > shivers. This is 
> > > music
> > > made with new technology by people who still know how to
> > program a 
> > > real drum
> > > machine. A good balance of old and new.
> > >
> > > Another sound I've been hearing is this very sparse,
> > percussive, 
> > > effected,
> > > and rhythmically complex techno.  The arrangements are
> > extremely 
> > > sparse, but
> > > continually changing - almost the opposite of what used to
> > be called
> > > 'minimal'.  What I love about these tracks is that they are
> > so heady 
> > > and
> > > spaced out, but still major dancefloor movers, designed for
> > that 
> > > special
> > > moment around 7:30am.  Hi-hats will pan from one side to
> > the other, a
> > > heavily delayed "blooooooop!" might just pop up when you
> > least expect 
> > > it,
> > > and bursts of white noise are everywhere.  It's psychedelic
> > without 
> > > being in
> > > your face about it, maintaining its elegance. Though the
> > percussion is
> > > relatively thin, the beats are still driving and the bass
> > is mega 
> > > deep.  A
> > > friend of mine here described this sound as techno created
> > with the
> > > techniques and aesthetic of minimal.  It's stripped down
> > and tripped 
> > > out,
> > > but still pretty bangin by 2007 standards.
> > >
> > > Berlin is pretty special, of course we know this.  The
> > musical climate 
> > > here
> > > is so open, fresh, and fertile.  We have a pretty solid
> > minimal scene 
> > > in SF
> > > now (as I'm sure you've noticed by now), but it's nothing
> > like Berlin.
> > > There are tons of reasons why there is such a unique and
> > amazing music 
> > > scene
> > > here, I won't go over all the history and other blah blah
> > blah stuff, 
> > > but
> > > there is one huge difference I see between the two cities:
> > emphasis on 
> > > local
> > > talent.  Techno is made here in Berlin, there are so many
> > great DJs,
> > > producers, record labels, record shops, clubs, etc. 
> > Parties here are 
> > > often
> > > driven by local acts. SF has a strong techno community as
> > well, as you 
> > > can
> > > see from the near-nightly minimal club events happening in
> > the city, 
> > > but I
> > > see a couple major issues that prevent SF from reaching the
> > level of a 
> > > city
> > > like Berlin-
> > >
> > > For one, everything is imported.  From the headliners
> > flying in from 
> > > Sweden,
> > > Germany, or Detroit, to the legions of DJs playing the
> > Latest Techno 
> > > MegaHit
> > > from M_nus, it all comes from outside.  I don't think this
> > is because 
> > > of any
> > > shortage on talent, there are many people creating techno
> > in the Bay 
> > > Area, I
> > > know a lot of you!  The party scene is strong in SF, but
> > that's just 
> > > it -
> > > it's a party scene, not a music scene. It's a promoter
> > scene. The
> > > two-headliners-two-residents formula that pretty much rules
> > all techno
> > > events in the Bay Area is stifling. There is little room
> > for growth. I 
> > > know
> > > there are local DJs that play out regularly, but there are
> > only, what, 
> > > seven
> > > of you? And you only get booked because you're a promoter
> > who books 
> > > yourself
> > > to play at every party you throw (I mean... ahem... you're
> > a 
> > > "resident")...
> > > am I wrong?  I know how great it feels to bring out a
> > headliner you 
> > > love and
> > > watch hundreds of smiling people get off to the music you
> > selected for 
> > > them.
> > > And I know that it's important to get some
> > cross-pollination going, 
> > > getting
> > > new sounds and ideas coming in from other places. I also
> > know that many
> > > promoters feel entitled to play at every event they throw
> > because.... 
> > > well,
> > > it's their event, they can do what they want (or, they
> > worked hard for 
> > > it,
> > > they deserve it, they paid for it, etc, whatever). But
> > another 
> > > important
> > > thing is balance, and we don't have very much of that. 
> > Sure, bringing 
> > > out
> > > fantastic headliners from around the world brings exposure
> > to the 
> > > music, but
> > > haven't we passed that phase yet?  Minimal is everywhere-
> > I'm 
> > > expecting to
> > > hear Loco Dice in a supermarket any day now.  Isn't there
> > room to 
> > > support
> > > and develop local talent by now, as well as continue to
> > bring 
> > > headliners
> > > from other parts of the world? Can't we do both?  It's been
> > proven that
> > > techno works pretty well here, so now would be a good time
> > to 
> > > experiment
> > > with the formula, while people are still paying attention.
> > >
> > > Another thing I see holding SF back is its identity crisis.
> >  The local
> > > DJs/residents here are trying so hard to emulate what they
> > perceive to 
> > > be a
> > > European sound.  There isn't a whole lot of originality.  I
> > hear the 
> > > same
> > > tracks over and over, played by every DJ.  (If I hear
> > 'RUOK' one more
> > > time... good lord, enough with that shit! Yes, I am ok. No,
> > I don't 
> > > have to
> > > puke!)  We obsess over the latest tracks from Europe and
> > Detroit, and 
> > > strive
> > > to emulate whatever's hot in Berlin right now, but never
> > think to just 
> > > be
> > > ourselves.  Sure, imitation can lead to new innovations -
> > Berlin was
> > > imitating Detroit, after all. But originality is worth
> > almost nothing 
> > > in SF.
> > > Part of the magic of Berlin is the way DJs and producers
> > are so simply 
> > > being
> > > themselves, effortlessly. They aren't pretending to be
> > something 
> > > they're not
> > > - Berlin is Berlin, and that's it.  SF is just buying into
> > the global
> > > minimal explosion, rather than creating its own sound. 
> > There is no SF
> > > techno sound.  This also goes with the over-emphasis on
> > > out-of-town headliners.  Without creating something
> > original, and 
> > > without
> > > creating something locally, techno in San Francisco is
> > going to fade 
> > > out
> > > like any other normal fad. (Nuskool breaks anyone?)
> > >
> > > So, yes, ok, maybe I am a little biased about all this,
> > being a local 
> > > techno
> > > live pa. Really biased, in fact.  On the one hand, I feel
> > like I 
> > > should be
> > > happy that the music I love is finally popular in my city.
> > On the other
> > > hand, the minimal boom has killed the local techno scene
> > that used to 
> > > exist.
> > > Funny, we used to bitch about how none of us ever got
> > booked because 
> > > there
> > > were no techno parties, nowhere for us to play - now there
> > are more 
> > > techno
> > > parties than you can count, laptop DJs and minimal club
> > nights are a 
> > > dime a
> > > dozen, but my American passport doesn't really help me get
> > gigs in my
> > > European-headliner-obsessed city. (A friend of mine here in
> > Berlin 
> > > suggested
> > > I re-import myself - move to Europe and then get booked to
> > play in San
> > > Francisco. Ha.) I've heard people complain about local
> > techno folks 
> > > moving
> > > to Berlin.... "Another local producer moved to Berlin. They
> > keep 
> > > leaving,
> > > one after another!"  As if techno producers moving to
> > Berlin are 
> > > giving up,
> > > quitters, going AWOL. But they're smart.  There's a reason
> > why we're 
> > > all
> > > leaving. San Francisco's party scene (or rather, promoter
> > scene) does 
> > > not
> > > support local producers, period. Nope. Does not. Why should
> > we stay 
> > > here?
> > > To support the local scene or whatever?  What's the point
> > of staying 
> > > when
> > > the scene does not support us? We're just here to take your
> > flyers, 
> > > help you
> > > reach your bar minimum for the night, believe your hype,
> > and be pawns. 
> > > Maybe
> > > we won't get booked in Berlin either, but at least in
> > Berlin there is 
> > > better
> > > music and more efficient public transportation!
> > >
> > > There is TONS of interest in techno in San Francisco right
> > now, and 
> > > this is
> > > a great time to start something (well, I've been saying
> > that for a long
> > > time, but now is really a good time I think).  So, I
> > conclude, here 
> > > are a
> > > couple things we need to get over in order to elevate our
> > music scene-
> > >
> > > -Kill the headliner/residents formula, or party formulas in
> > general. 
> > > Try
> > > something different. There are all kinds of different
> > parties here in
> > > Berlin, with out of town headliners, locals, DJs, live
> > pa's, laptops,
> > > hardware, vinyl, etc. Parties happen in all types of venues
> > too, not 
> > > the
> > > same club each time. (My favorite example is Reclaim the
> > Sparkasse, 
> > > renegade
> > > parties that are held in the front room of banks, where the
> > ATMs are.)
> > >
> > > -Be yourself, be original, create something.  Sorry, I
> > know, this is 
> > > tired
> > > advice that you've been hearing from your mom and athletic
> > shoe 
> > > commercials
> > > since you were born, but it's still the truest thing ever. 
> > Forget 
> > > about the
> > > top 10 on Beatport, and just do your thing.
> > >
> > > I could go on, but I don't want to rant and nag too much. 
> > You catch my
> > > drift.  I don't usually post long, opinionated rants on
> > SFR, for fear 
> > > of
> > > being shit on and looked down upon, but I feel like I don't
> > have much 
> > > to
> > > lose.
> > >
> > > Oh no.  I truly am one of you now.  It happened. I am
> > jaded.
> > >
> > >
> > > Love Chelsea
> > > reporting from Berlin
> > > <3
> > >
> > > More Berlin reports to come, if you guys are interested.
> > 
> > 
> >
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> > To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> > For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
> > 
> >

Message-ID: <347df33a0712280850w7a85beddja7c4a584ee7bd695@mail.gmail.com>

From: filter.sf@gmail.com
To: SFR <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; 
	boundary="----=_Part_8455_23539395.1198860634437"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] Detroit Techno tonight at Anu with Fanon Flowers [live pa]

------=_Part_8455_23539395.1198860634437
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

For those who enjoy a more pure percussive techno sound, you won't want to
miss Fanon Flowers tonight at Anu.

 With a history of solid techno productions dating back to 1992 and a 2000
DEMF performance to his credit, Detroit native Fanon Flowers is credited for
being part of Detroit's 3rd wave of techno. Though not a household name in
techno like compadres Claude Young and Jeff Mills, Flowers' imprints have
made their way into the record bags of long-time Detroit techno followers,
and into the sets of influencial producers such as Adam Beyer and Surgeon. .


Recently, Flowers moved from Detroit to Los Angeles, where he's working on
another label project, based on the sounds of Berlin and Detroit, which aims
to move the classic sound forward.

His live PA, which debuts in SF tonight, will surely be an indication of
things to come for West Coast techno.


friday: dec. 28 ::07

Filter.SF presents::

F A N O N F L O W E R S [ live pa ]

[Mechanical Industries, Nheoma, Dumb, Detroit]

with filter residents:

::solekandi [filter.sf] ::
::saya [filter.sf] ::

anu-bar
46 sixth street, S.F
10 pm till 2 am
$5

Flyer here: i5.tinypic.com/6phlopd.jpg


-- 

www.myspace.com/filtersf

------=_Part_8455_23539395.1198860634437--

From sfraves-return-143637-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Dec 28 16:56:35 2007

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 42192 invoked by uid 1103); 28 Dec 2007 16:56:33 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

----- Original Message ----- 
From: <dangrsmind@yahoo.com>
To: "U bitch" <dj.import@hotmail.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, December 27, 2007 12:31 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] goa trance


U Bitch aka DJ Import aka Chris wrote;

"Do you think google is really the place to find underground music?"

Yes.  Using a search engine is certainly one good way to find non-commercial 
and underground music.

However I note that previously on sfraves Chris opined: "What is the real 
difference between commercial music and underground music?"

You see oh clueless one, generally underground music actually requires some 
effort on the part of the listener to locate, obtain, and enjoy said music. 
It is supposed to be challenging.  There are lots of reasons for this, it is 
not merely elitism as I expect you believe.  Commercial music is designed to 
sell and that means it has to be easily accessible to a wide audience. 
Sales are not the primary purpose of undergound music therefore neither is 
accesibility.  But that's all changed now with the Internet.  We can get 
underground music almost as weasily as commercial music.  Unless you happen 
to be a Google retard of course.

Hint: use Google to find places that have mixes you like and/or links to 
them.

For example in this genre I found http://www.psypix.org 
http://www.psynews.org  and http://www.tranceaddict.com all had Goa mixes 
available.

e.g. I found a live set from Magic Dave which I enjoyed.  I downloaded a few 
other sets which I haven't listened to yet.  I found so many Goa mixes in 
fact, that I haven't had time to download or listen to them all.  i probably 
never will.

Why don't you post links to mixes you liked yourself instead of the usual 
mindless trolling?  Of course that would imply you are actually interested 
in music rather than just being an annoyance here.

Which is it?  I think I know the answer.

Peter

A majority of the older goa isn't being released anymore. I recommend
signing up on discogs.com and trading/buying music on there; you'll be able
to find a lot of the classic stuff. Just don't bite more than you can chew;
the higher levels of record collecting are comparable to a crack addiction.

On Sun, Dec 30, 2007 at 07:54:30AM -0800, dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
>Tracing an email address to Hotmail isn't very informative.

The computer he's using is in likely Oakland and he likely uses Comcast
as his ISP. This assertion is based on the IP adress in the
X-Originating-IP header in his mails, which is 24.23.224.165.
Other conclusions are based on data returned by using whois and traceroute.

Hotmail, Gmail, and others usually use a mail header such as this
to track abuse. If one doesn't use a proxy, then one leaks this
information on each email sent.

Note that this header hasn't changed on any of the 18 or so posts
he's made to the list.

My take is he's a person (troll?!) who's listserv experience is low,
has maybe been to a few of the undergrounds in Oakland, is new to the
scene, and has annoyed more than a few people on the list. Maybe he's a
narc or an informant, but I doubt it, since pissing off people is counter
to gaining people's trust, which a narc or an informant needs.

Re: events being posted to sfraves, most of the undergrounds I've
been to aren't posted here anyway.

--

Peter

IP ban (if it's possible). But honestly, it's probably easier to avoid
feeding the troll. Although, we can't conclude that he is one; I've seen a
lot of kids try to find out (or at least act like) they know everything
about the party scene after their first shindig. Although such a situation
seems less of a problem in the bay, it is more visible in the socal scene
were the crowds are much younger. For instance, I used to go to this forum
called ravelinks, and a trolling situation like this was common. Most of the
time the culprit was just a naive kid, rather than a malignant troll.

Date: Sun, 30 Dec 2007 22:40:10 +0100
From: "Chelsea Faith" <chelcfaith@gmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; 
	boundary="----=_Part_14837_25831510.1199050810546"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] A Berlin Story.

------=_Part_14837_25831510.1199050810546
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Disposition: inline

Hello again friends. Thought I would share my Saturday night report, live
and direct from East Berlin. Osby isn't the only one who can share stories
of Saturday night debauchery here...

On Saturday, I met up with some friends at my friend Martin's record shop i=
n
Friedrichshain. We drank champagne and listened to some records
before walking down Revalerstra=DFe to a club called Rosi's.  This place is=
 so
typically Friedrichshain - A big, one-story brick building, placed off the
street, behind a wall, with a crumbling facade and an equally rough
interior. It seems to me that having a hole in the floor or in the wall is =
a
standard feature for clubs on the East side of town. There was a big patio
area outside, which I'm sure must be a blast in the Summer, when they have =
a
soundsystem set up out there. Tonight there was no soundsystem on the patio=
,
it was quite cold, but the outdoor grill was open and people were standing
in line to get themselves a bratwurst and a beer.

Inside, the place looked much like an oldschool Oakland warehouse space,
decked out with crazy projections everywhere and those trance-inducing LED
bricks that can light a room any color of the rainbow. Tall ceilings, brick
walls, cement floors, and lots of little secret hang out rooms behind beade=
d
curtains. At midnight, the place was still completely empty, as parties her=
e
don't really get going until after 2am.  I sat with my friends in some old
movie theater seats up against the wall. The music was typical Berlin techn=
o
early in the night - Minimal, touching on melodic, but still dark and
driving.

By 2am the place was packed, and we went to check out an acquaintance who
was DJing in the smaller room.  This room was totally reminiscent of the
Dungeon, having low ceilings with that yucky ceiling tile stuff that you
find in office buildings. The DJ was playing sparse, glitchy,
electro-influenced tech-house, which I was told is being called Fidget Hous=
e
these days. I've heard the term here and there, but didn't really know what
it was. Sort of a more techy offshoot of electro-house, from my perspective=
,
though I only heard this music once, so I am not an expert on the subject.

We weren't really that into the music, so we decided this:  If we heard
either RUOK, or Heater (that god-awful minimal track with the accordion in
it), we would leave. It was kind of a joke, kind of not. Talking about
these, my least favorite current minimal anthems, reminded me of my previou=
s
night out, at a club called Zur M=F6belfabrik, in Mitte. This place is anot=
her
typical East Berlin club - A former furniture factory, found below street
level, with lots of brick and cement, and of course the obligatory holes in
the wall. I told my friend about my surprise when I heard the DJ playing
Marc Houle's "Techno Vocals," a track I saw as a novelty record and didn't
really take seriously. (In case you're not familiar, the track is a parody
of the trend in minimal techno to make tracks with these really pitched-dow=
n
vocals in them. The refrain goes "Why are all the vocals pitched down so
low? This is the way we make techno!"  Yeah, funny. See here:
http://www.discogs.com/release/1075727)  I was genuinely surprised to hear =
a
DJ playing it at a real techno club, this record is such a piece of shit,
really. A shitty parody of some other shitty tracks, something that will
have little to no relevance a year from now.  So, just as I'm finishing
telling him this, the DJ starts to mix in the next record, and I hear "Why
are all the vocals pitched down so low, low, low?"  I totally jumped out of
my seat with surprise, laughing. It cracked me up. I couldn't help but
exclaim, "I can't believe he's playing this shit!!" Hilarious.

So, the verdict was that the music wasn't really doing it for us, so the tw=
o
of us that remained from our party walked out to grab a falafel and hit the
next club.  We walked through the outskirts of F'hain, in a quieter and mor=
e
industrial part of town. The first club we reached was closed, so we walked
on to the the Plan B club, which was also closed. It was about 5am, and I
was ready to go home, so it was ok with me. The two of us began to walk
towards Warschauerstra=DFe to catch a train home, when this guy comes up to=
 us
as asks if the party is around here. Neither of us knew what he was talking
about, but as we stopped walking and listened for a moment, we heard that
familiar sound coming from the next block: "wmmph-wmmph-wmmph-wmmph".  We
walked over to this run-down building covered in scaffolding.  It looked
abandoned and empty. A couple of street punks were sitting outside, smoking
cigarettes. The front door was unlocked, so we walked in. We went up severa=
l
flights of stairs, to the top floor, where much to my surprise, was this
amazing underground loft party. What luck! The place looked a lot like
Overworld in Oakland, for those of you who remember that space - an open,
dark, dirty loft. There were lots of TVs stuck up in the rafters, with live
visuals, and projections of circuit diagrams all over the walls. Hammocks
were strung up here and there, and there were lots of different chill areas
with benches, futons, chairs, etc. This was the first place I have ever see=
n
in Berlin with blacklights - it felt like home! I sat down on a park bench
with a beer in my hand and rested my feet on a broken wood box covered in
bottles. The coat check consisted of a row of nails on one of the rafters,
where a line of long black coats and scarves were hanging. At the bar they
were serving cheap German beer and afri-cola with jaegermeister. The way th=
e
place was set up, with all the projectors, TVs, netting, lighting,
soundsystem, and such, it appeared that this was a regular party spot, not
just a one-off thing.

I went over to the the dancefloor to check out what was happening, I had
heard a few people say that the "Ha-pa-na" was really going off, so I wante=
d
to find out what this was.  A Japanese guy was playing a live p.a. set of
stripped down, hard, heady, minimal techno. It was the real shit! Not any o=
f
this clubby minimal tech-house stuff, this was pure techno. Gorgeous.

The people here were peaceful, respectful, fun, and open, the way it should
be.  Berlin can be a little intimidating at first, because some parts of th=
e
club scene are very exclusive. I was shocked coming here for the first time
in 2002, when I had to be 'picked' to get into the first club I went to -
this was contrary to everything I knew about dance music events. We're all =
a
family, and everyone is welcome, right...?  We're united by music, dancing
together as one, aren't we...? Not always so.  So I was a little bummed out=
,
thinking Berlin wouldn't open its arms to a freaky hippie raver girl from
San Francisco. But, here, as in many cities, if you dig deep enough, you ca=
n
find the beating heart of the underground. Here at this loft party, I could
talk to anyone, everyone was kind, no fights, no drunken outbursts, no
creepy guys hitting on me, just a bunch of good people having fun and being
free.  Totally brought me back to my early days of raving. What a fantastic
party!

I left as the sun was coming up, and caught the train back to my flat,
watching the last stars burn out from the sky. What a great night!

That's all for now.  I hope all of you have a fantastic New Year's Eve!


Love Chelsea
reporting from Berlin, city of joyous techno and delicious falafel.

------=_Part_14837_25831510.1199050810546--

Subject: [sfraves] Oooh.. Thursday Thristy Evening Night Adventure kinda

So Thursday Afternoon, I met up w/ Maz in Berk to go hitch a ride to his
pad... he's doing this Tech House Live PA over in Diego for New Years @
this "Techno Circus" party & he needed me to sing the "Party IN My Pants"
song.. like lay the vocals & stuff... so i did.. like it went faily quick
& I admit... i shoulda been more vocally animated then i was.. but it was
good... we did good work.. i sang what i did & I'm happy withthe turn
out... if you wanna hear the song... send me a private & I'll hook you up
:)  Oooh Yum & John Spartan G.. if you reading this... Thank U Sir for the
Yummy Bacon Double Cheese Burger!!!  I <3 U 4 that man!!!  Oh yeah.. there
was also a dog who was tryin' to eat my shoe there....

Anywaze... so i went to ummmm... that bar.. not Arrow Bar no more... & I
wanted to check out the New Thristy Monthly that the Girls were
throwin'... :)  It was fun... i got to kick it w/ Denise, Amber, Sam
wasn't there yet, & ummmm.. that new DJ Girl ummmm... what's her name...
well, Denise's GF.. she was the 1st DJ up & she dropped TECHNO!!!  I
mean.. I'm just sayin'.. as long as i known Denise... i never associated
Techno w/ her.. so it was kinda surreal.. 'cause D was always NRG & then
House...

BUt i kicked it w/ Amber alot & we had out monthly catch up conversation
'cause i been flakin' on our weeklie, bi weeklie catch up phone convos...
so that was Dope... btw... Amber's sellin' some of her vinyl if anyone's
interested...

I left early... around 10:30ish 'cause I was still tired after like Family
Holiday stuff... so i had to leave..i really wanted to go to
Compression... but uuugh.. i'm so lame.. i just felt like i need to be
home & chill off the gypsy raver adventures atleast until new years day/
morning :)
-- 
Take Care <3

From sfraves-return-143673-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Dec 31 02:10:32 2007

From sfraves-return-143675-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Dec 31 02:25:21 2007

Chelsea Faith wrote:
> Hello again friends. Thought I would share my Saturday night report, live
> and direct from East Berlin. Osby isn't the only one who can share stories
> of Saturday night debauchery here...
>
> On Saturday, I met up with some friends at my friend Martin's record shop
> in
> Friedrichshain. We drank champagne and listened to some records
> before walking down Revalerstraße to a club called Rosi's.  This place is
> so
> typically Friedrichshain - A big, one-story brick building, placed off the
> street, behind a wall, with a crumbling facade and an equally rough
> interior. It seems to me that having a hole in the floor or in the wall is
> a
> standard feature for clubs on the East side of town. There was a big patio
> area outside, which I'm sure must be a blast in the Summer, when they have
> a
> soundsystem set up out there. Tonight there was no soundsystem on the
> patio,
> it was quite cold, but the outdoor grill was open and people were standing
> in line to get themselves a bratwurst and a beer.
>
> Inside, the place looked much like an oldschool Oakland warehouse space,
> decked out with crazy projections everywhere and those trance-inducing LED
> bricks that can light a room any color of the rainbow. Tall ceilings,
> brick
> walls, cement floors, and lots of little secret hang out rooms behind
> beaded
> curtains. At midnight, the place was still completely empty, as parties
> here
> don't really get going until after 2am.  I sat with my friends in some old
> movie theater seats up against the wall. The music was typical Berlin
> techno
> early in the night - Minimal, touching on melodic, but still dark and
> driving.
>
> By 2am the place was packed, and we went to check out an acquaintance who
> was DJing in the smaller room.  This room was totally reminiscent of the
> Dungeon, having low ceilings with that yucky ceiling tile stuff that you
> find in office buildings. The DJ was playing sparse, glitchy,
> electro-influenced tech-house, which I was told is being called Fidget
> House
> these days. I've heard the term here and there, but didn't really know
> what
> it was. Sort of a more techy offshoot of electro-house, from my
> perspective,
> though I only heard this music once, so I am not an expert on the subject.
>
> We weren't really that into the music, so we decided this:  If we heard
> either RUOK, or Heater (that god-awful minimal track with the accordion in
> it), we would leave. It was kind of a joke, kind of not. Talking about
> these, my least favorite current minimal anthems, reminded me of my
> previous
> night out, at a club called Zur Möbelfabrik, in Mitte. This place is
> another
> typical East Berlin club - A former furniture factory, found below street
> level, with lots of brick and cement, and of course the obligatory holes
> in
> the wall. I told my friend about my surprise when I heard the DJ playing
> Marc Houle's "Techno Vocals," a track I saw as a novelty record and didn't
> really take seriously. (In case you're not familiar, the track is a parody
> of the trend in minimal techno to make tracks with these really
> pitched-down
> vocals in them. The refrain goes "Why are all the vocals pitched down so
> low? This is the way we make techno!"  Yeah, funny. See here:
> http://www.discogs.com/release/1075727)  I was genuinely surprised to hear
> a
> DJ playing it at a real techno club, this record is such a piece of shit,
> really. A shitty parody of some other shitty tracks, something that will
> have little to no relevance a year from now.  So, just as I'm finishing
> telling him this, the DJ starts to mix in the next record, and I hear "Why
> are all the vocals pitched down so low, low, low?"  I totally jumped out
> of
> my seat with surprise, laughing. It cracked me up. I couldn't help but
> exclaim, "I can't believe he's playing this shit!!" Hilarious.
>
> So, the verdict was that the music wasn't really doing it for us, so the
> two
> of us that remained from our party walked out to grab a falafel and hit
> the
> next club.  We walked through the outskirts of F'hain, in a quieter and
> more
> industrial part of town. The first club we reached was closed, so we
> walked
> on to the the Plan B club, which was also closed. It was about 5am, and I
> was ready to go home, so it was ok with me. The two of us began to walk
> towards Warschauerstraße to catch a train home, when this guy comes up to
> us
> as asks if the party is around here. Neither of us knew what he was
> talking
> about, but as we stopped walking and listened for a moment, we heard that
> familiar sound coming from the next block: "wmmph-wmmph-wmmph-wmmph".  We
> walked over to this run-down building covered in scaffolding.  It looked
> abandoned and empty. A couple of street punks were sitting outside,
> smoking
> cigarettes. The front door was unlocked, so we walked in. We went up
> several
> flights of stairs, to the top floor, where much to my surprise, was this
> amazing underground loft party. What luck! The place looked a lot like
> Overworld in Oakland, for those of you who remember that space - an open,
> dark, dirty loft. There were lots of TVs stuck up in the rafters, with
> live
> visuals, and projections of circuit diagrams all over the walls. Hammocks
> were strung up here and there, and there were lots of different chill
> areas
> with benches, futons, chairs, etc. This was the first place I have ever
> seen
> in Berlin with blacklights - it felt like home! I sat down on a park bench
> with a beer in my hand and rested my feet on a broken wood box covered in
> bottles. The coat check consisted of a row of nails on one of the rafters,
> where a line of long black coats and scarves were hanging. At the bar they
> were serving cheap German beer and afri-cola with jaegermeister. The way
> the
> place was set up, with all the projectors, TVs, netting, lighting,
> soundsystem, and such, it appeared that this was a regular party spot, not
> just a one-off thing.
>
> I went over to the the dancefloor to check out what was happening, I had
> heard a few people say that the "Ha-pa-na" was really going off, so I
> wanted
> to find out what this was.  A Japanese guy was playing a live p.a. set of
> stripped down, hard, heady, minimal techno. It was the real shit! Not any
> of
> this clubby minimal tech-house stuff, this was pure techno. Gorgeous.
>
> The people here were peaceful, respectful, fun, and open, the way it
> should
> be.  Berlin can be a little intimidating at first, because some parts of
> the
> club scene are very exclusive. I was shocked coming here for the first
> time
> in 2002, when I had to be 'picked' to get into the first club I went to -
> this was contrary to everything I knew about dance music events. We're all
> a
> family, and everyone is welcome, right...?  We're united by music, dancing
> together as one, aren't we...? Not always so.  So I was a little bummed
> out,
> thinking Berlin wouldn't open its arms to a freaky hippie raver girl from
> San Francisco. But, here, as in many cities, if you dig deep enough, you
> can
> find the beating heart of the underground. Here at this loft party, I
> could
> talk to anyone, everyone was kind, no fights, no drunken outbursts, no
> creepy guys hitting on me, just a bunch of good people having fun and
> being
> free.  Totally brought me back to my early days of raving. What a
> fantastic
> party!
>
> I left as the sun was coming up, and caught the train back to my flat,
> watching the last stars burn out from the sky. What a great night!
>
> That's all for now.  I hope all of you have a fantastic New Year's Eve!
>
>
> Love Chelsea
> reporting from Berlin, city of joyous techno and delicious falafel.
>


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Oh.. Happy HArdcore Bday Apollo

Haha... yeah.  Just to give him the benefit of the doubt;  I'll remind  
everyone that when *I* first started posting to the list, I knew so  
little, and asked so many damn stupid questions, and was an arrogant  
dot-commer who still thought there was nothing, including the rave  
scene, that I couldn't master with a couple of overnighters...

... that something like my second post here EVER, I accidently touched  
off a vinyl vs. digital format flamewar that got so big that Brian B  
got involved!  Whoopsie.

Now, I'm a jaded and overly-opinionated ass who probably does bring up  
the negative too often when I should be looking for the positive.  But  
for all the ass-hattery I've made of myself over the years, I've never  
been trolling; just sharing honest opinions in a sometimes tactless  
manner.


cya,
john

Date: Mon, 31 Dec 2007 15:16:59 -0800 (PST)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: dangrsmind@yahoo.com
cc: Chelsea Faith <chelcfaith@gmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <711594.522.qm@web32408.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.62.0712311413450.16217@atari>
References: <711594.522.qm@web32408.mail.mud.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] A report from late 2007-era Berlin, plus my musings
 (rant) on why SF is not Berlin.


On Thu, 27 Dec 2007 dangrsmind@yahoo.com wrote:
-&e->I loved this posting Chelsea and hope to hear more reports from Berlin.  
-&e->
-&e->One thing I found interesting is contrasting your description of the 
-&e->local techno scene, "There is no SF techno sound" with the late 
-&e->nineties house scene.  There definitely was/is a unique SF house 
-&e->sound, but still many of the same issues with imported headliners, 
-&e->closed lineups, little innovation party-wise, and often just boring 
-&e->music.  IMO anyhow.

There very definitely *was* a SF techno sound.  Or more correctly, sounds.  
Kit Clayton, Twerk, Sutehk laid the foundation for a lot of what minimal 
eventually became.  Around the same time, San Jose's techno sound was 
driving dancefloors with a percussion driven, rarely distorted hybrid of 
what the Advent were doing but very much with their own sound and approach 
(namely in the approach to bassline and the often crazed past-latin amount 
of swing on the drum patterns)... and EBE (also from San Jose) was hitting 
massive critical and popular acclaim spearheading a new sound that blew up 
called tech house.  I had friends with releases on Mille Plateux and Force 
(landmark miminal labels), Planet Rhythm (*the* og swedish tech label), 
and Sonic Groove (NYC's original shack shaking dirty techno label).

I do however totally support that there is a MASSIVE disconnect between 
booking and talent in this town, and that even with releases on good 
labels, magazine coverage, and people in NYC, Chicago, Tokyo, Berlin, 
London, etc that love your shit from first listen, SF is and always has 
been a weird place for techno.

Your jaded dj/producer/live pa/club + one off promoter/sound system,
andyw

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  In the Fight Over Piracy, a Rare Stand for Privacy By ADAM LIPTAK


>From today's NY Times..

In the Fight Over Piracy, a Rare Stand for Privacy By ADAM LIPTAK

Published: December 31, 2007

The record industry got a surprise when it subpoenaed the University of
Oregon in September, asking it to identify 17 students who had made
available songs from Journey, the Cars, Dire Straits, Sting and Madonna =
on a
file-sharing network. The surprise was not that 20-year-olds listen to
Sting. It was that the university fought back.

Represented by the state's attorney general, Hardy Myers, the university
filed a blistering motion to quash the subpoena, accusing the industry =
of
misleading the judge, violating student privacy laws and engaging in
questionable investigative practices. Cary Sherman, the president of the
Recording Industry Association of America, said the industry had seen "a =
lot
of crazy stuff" filed in response to its lawsuits and subpoenas. "But =
coming
from the office of an attorney general of a state?" Mr. Sherman asked,
incredulous. "We found it really surprising and disappointing."

No one should shed tears for people who steal music and have to face the
consequences. But it is nonetheless heartening to see a university =
decline
to become the industry's police officer and instead to defend the =
privacy of
its students.

The recording industry may not be selling as much music these days, but =
it
has built a pretty impressive and innovative litigation subsidiary.

In the past four years, record companies have sued tens of thousands of
people for violating the copyright laws by sharing music on the =
Internet.=20
The people it sues tend to settle, paying the industry a few thousand
dollars rather than risking a potentially ruinous judgment by fighting =
in
court.

"People get pushed into settlements," said Fred von Lohmann, a lawyer =
with
the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a civil liberties group. "The Oregon
attorney general is showing what a real fight among equals would look =
like."

In his filings, Mr. Myers claimed to be looking for a middle ground.

"Certainly it is appropriate for victims of copyright infringement to
lawfully pursue statutory remedies," Mr. Myers wrote last month. =
"However,
that pursuit must be tempered by basic notions of privacy and due =
process."

"The larger issue," Mr. Myers said, "is whether plaintiffs' =
investigative
and litigation strategies are appropriate."

Mr. Myers questioned the tactics of MediaSentry, an investigative =
company
hired by the recording industry. He said the company seemed to use data
mining techniques to obtain "private, confidential information unrelated =
to
copyright infringement." He added that it may have violated an Oregon
criminal law requiring investigators to be licensed.

A spokeswoman for MediaSentry said it collected only information that =
users
of peer-to-peer networks make available to anyone who cared to look. She =
had
no comment on the licensing law.

The record companies, in an apoplectic response in court, accused the
university of having "a political agenda." They said that it was =
protecting
people who had broken the law and that it was not entitled to raise =
privacy
and due process arguments on behalf of its students.

"Hundreds of universities and dozens of commercial Internet service
providers have responded to the exact same subpoenas," the record =
companies'

lawyers wrote.

James Gibson, a law professor at the University of Richmond, said Mr.
Myers's arguments had been raised in other cases and had met with little
success.=20
Still, Professor Gibson said, "it's significant that a public university =
and
its state apparatus is standing up to the R.I.A.A."

Mr. Sherman, of the recording industry association, predicted that Mr.
Myers's motion would fail and said the industry's litigation strategy =
had
worked well.

"The litigation program, as controversial as it is often written up to =
be,
has been very successful in transforming public awareness," Mr. Sherman
said. "Everybody used to think this was legal. Now everybody knows it's
illegal."

Indeed, the program seems to be expanding, and universities are being =
asked
to play an even bigger role. In February, the association started asking
universities to identify students suspected of file sharing and to pass
along "prelitigation letters" to them. The association says it has =
provided
some 4,000 such letters to more than 150 colleges and universities. The
letters offer the students what they call bargain settlements of about
$3,000 if they act fast, by punching in a credit card number at
www.p2plawsuits.com.

"The 'reduced' settlement amount, in other words, represents the record
companies' savings from cutting out the middleman - our justice system," =
the
Electronic Frontier Foundation said in a recent report.

The universities are under no legal obligation to pass the letters =
along,
but most do. Those that don't typically receive subpoenas like the one
issued to the University of Oregon.

At least one other public university in Oregon has cooperated with the
industry. In 2004, Portland State responded to a record industry =
subpoena by
blandly and efficiently providing the names, addresses, phone numbers =
and
goofy e-mail addresses of two roommates. The university said it could =
not
say which student's computer was involved, so it fingered both of them.

"We definitely felt betrayed," said Karen Conway, the mother of one of =
the
roommates. "They readily turned over private information without =
notifying
us. They placed responding to a legal subpoena far above a student's =
right
to privacy."

Though her daughter Delaney was blameless, the record companies' lawyers
demanded $4,500. It was, Ms. Conway said, "basically extortion," and the
family was forced to hire a lawyer. The case against Delaney Conway was
eventually dropped. Her roommate settled.

Mr. Sherman said the University of Oregon should disclose what it knew =
and
let the legal system sort out the rest. "It's no different than us
subpoenaing Verizon," he said.

But an institution of higher education has different aspirations and
obligations than an Internet service provider, which is why Portland =
State's
actions are so unsettling. The University of Oregon's efforts may be =
doomed,
but there is something bracing about them nonetheless.

All the university is saying, after all, is that the record industry =
must
make its case in court before the university will point a finger at one =
of
its own.

"No wonder kids grow up crazy," the midget says. "A cat's cradle is =
nothing
but a bunch of X's between somebody's hands, and little kids look and =
look
and look at all those X's..."
"And?"
"No damn cat, and no damn cradle."
-Kurt Vonnegut

Record review of the year ::::


Samim - Heater <http://www.residentadvisor.net/review-view.aspx?id=3D4721> =
[Get
Physical <http://www.residentadvisor.net/record-label.aspx?id=3D403>]

[image: 23 - Samim - Heater]
Video: Samim =96 Heater <http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DNZ806mlFoMY>
"This is the one with the accordion in it. It's being played at every party
you go to and it's causing a bit of a stink because accordions are not
exactly techno, are they? It's also got a man making monkey noises on it,
and it's really catchy, which means that now that everyone is playing it,
it's going to start annoying the shit out of people very, very soon. A bit
like 'Geht's Noch?' or 'Erotic Discourse' did. But to be fair, I promised I
wouldn't write this review until I'd heard 'Heater' out. Unfortunately, I
got my chance in Berlin, where the track had the awkward effect of making
all the white people in the room suddenly dance *whiter*. Club Weekend
turned into an old worlde barn dance, with woodcutters jigging with
milkmaids for six minutes. Hmm. Overall then, 'Heater' is a fun little
listen, but dancing to it makes you feel like an idiot." =96 Jeremy Armitag=
e
