>
> Chelsea Faith wrote:
> > Hello again friends. Thought I would share my Saturday night report,
> live
> > and direct from East Berlin. Osby isn't the only one who can share
> stories
> > of Saturday night debauchery here...
> >
> > On Saturday, I met up with some friends at my friend Martin's record
> shop
> > in
> > Friedrichshain. We drank champagne and listened to some records
> > before walking down Revalerstra=DFe to a club called Rosi's.  This plac=
e
> is
> > so
> > typically Friedrichshain - A big, one-story brick building, placed off
> the
> > street, behind a wall, with a crumbling facade and an equally rough
> > interior. It seems to me that having a hole in the floor or in the wall
> is
> > a
> > standard feature for clubs on the East side of town. There was a big
> patio
> > area outside, which I'm sure must be a blast in the Summer, when they
> have
> > a
> > soundsystem set up out there. Tonight there was no soundsystem on the
> > patio,
> > it was quite cold, but the outdoor grill was open and people were
> standing
> > in line to get themselves a bratwurst and a beer.
> >
> > Inside, the place looked much like an oldschool Oakland warehouse space=
,
> > decked out with crazy projections everywhere and those trance-inducing
> LED
> > bricks that can light a room any color of the rainbow. Tall ceilings,
> > brick
> > walls, cement floors, and lots of little secret hang out rooms behind
> > beaded
> > curtains. At midnight, the place was still completely empty, as parties
> > here
> > don't really get going until after 2am.  I sat with my friends in some
> old
> > movie theater seats up against the wall. The music was typical Berlin
> > techno
> > early in the night - Minimal, touching on melodic, but still dark and
> > driving.
> >
> > By 2am the place was packed, and we went to check out an acquaintance
> who
> > was DJing in the smaller room.  This room was totally reminiscent of th=
e
> > Dungeon, having low ceilings with that yucky ceiling tile stuff that yo=
u
> > find in office buildings. The DJ was playing sparse, glitchy,
> > electro-influenced tech-house, which I was told is being called Fidget
> > House
> > these days. I've heard the term here and there, but didn't really know
> > what
> > it was. Sort of a more techy offshoot of electro-house, from my
> > perspective,
> > though I only heard this music once, so I am not an expert on the
> subject.
> >
> > We weren't really that into the music, so we decided this:  If we heard
> > either RUOK, or Heater (that god-awful minimal track with the accordion
> in
> > it), we would leave. It was kind of a joke, kind of not. Talking about
> > these, my least favorite current minimal anthems, reminded me of my
> > previous
> > night out, at a club called Zur M=F6belfabrik, in Mitte. This place is
> > another
> > typical East Berlin club - A former furniture factory, found below
> street
> > level, with lots of brick and cement, and of course the obligatory hole=
s
> > in
> > the wall. I told my friend about my surprise when I heard the DJ playin=
g
> > Marc Houle's "Techno Vocals," a track I saw as a novelty record and
> didn't
> > really take seriously. (In case you're not familiar, the track is a
> parody
> > of the trend in minimal techno to make tracks with these really
> > pitched-down
> > vocals in them. The refrain goes "Why are all the vocals pitched down s=
o
> > low? This is the way we make techno!"  Yeah, funny. See here:
> > http://www.discogs.com/release/1075727)  I was genuinely surprised to
> hear
> > a
> > DJ playing it at a real techno club, this record is such a piece of
> shit,
> > really. A shitty parody of some other shitty tracks, something that wil=
l
> > have little to no relevance a year from now.  So, just as I'm finishing
> > telling him this, the DJ starts to mix in the next record, and I hear
> "Why
> > are all the vocals pitched down so low, low, low?"  I totally jumped ou=
t
> > of
> > my seat with surprise, laughing. It cracked me up. I couldn't help but
> > exclaim, "I can't believe he's playing this shit!!" Hilarious.
> >
> > So, the verdict was that the music wasn't really doing it for us, so th=
e
> > two
> > of us that remained from our party walked out to grab a falafel and hit
> > the
> > next club.  We walked through the outskirts of F'hain, in a quieter and
> > more
> > industrial part of town. The first club we reached was closed, so we
> > walked
> > on to the the Plan B club, which was also closed. It was about 5am, and
> I
> > was ready to go home, so it was ok with me. The two of us began to walk
> > towards Warschauerstra=DFe to catch a train home, when this guy comes u=
p
> to
> > us
> > as asks if the party is around here. Neither of us knew what he was
> > talking
> > about, but as we stopped walking and listened for a moment, we heard
> that
> > familiar sound coming from the next block:
> "wmmph-wmmph-wmmph-wmmph".  We
> > walked over to this run-down building covered in scaffolding.  It looke=
d
> > abandoned and empty. A couple of street punks were sitting outside,
> > smoking
> > cigarettes. The front door was unlocked, so we walked in. We went up
> > several
> > flights of stairs, to the top floor, where much to my surprise, was thi=
s
> > amazing underground loft party. What luck! The place looked a lot like
> > Overworld in Oakland, for those of you who remember that space - an
> open,
> > dark, dirty loft. There were lots of TVs stuck up in the rafters, with
> > live
> > visuals, and projections of circuit diagrams all over the walls.
> Hammocks
> > were strung up here and there, and there were lots of different chill
> > areas
> > with benches, futons, chairs, etc. This was the first place I have ever
> > seen
> > in Berlin with blacklights - it felt like home! I sat down on a park
> bench
> > with a beer in my hand and rested my feet on a broken wood box covered
> in
> > bottles. The coat check consisted of a row of nails on one of the
> rafters,
> > where a line of long black coats and scarves were hanging. At the bar
> they
> > were serving cheap German beer and afri-cola with jaegermeister. The wa=
y
> > the
> > place was set up, with all the projectors, TVs, netting, lighting,
> > soundsystem, and such, it appeared that this was a regular party spot,
> not
> > just a one-off thing.
> >
> > I went over to the the dancefloor to check out what was happening, I ha=
d
> > heard a few people say that the "Ha-pa-na" was really going off, so I
> > wanted
> > to find out what this was.  A Japanese guy was playing a live p.a. set
> of
> > stripped down, hard, heady, minimal techno. It was the real shit! Not
> any
> > of
> > this clubby minimal tech-house stuff, this was pure techno. Gorgeous.
> >
> > The people here were peaceful, respectful, fun, and open, the way it
> > should
> > be.  Berlin can be a little intimidating at first, because some parts o=
f
> > the
> > club scene are very exclusive. I was shocked coming here for the first
> > time
> > in 2002, when I had to be 'picked' to get into the first club I went to
> -
> > this was contrary to everything I knew about dance music events. We're
> all
> > a
> > family, and everyone is welcome, right...?  We're united by music,
> dancing
> > together as one, aren't we...? Not always so.  So I was a little bummed
> > out,
> > thinking Berlin wouldn't open its arms to a freaky hippie raver girl
> from
> > San Francisco. But, here, as in many cities, if you dig deep enough, yo=
u
> > can
> > find the beating heart of the underground. Here at this loft party, I
> > could
> > talk to anyone, everyone was kind, no fights, no drunken outbursts, no
> > creepy guys hitting on me, just a bunch of good people having fun and
> > being
> > free.  Totally brought me back to my early days of raving. What a
> > fantastic
> > party!
> >
> > I left as the sun was coming up, and caught the train back to my flat,
> > watching the last stars burn out from the sky. What a great night!
> >
> > That's all for now.  I hope all of you have a fantastic New Year's Eve!
> >
> >
> > Love Chelsea
> > reporting from Berlin, city of joyous techno and delicious falafel.
> >
>
>

On Dec 31, 2007 8:41 PM, <filter.sf@gmail.com> wrote:

> Record review of the year ::::
>
>
> Samim - Heater <http://www.residentadvisor.net/review-view.aspx?id=3D4721=
>
> [Get
> Physical <http://www.residentadvisor.net/record-label.aspx?id=3D403>]
>
> [image: 23 - Samim - Heater]
> Video: Samim =96 Heater <http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DNZ806mlFoMY>
> "This is the one with the accordion in it. It's being played at every
> party
> you go to and it's causing a bit of a stink because accordions are not
> exactly techno, are they? It's also got a man making monkey noises on it,
> and it's really catchy, which means that now that everyone is playing it,
> it's going to start annoying the shit out of people very, very soon. A bi=
t
> like 'Geht's Noch?' or 'Erotic Discourse' did. But to be fair, I promised
> I
> wouldn't write this review until I'd heard 'Heater' out. Unfortunately, I
> got my chance in Berlin, where the track had the awkward effect of making
> all the white people in the room suddenly dance *whiter*. Club Weekend
> turned into an old worlde barn dance, with woodcutters jigging with
> milkmaids for six minutes. Hmm. Overall then, 'Heater' is a fun little
> listen, but dancing to it makes you feel like an idiot." =96 Jeremy Armit=
age

> On 12/30/07, Osby Oi Oi Jamz <osby@viberation.com> wrote:
> >
> > OK... Chel-C.. YUMMY YUM YUM McYUMMERSON!!  I Love that!!!  OK.. Girl..

> form
> > where I'm at & Make my way there!!!  That was Awesome!!  Hello 2Day..
> i'm
> > so happy for you!!!  BIG FUCKIN UPS TO THE UNDERGROUND!!!  YAAAAY!@!!!
> > --
> > Take Care <3
> > Peace=3D->Jus' Me =3D-> O=A7bY {8O)
> >
> >
> >
> > Chelsea Faith wrote:
> > > Hello again friends. Thought I would share my Saturday night report,
> > live
> > > and direct from East Berlin. Osby isn't the only one who can share
> > stories
> > > of Saturday night debauchery here...
> > >
> > > On Saturday, I met up with some friends at my friend Martin's record
> > shop
> > > in
> > > Friedrichshain. We drank champagne and listened to some records
> > > before walking down Revalerstra=DFe to a club called Rosi's.  This pl=
ace
> > is
> > > so
> > > typically Friedrichshain - A big, one-story brick building, placed of=
f
> > the
> > > street, behind a wall, with a crumbling facade and an equally rough
> > > interior. It seems to me that having a hole in the floor or in the
> wall
> > is
> > > a
> > > standard feature for clubs on the East side of town. There was a big
> > patio
> > > area outside, which I'm sure must be a blast in the Summer, when they
> > have
> > > a
> > > soundsystem set up out there. Tonight there was no soundsystem on the
> > > patio,
> > > it was quite cold, but the outdoor grill was open and people were
> > standing
> > > in line to get themselves a bratwurst and a beer.
> > >
> > > Inside, the place looked much like an oldschool Oakland warehouse
> space,
> > > decked out with crazy projections everywhere and those trance-inducin=
g
> > LED
> > > bricks that can light a room any color of the rainbow. Tall ceilings,
> > > brick
> > > walls, cement floors, and lots of little secret hang out rooms behind
> > > beaded
> > > curtains. At midnight, the place was still completely empty, as
> parties
> > > here
> > > don't really get going until after 2am.  I sat with my friends in som=
e
> > old
> > > movie theater seats up against the wall. The music was typical Berlin
> > > techno
> > > early in the night - Minimal, touching on melodic, but still dark and
> > > driving.
> > >
> > > By 2am the place was packed, and we went to check out an acquaintance
> > who
> > > was DJing in the smaller room.  This room was totally reminiscent of
> the
> > > Dungeon, having low ceilings with that yucky ceiling tile stuff that
> you
> > > find in office buildings. The DJ was playing sparse, glitchy,
> > > electro-influenced tech-house, which I was told is being called Fidge=
t
> > > House
> > > these days. I've heard the term here and there, but didn't really kno=
w
> > > what
> > > it was. Sort of a more techy offshoot of electro-house, from my
> > > perspective,
> > > though I only heard this music once, so I am not an expert on the
> > subject.
> > >
> > > We weren't really that into the music, so we decided this:  If we
> heard
> > > either RUOK, or Heater (that god-awful minimal track with the
> accordion
> > in
> > > it), we would leave. It was kind of a joke, kind of not. Talking abou=
t
> > > these, my least favorite current minimal anthems, reminded me of my
> > > previous
> > > night out, at a club called Zur M=F6belfabrik, in Mitte. This place i=
s
> > > another
> > > typical East Berlin club - A former furniture factory, found below
> > street
> > > level, with lots of brick and cement, and of course the obligatory
> holes
> > > in
> > > the wall. I told my friend about my surprise when I heard the DJ
> playing
> > > Marc Houle's "Techno Vocals," a track I saw as a novelty record and
> > didn't
> > > really take seriously. (In case you're not familiar, the track is a
> > parody
> > > of the trend in minimal techno to make tracks with these really
> > > pitched-down
> > > vocals in them. The refrain goes "Why are all the vocals pitched down
> so
> > > low? This is the way we make techno!"  Yeah, funny. See here:
> > > http://www.discogs.com/release/1075727)  I was genuinely surprised to
> > hear
> > > a
> > > DJ playing it at a real techno club, this record is such a piece of
> > shit,
> > > really. A shitty parody of some other shitty tracks, something that
> will
> > > have little to no relevance a year from now.  So, just as I'm
> finishing
> > > telling him this, the DJ starts to mix in the next record, and I hear
> > "Why
> > > are all the vocals pitched down so low, low, low?"  I totally jumped
> out
> > > of
> > > my seat with surprise, laughing. It cracked me up. I couldn't help bu=
t
> > > exclaim, "I can't believe he's playing this shit!!" Hilarious.
> > >
> > > So, the verdict was that the music wasn't really doing it for us, so
> the
> > > two
> > > of us that remained from our party walked out to grab a falafel and
> hit
> > > the
> > > next club.  We walked through the outskirts of F'hain, in a quieter
> and
> > > more
> > > industrial part of town. The first club we reached was closed, so we
> > > walked
> > > on to the the Plan B club, which was also closed. It was about 5am,
> and
> > I
> > > was ready to go home, so it was ok with me. The two of us began to
> walk
> > > towards Warschauerstra=DFe to catch a train home, when this guy comes=
 up
> > to
> > > us
> > > as asks if the party is around here. Neither of us knew what he was
> > > talking
> > > about, but as we stopped walking and listened for a moment, we heard
> > that
> > > familiar sound coming from the next block:
> > "wmmph-wmmph-wmmph-wmmph".  We
> > > walked over to this run-down building covered in scaffolding.  It
> looked
> > > abandoned and empty. A couple of street punks were sitting outside,
> > > smoking
> > > cigarettes. The front door was unlocked, so we walked in. We went up
> > > several
> > > flights of stairs, to the top floor, where much to my surprise, was
> this
> > > amazing underground loft party. What luck! The place looked a lot lik=
e
> > > Overworld in Oakland, for those of you who remember that space - an
> > open,
> > > dark, dirty loft. There were lots of TVs stuck up in the rafters, wit=
h
> > > live
> > > visuals, and projections of circuit diagrams all over the walls.
> > Hammocks
> > > were strung up here and there, and there were lots of different chill
> > > areas
> > > with benches, futons, chairs, etc. This was the first place I have
> ever
> > > seen
> > > in Berlin with blacklights - it felt like home! I sat down on a park
> > bench
> > > with a beer in my hand and rested my feet on a broken wood box covere=
d
> > in
> > > bottles. The coat check consisted of a row of nails on one of the
> > rafters,
> > > where a line of long black coats and scarves were hanging. At the bar
> > they
> > > were serving cheap German beer and afri-cola with jaegermeister. The
> way
> > > the
> > > place was set up, with all the projectors, TVs, netting, lighting,
> > > soundsystem, and such, it appeared that this was a regular party spot=
,
> > not
> > > just a one-off thing.
> > >
> > > I went over to the the dancefloor to check out what was happening, I
> had
> > > heard a few people say that the "Ha-pa-na" was really going off, so I
> > > wanted
> > > to find out what this was.  A Japanese guy was playing a live p.a. se=
t
> > of
> > > stripped down, hard, heady, minimal techno. It was the real shit! Not
> > any
> > > of
> > > this clubby minimal tech-house stuff, this was pure techno. Gorgeous.
> > >
> > > The people here were peaceful, respectful, fun, and open, the way it
> > > should
> > > be.  Berlin can be a little intimidating at first, because some parts
> of
> > > the
> > > club scene are very exclusive. I was shocked coming here for the firs=
t
> > > time
> > > in 2002, when I had to be 'picked' to get into the first club I went
> to
> > -
> > > this was contrary to everything I knew about dance music events. We'r=
e
> > all
> > > a
> > > family, and everyone is welcome, right...?  We're united by music,
> > dancing
> > > together as one, aren't we...? Not always so.  So I was a little
> bummed
> > > out,
> > > thinking Berlin wouldn't open its arms to a freaky hippie raver girl
> > from
> > > San Francisco. But, here, as in many cities, if you dig deep enough,
> you
> > > can
> > > find the beating heart of the underground. Here at this loft party, I
> > > could
> > > talk to anyone, everyone was kind, no fights, no drunken outbursts, n=
o
> > > creepy guys hitting on me, just a bunch of good people having fun and
> > > being
> > > free.  Totally brought me back to my early days of raving. What a
> > > fantastic
> > > party!
> > >
> > > I left as the sun was coming up, and caught the train back to my flat=
,
> > > watching the last stars burn out from the sky. What a great night!
> > >
> > > That's all for now.  I hope all of you have a fantastic New Year's
> Eve!
> > >
> > >
> > > Love Chelsea
> > > reporting from Berlin, city of joyous techno and delicious falafel.
> > >
